[Online] 2010. ===Recent reported sightings=== *On the night of July 22, 2008, about 11:27 p.m, [[Closed-circuit television|CCTV]] footage of a lemonade factory in [[Nong Suea District]], [[Pathum Thani Province]] captured quite clearly an alleged Krasue. The Krasue appears near one side of the factory wall adjacent to the field. When a smartphone's camera was used to take a shot of the CCTV footage in order to zoom at it closer, an old woman living alone in that area was seen in the image. Local people insist that they see strange lights and hear strange sounds at night for about a year. However, when the old woman seen in the image died, sightings of the Krasue reportedly stopped. Asst. Prof. Dr. Chawan Koopipat, an expert in photography and video technology from [[Chulalongkorn University]] checked the CCTV footage and determined that it was not edited. According to the professor, the Krasue in the CCTV footage probably was a result of the lighting, which has movement on the upper part and reflecting on the bottom wet and damp area of the land that was not farmed giving the illusion of a Krasue. *Strange red lights floating up the paddy fields in the area of [[Phachi District]], [[Ayutthaya Province]], near Wat Tako were sighted in mid-June 2014 and was believed to be from a Krasue. Soon after, hundreds of teenagers (in some nights ranging to thousands) flocked in the area reportedly to prove the truth. This has caused damage to this field. The landlord insists that there are no Krasue here and the lights seen were actually a floating lantern bird chaser.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ma8aLhCVOpc|title=ปากโป้ง - วัยรุ่นนับร้อย แห่ล่าดวงไฟประหลาดโผล่กลางทุ่งนา เชื่อว่าเป็นกระสือ 1/2|date=2014-06-23|accessdate=2017-08-19|language=thai|website=[[Channel 8 (Thailand)|Channel 8]]}} {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gyzOyN4mqxA|title=ปากโป้ง - วัยรุ่นนับร้อย แห่ล่าดวงไฟประหลาดโผล่กลางทุ่งนา เชื่อว่าเป็นกระสือ 2/2|date=2014-06-23|accessdate=2017-08-19|language=thai|website=Channel 8}} *In September 2015, one image was shared on online social networks allegedly shot at Ban Phai village, in the area of [[Chae Hom District]], [[Lampang Province]], depicting a Krasue that has guts and internal organs trapped with thorny branches. However, the villagers denied the report and clarified that there was no village named Ban Phai at the area.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UNIXxhUgmx4|title=ชาว อ.แจ้ห่ม จ.ลำปางยัน ไม่มีผีกระสือตามที่แชร์ภาพกัน|date=2015-09-23|accessdate=2017-08-19|language=thai|website=[[Channel 5 (Thailand)|Channel 5]]}} *The death of a great number of chickens from mysterious circumstances at a farm in [[Nakhon Luang District]], Ayutthaya Province, on the night of October 4, 2015 was blamed by local villagers on the activity of the Krasue.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynews.co.th/regional/352368 |website=[[Dailynews (Thailand)|Daily News]]|title= ผวาไก่ตายปริศนาทั้งหมู่บ้าน เชื่อฝีมือ'กระสือ-ปอบ'กัดกิน|language=Thai}}{{cite web|url=http://www.matichon.co.th/news_detail.php?newsid=1444284313|website= Matichon|title= อวสานข่าวลือปอบ-กระสือ! ปศุสัตว์อยุธยาสรุป "สุนัขแอบกัดไก่ตาย"|language=Thai}} *In February 2016, at Ban Don Pho Thong, [[Mueang Suphan Buri District]], [[Suphan Buri Province]], some villagers found strange lights floating at night which they believed to be a Krasue. This news has caused many people to panic.{{cite web|website=[[Channel 7 (Thailand)|Channel 7]]|language=Thai|date=2016-02-25|accessdate=2017-07-29|url=http://news.ch7.com/detail/162308/%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%9C%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%84%E0%B8%A5%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%94%E0%B8%A7%E0%B8%87%E0%B9%84%E0%B8%9F%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A8%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%A5%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%95%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%A1%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%94%E0%B9%84%E0%B8%A1%E0%B9%89%E0%B8%84%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%94%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%9B%E0%B9%87%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B0%E0%B8%AA%E0%B8%B7%E0%B8%AD.html|title=เผยคลิปดวงไฟปริศนาลอยตามยอดไม้ ชาวบ้านเชื่อกระสือออกหากิน}} *In May 2016, villagers at Ban Khok Ta Kerd, [[Mueang Surin District]], [[Surin Province]] saw strange green and red lights rising up and down the paddy fields at night.{{cite web|website=[[Channel 3 (Thailand)|3SD]]|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2yMZhXz3SwQ|title=พิสูจน์ความจริง กับ บิณฑ์ บรรลือฤทธิ์ พิสูจน์ดวงไฟประหลาด "กระสือ" !? 26-05-59 TV3 Official|date=2016-05-26|accessdate=2017-07-29|author=[[Bin Bunluerit]]|language=Thai}} *In early August 2016 at Ban Song Yang, [[Mueang Amnat Charoen District]], [[Amnat Charoen Province]], video clips from smartphone cameras shot by individuals in the area showed red lights floating at night, believed to be a Krasue.{{cite web|website=Amarin TV|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FVU8fyBUqhA&t=10s|date=2016-08-06|accessdate=2017-07-29|title=ทุบโต๊ะข่าว : กระสือโผล่!ชาวอำนาจเจริญเเตกตื่นเห็นดวงไฟประหลาดแห่พิสูจน์นับร้อย 06/08/59|language=Thai}} *At approximately 09:30 p.m., on September 13, 2016, CCTV footage from a house in the [[Tha Ruea District]], Ayutthaya Province, captured strange lights. The woman owner of the house who first reviewed the CCTV footage said she was watching television at that time and she heard a loud barking dog. She went out to check the source of the sound but she did not see anything, so she looked at the CCTV monitor. She saw the strange lights which she watched for almost an hour, until the lights floated in the fence of her house and moved near the [[chicken coop]] and the [[Phyllanthus acidus|star gooseberry]] tree. She became scared and called her neighbor, along with her father and her two other employees, whom she all asked to help her investigate the lights. However, they found nothing. She said that at the time of the event, there was bad weather during two to three days, it's sprinkling and nighttime comes faster than normal. After another 10 days at 08:28 p.m. on 23 September, she saw again the lights in the backyard. This time she asked her son to investigate the lights but her son found nothing. Their neighbors were believed to be a Krasue. At that time, there were chickens and cats that the villagers were missing for unknown reasons.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NJ5-_iBjk3A|title=รายการบันทึกลึกลับ " กระสือ..กรุงเก่า " 08/10/59 EP 2/3|date=2016-11-12|accessdate=2017-07-30|language=Thai|website=miraclechannel tvthailand}} However, according to Dr. Jessada Denduangboripant, a skeptic, the strange lights actually came from the [[flashlight]] held by someone in front of the house.{{cite web|date=2016-09-27|url=http://news.sanook.com/2074058/|title=อ.เจษฎา ชี้ คลิปกระสือ อยุธยา ที่แท้ขโมยจะเข้าบ้าน|accessdate=2017-07-31|language=Thai|website=Sanook.com}}. This explanation however was rejected by the television program reporting the incident. {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zuHUYN1qZzM&t=206s|title=รายการบันทึกลึกลับ " กระสือ..กรุงเก่า " 08/10/59 EP 3/3|language=Thai|date=2016-11-12|accessdate=2017-07-31|website=miraclechannel tvthailand}} *By the end of 2016, one image has been shared on online social networks in Thailand. The image was shot in [[Buachet District]], Surin Province, and shows an entity that looks like a human's face on a tree at night nearby a light. The image is believed to be depicting a Krasue.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OoLY-QGkp-Y|website=[[Workpoint TV]]|title=กระสือหรือคน โผล่บนต้นไม้ที่สุรินทร์ l ข่าวเวิร์คพอยท์ (เช้า) 29 ธ.ค.59|date=2016-12-29|accessdate=2017-07-28|language=Thai}} *In early 2017, at Ban Lao Luang, [[Mueang Kalasin District]], [[Kalasin Province]], a stampede occurred and villagers rode in motorcycles to go to the area where an individual shot a video showing red lights floating at 100 meters above the ground. The video shows that the light has already floated away. A man reported that at the time he lived in [[Yang Talat District]], he would frequent the woods at night and while at the woods he looked at the sky and saw a Krasue. According to him, he cannot see the Krasue's face because it was covered by long hair, but he can make out the long fangs and the bright lights. It was reportedly able to escape when he drew his gun to shoot it. {{cite web|website=[[Khaosod]]|url=https://www.khaosod.co.th/around-thailand/news_196091|title=ผวาแสงไฟลอยเข้าหมู่บ้าน!! ชาวบ้านเห็นเป็นกระสือ กลัวแต่อยากรู้ ขับรถตามดวงไฟ(คลิป)|language=Thai|date=2017-01-26|accessdate=2017-07-30}} *In mid-July 2017 a video clip was shared on online social networks, showing an alleged entity floating in the air at the same level as a tree in the area at night. The entity was being witnessed by either a [[security guard]] or a police officer standing and looking with suspicion. There is no information as to where the video came from, and no additional details were available. However, it was found out that the entity was actually a [[Unmanned aerial vehicle|drone]], decorated as a man's face as a hoax.{{cite web|url=https://www.thaich8.com/news_detail/41650/%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%89%E0%B8%A5%E0%B8%A2%E0%B9%81%E0%B8%A5%E0%B9%89%E0%B8%A7%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B0%E0%B8%AA%E0%B8%B7%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%88%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%84%E0%B8%A5%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%94%E0%B8%B1%E0%B8%87-%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%B5%E0%B9%88%E0%B9%81%E0%B8%97%E0%B9%89%E0%B9%81%E0%B8%84%E0%B9%88%E0%B9%82%E0%B8%94%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%95%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%94%E0%B8%AB%E0%B8%99%E0%B9%89%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%84%E0%B8%99|website=Channel 8|title=เฉลยแล้วกระสือจากคลิปดัง ที่แท้แค่โดรนติดหน้าคน|date=2017-07-20|accessdate=2017-07-29|language=Thai}} ===Krasue references in Thai culture=== [[File:Luminescent mushroom.jpg|thumb|Glowing mushroom in Khonkaen province is called “ Krasue Mushroom”.]] There is information from The Royal Academy which provides examples of how belief in the Krasue has been reflected in Thai culture for centuries, for example: #An abnormally tiny banana (caused by a mutation) is said to be eaten by a Krasue. #A gluttonous person who eats too fast is usually said to “eat like a Krasue” or to be “as gluttonous as Krasue”. #Glowing mushroom in Khonkaen province is called “ Krasue Mushroom”.2. Siamsouth. เห็ดกระสือ หรือ เห็ดเรืองแสง ควบคุมไส้เดือนฝอยรากปมในมะเขือเทศ. siamsouth.com. [Online] 2008. #In Chonburi province, there is a village named “ Nong Krasue” (Krasue marsh). Now, the name has been changed to “ Nong Krasaem” (Happiness marsh) to make it less scary.1. Janputt, Pitchayatun. Nong Krasue. [interv.] Sorayutt Sututsanajinda. January 21, 2013. ==Scientific explanation== A possible scientific explanation is that Krasue sightings are caused by blazing flames from methane gas particles emitted from rotten organic matters such as found in farms and fields, where Krasue sightings are commonly reported. However, according to Associate Professor Dr. Sirintornthep Towprayoon, an energy researcher from [[King Mongkut's University of Technology Thonburi]], the hypothesis that the Krasue is actually burning methane gas particles is impossible because not enough methane is emitted from rotten organic matter to be able to cause an ignition and that even if the methane gas particles did ignited, the burning would be confined to the surface of the organic, flammable matter and will not lead to floating flames that allegedly give the illusion of the Krasue. An anatomical interpretation is that when the head is pulled off from the human body, other organs such as the intestines, heart, and lungs will not come together with the head.{{cite web|title=บางอ้อ : ท้าพิสูจน์ตำนานกระสือ|website=บางอ้อ|url=http://video.sanook.com/player/398603/|language=Thai|date=2009-06-17}} ==Modern popular culture== Countries where the Krasue tale is popular have adapted it to film.[http://tracker.zaerc.com/torrents-details.php?id=8238 Krasue movies] Several [[Cinema of Thailand|Thai films]] depict this spirit, including 1973 movie ''[[Krasue Sao]]'' (Ghosts of Guts Eater), {{lang-th|กระสือสาว}} with [[Sombat Metanee]], which features a fight between two Krasues,[http://diedangerdiediekill.blogspot.com/2011/06/ghost-of-guts-eater-thailand-1973.html Ghosts of Guts Eater (Thailand 1973)] ''[[Itthirit Nam Man Phrai]]'' {{lang-th|อิทธิฤทธิ์น้ำมันพราย}} made in 1984, with [[Tanid Pongmanoon]] and [[Praew Mardmarud]],[http://tonpalm.tarad.com/shop/t/tonpalm/img-lib/spd_2011031393404_b.jpg Itthirith Nam Man Phrai (Thailand 1984)] ''[[Krasue Kat Pop]]'' {{lang-th|กระสือกัดปอบ}} (1990) with [[Bin Bunluerit]] and [[Trirak Rakkarndee]],[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=24V4743fiw8 Krasue Kat Pop (Thailand 1990)] ''[[Krasue Krahailueat]]'' (Bloodthirsty Krasue), {{lang-th|กระสือกระหายเลือด}}, made in 1995 with [[Thida Teerarat]],[http://www.thaifilm.com/imgUpload/reply773761_0.jpg Krasue Krahailueat (Thailand 1995)] [[Demonic Beauty|''Tamnan Krasue'']] {{lang-th|ตำนานกระสือ}} (Demonic Beauty) released in 2002, ''[[Krasue Valentine]]'' (2006) by [[Yuthlert Sippapak]], ''Krasue'' (The Gluttonous Fear) {{lang-th|กระสือ}} made in 2007, with [[Jedsada Roongsakorn]] and [[Sirintorn Parnsamutr]],[http://vcddvd88.com/imgs/cd/fear2.jpg The Gluttonous Fear (Thailand 2007)] ''[[Krasue Fat Pop]]'' {{lang-th|กระสือฟัดปอบ}} (2009) with [[Chutima Naiyana]], in which Krasue fights against [[Phi Pop]],[http://doopap.files.wordpress.com/2011/03/e0b881e0b8a3e0b8b0e0b8aae0b8b7e0b8ade0b89fe0b8b1e0b894e0b89be0b8ade0b89a.jpg?w=592 Krasue Phat Pop (Thailand 2009)] and ''[[Fullmoon Devil]]'' (2011) {{lang-th|กระสือ}} by [[Komson Thripong]]. Krasue also appears in [[erotic movie]]s such as ''[[Krasue Rak Krasue Sawat]]'' (2014) {{lang-th|กระสือรัก กระสือสวาท}}[http://www.ethaicd.com/show.php?pid=787312 Krasue Rak Krasue Sawat] and ''[[Wan Krasue Sao]]'' (2013) {{lang-th|ว่านกระสือสาว}}[http://group.wunjun.com/mini_hd_one2up/topic/564959-24605 Wan Krasue Sao - ว่านกระสือสาว (2013)] In all these movies Krasue plays a central role, but she also appears in many other movies in lesser roles, such as in ''[[Phi Ta Wan Kap Achan Ta Bo]]'' (2008) {{lang-th|ผีตาหวานกับอาจารย์ตาโบ๋}},[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PndW6giDfv8 ผีตาหวานกับอาจารย์ตาโบ๋ (Phi Ta Wan Kap Achan Ta Bo) movie - YouTube] among others.[http://image.dek-d.com/27/0256/1740/117786706 นธัญ จอมนางลวงโลก movie poster] Krasue, as ''Ap'' (also spelt ''Arp'' or ''Arb''), is present in the [[Cinema of Cambodia|Cambodian horror film]]s ''[[Neang Arp]]'' (Lady Vampire) (2004),[http://www.moviecambodia.com/2012/07/neang-arp.html Neang Arp - Moviecambodia] ''[[Tiyen Arp]]'' (Heredity of Krasue) (2007), ''[[Arb Kalum]]'' (The Sexiest Krasue) (2009)[http://www.khmerlife.com/showthread.php/23-Khmai-HORROR Khmai HORROR] and ''Phlerng Chhes Arb''.[http://www.angkorwat.com/index.php?com=info&wprdtid=39&wid=2344&wpid=KHMMOV064&wcatid=58&wmtypeid=65&wc=14&winst=1&whp=0 Khmer Movies - Phlerng Chhes Arb] [[Cinema of Hong Kong|Hong Kong]]'s ''[[Witch with the Flying Head]]'' (飛頭魔女) (1977), which includes a ''Krasue'' spitting flames and firing laser beams and that was [[Dubbing (filmmaking)|dubbed]] in Thai as ''Krasue Sawat'' (กระสือสวาท), meaning "Lovely Krasue",[http://www.dvdaddicted.it/forum/uploads/1315397014/gallery_31_728_153102.jpg Witch with the Flying Head - Thai poster] and [[Indonesia]]'s ''[[Mystics in Bali]]'' (1981) also feature local versions of Krasue. In the [[Vietnam War]]-era drama ''Freedom Deal''[https://store.steampowered.com/app/720180/FREEDOM_DEAL_Story_of_Lucky__Vietnam_War_Supernatural_Historical_Drama Freedom Deal VOD] by [[Camerado]], [[Richard M. Nixon|President Nixon]] orders the 1970 military incursion into Cambodia, unwittingly unleashing a legion of local ghosts similar to the Krasue.[https://www.facebook.com/FREEDOMDEAL Freedom Deal] This ghost appears periodically in [[Thai television soap opera]]s (ละคร). ''[[Krasue (lakhon)|Krasue]]'', a popular ''lakhon'' aired between 20 December 1994 and 21 March 1995,[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HrxSugyM_S0 Krasue - The Floating Head Thai Ghost Lakorn.flv] as well as the more recent ''[[Krasue Mahanakhon]]'' (กระสือมหานคร) —in which the ghost story for a change is against a background of young city people instead of the usual rural or traditional setting[http://drama.tlcthai.com/%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B0%E0%B8%AA%E0%B8%B7%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%A1%E0%B8%AB%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%84%E0%B8%A3-%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B7%E0%B9%88%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%A2%E0%B9%88%E0%B8%AD Krasue Mahanakhon - Thai Channel 3]— feature a ''Krasue'' in the central role. The [[theme song]] of the 1994 ''Krasue'' TV soap opera became very famous.[http://topicstock.pantip.com/chalermthai/topicstock/2008/05/A6622501/A6622501-0.jpg Krasue - Lakorn Theme song] There was a [[remake]] in 2011 named ''[[Krasue Cham Sin]]'' (กระสือจำศีล),[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tn3WddjOGec ละครกระสือจำศีล ''(Lakhon Krasue Chamsin)''] but it was poorly cast and produced, not being able to reach the popularity of the 1994 ''lakhon''. A Krasue has been also comically featured in a [[Osram Sylvania|Sylvania]] light bulb commercial for Thai audiences[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XRFPf0dgfSg Sylvania light bulb commercial] and in a more recent dietary supplement ad.[http://www.thesecretplus.com/ On Air ทางฟรีทีวีแล้ววันนี้ !!! กับอาหารเสริม The Secret Plus] A rather ugly Krasue also appears in the animated film ''[[Nak (film)|Nak]]''.[https://library.mju.ac.th/film/detail.php?id=1651 Films Database - Nak] Representations of Krasue, often humorous,[http://www.bloggang.com/data/inmylife-inmyworld/picture/1188699676.jpg ''Krasue'' image] are very common in [[Thai comics|Thai comic]] [[comic book|book]]s.[http://www.bloggang.com/data/real-ghost/picture/1220969448.gif Comic Vignette][http://uc.exteenblog.com/yochi/images/ptoon/T1_P4.png Comic page][http://www.letcomic.com/2011/webboard/stocks/attach/ba1c8ef98aca81c958707a40cb777c8d.jpg Let Comic - Krasue leaving her body] Since this ghost is a popular subject in some places of Southeast Asia, especially in Thailand, there are even costumes,[http://www.thairath.co.th/content/ent/36769 Comedian with Krasue costume] dolls,[http://img256.imageshack.us/img256/4045/img6556res.jpg Krasue doll] keyholders[http://2.bp.blogspot.com/_6vvd1Dwa1VU/TUrCsUb9YeI/AAAAAAAAAAg/1YPAQUVHExE/s1600/102_1314.gif Krasue keyholder] and lamps[http://moohin.com/trips/bangkok/sanghee/300/42.jpg Krasue lamp] in Krasue form. The Krasue is one of the enemies found in ''[[Indivisible (video game)|Indivisible]]'', a [[role-playing game]].{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} ==See also== *[[Thai folklore]] *[[Hungry ghost]] *[[Leyak]] *[[Rokurokubi#Rokurokubi whose heads come off (nukekubi)|Nukekubi]] *[[Manananggal]] (Philippine mythology) *[[Penanggalan]] (Malay culture) ==Bibliography== *Chutima Pragatwutisarn (2010) (ชุติมา ประกาศวุฒิสาร), ''Evil Woman in a Beautiful Body: Femininity and the Crisis of Modernity in Thai Society'', Chulalongkorn University *Baumann, Benjamin (2013) ''Tamnan Krasue - Constructing a Khmer Ghost for a Thai Film''. in: [http://kyotoreview.org/issue-14/tamnan-krasue-constructing-a-khmer-ghost-for-a-thai-film/ Kyoto Review of Southeast Asia (14)] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[http://kyotoreview.org/issue-14/tamnan-krasue-constructing-a-khmer-ghost-for-a-thai-film/ Tamnan Krasue-Constructing a Khmer Ghost for a Thai Film] *[http://www.macula.tv/gallery/Illustration/gallery/krasue/gallery.htm Macula's illustration of (krasue)] {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} {{Ghosts}} [[Category:Southeast Asian culture]] [[Category:Fictional body parts]] [[Category:Thai ghosts]] [[Category:Laotian legendary creatures]] [[Category:Cambodian legendary creatures]] [[Category:Mythological hematophages]] [[Category:Female legendary creatures]] [[Category:Cambodian legends]] [[Category:Mythological monsters]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Use Indian English|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox field hockey player | name = Len Aiyappa | fullname = Len Aiyappa Ballachanda Madappa | image = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1979|03|31|df=yes}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nickname = | height = {{convert|5|ft|8|in|m|abbr=on}}<ref>{{cite web |url= https://sports.yahoo.com/olympics/athens2004/ind/Len+Aiyappa+Ballachandra+Mallappa/9004272 |title= 2004 Olympics Athens: Player's Profile}}</ref> | weight = <!-- {{convert|}} (yyyy) --> | website = <!-- {{URL|www.example.com}} --> | position = [[Defender (association football)|Fullback]] | clubs1 = [[Bharat Petroleum|BPCL]] | years1 = | caps1 = | goals1 = | clubs2 = [[Air India]] | years2 = | caps2 = | goals2 = | clubs3 = Telekom Malaysia HC | years3 = 2005 | caps3 = | goals3 = | clubs4 = [[Bangalore Hi-Fliers]] | years4 = 2005 - 2008 | caps4 = | goals4 = | clubs5 = [[Karnataka Lions]] | years5 = 2012 - present | caps5 = 12 | goals5 = 13 | nationalteam1 = [[India men's national field hockey team|India]] | nationalyears1 = ? - 2005 | nationalcaps1 = | nationalgoals1 = | turnedpro = | coach = | retired = | coaching = | updated = 17 January 2013 | medaltemplates-expand = yes | medaltemplates = <!-- don't include medal templates unless there is a medal {{MedalSport | Men’s [[Field Hockey]] }} {{MedalCountry | {{IND}} }} --> }}
'''Len Aiyappa''' (born 31 March 1979) is an [[Indian people|Indian]] professional [[field hockey]] player. He remained one of [[India men's national field hockey team|India's]] best drag-flickers until he retired from the national team following a fallout with the [[Indian Hockey Federation]] in 2006.<ref>{{cite news |title= Hockey: Len gives up on India |url= http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/top-stories/Hockey-Len-gives-up-on-India/articleshow/1406937.cms |publisher= [[The Times of India]] |date= 2006-02-09 |accessdate= 2013-01-17}}</ref> He last played for India during the [[Sultan Azlan Shah Cup]] in 2005.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.indianhockey.com/FeaturedStories/tabid/54/EntryId/25/Jothi-ruined-many-careers-Len.aspx |title= Jothi ruined many careers: Len |publisher= indianhockey.com |date= 2008-04-25 |accessdate= 2013-01-17}}</ref>
==Career== Aiyappa, playing for [[Karnataka Lions]] in the inaugural season of the [[World Series Hockey]] became the top scorer for the team and third overall, scoring 13 goals in 12 games. He joined the team on the insistence of [[Dhanraj Pillay]] and the coach of Karnataka Lions, Jude Felix and scored a hat-trick in the game against [[Chandigarh Comets]].<ref>{{cite news |title= Did it for my mother: Len Aiyappa |url= http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/hockey/world-series-hockey/Did-it-for-my-mother-Len-Aiyappa/articleshow/12182097.cms | publisher= The Times of India |date= 2012-03-08 |accessdate= 2013-01-17 }}</ref>
==Personal life== He is married.

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Use British English|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Christina 'Licorice' McKechnie | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Christina McKechnie | alias = Likky Lambert
Likky McKechnie | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1945|10|2|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Edinburgh]], [[Scotland]] | death_date = | origin = | instrument = Vocals | genre = | occupation = Singer | years_active = 1967–1977 | label = | associated_acts = [[The Incredible String Band]]
[[Robin Williamson]] and his Merry Band
[[Mick Woodmansey|Woody Woodmansey]] | website = |module={{Infobox person|child=yes |disappeared_status={{missing for|1990}} }} }} '''Christina 'Licorice' McKechnie''' (born 2 October 1945) is a Scottish musician. She was a singer and songwriter in the [[Incredible String Band]] between 1968 and 1972. Her whereabouts have been unknown since 1990. ==Biography== McKechnie was born in [[Edinburgh]], [[Scotland]]. After reading her poetry at folk clubs in Edinburgh, she met the musician [[Robin Williamson]], but left home in her teens with the intention of marrying [[Bert Jansch]]. The [[banns]] were published but the wedding never took place. Jansch left her behind to travel to [[Morocco]] in 1963, and, according to Williamson, "she fell into [my] arms". In 1966 she travelled to Morocco with Williamson, and was later involved in the Incredible String Band's recordings. Her first contribution to the band came in the form of [[backing vocals]] on the track "Painting Box", on the 1967 album ''[[The 5000 Spirits or the Layers of the Onion]]''. By 1968, she was regarded as a fully-fledged member of the band, usually as a backing singer and [[percussionist]], and she performed with them at the [[Woodstock Festival]] in August 1969. By 1972 she had left the band, after her relationship with Williamson ended.Whittaker, Adrian, ed. (2003). ''Be Glad: The Incredible String Band Compendium''. {{ISBN|1-900924-64-1}}. In 1974, McKechnie appeared onstage at a [[Scientology]] benefit concert in [[East Grinstead]] with [[Mike Garson]], [[Mick Woodmansey|Woody Woodmansey]], Leonard Halliwell and others, before moving to California and joining the Silver Moon Band. She later married the musician Brian Lambert; they later divorced. She appeared with Williamson and his Merry Band in 1977, and is credited as Likky Lambert on the 1977 album ''[[Journey's Edge]]'', before joining Woody Woodmansey's band U-Boat. She visited Edinburgh in 1986 to see her family, but her whereabouts have been unknown since 1990, when, according to her sister, she was in [[Sacramento, California]], apparently recovering from surgery. The music journalist [[Mark Ellen]] wrote in ''[[Mojo (magazine)|Mojo]]'' magazine in 2000 that she was "last seen in 1987 hitchhiking across the [[Arizona]] Desert. Not even her family has heard from her since." Fellow former Incredible String Band member [[Rose Simpson]] was quoted as saying: "There's a possibility she may be dead."Ellen, Mark (2000). "Supertroupers—The Incredible String Band". ''MOJO''. August 2000, issue 81, EMAP Metro, London. p. 46. ==See also== *[[List of people who disappeared mysteriously]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.angelfire.com/biz3/ISB/likkie.html "The Likky Shrine"] {{The Incredible String Band}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McKechnie, Licorice}} [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:20th-century Scottish singers]] [[Category:Scottish songwriters]] [[Category:Scottish female singers]] [[Category:Missing people]] [[Category:Musicians from Edinburgh]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Possibly living people]] [[Category:1990s missing person cases]] [[Category:Missing person cases in California]] [[Category:20th-century women singers]] [[Category:The Incredible String Band members]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} <!--Per Wikipedia:Manual of style, use she/her to refer to Lili Elbe throughout her life.--> {{Infobox person | name = Lili Elbe | image = Lili Elbe 1926.jpg | caption = Lili Elbe in 1926 | birth_name = Einar Magnus Andreas Wegener | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1882|12|28}} | birth_place = [[Vejle]], Denmark | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1931|9|13|1882|12|28}} | death_place = [[Dresden]], Germany | nationality = Danish | other_names = Lili Ilse Elvenes | occupation = | known_for = }} '''Lili Ilse Elvenes''' (28 December 1882 – 13 September 1931), better known as '''Lili Elbe''', was a Danish [[transgender]] woman and among the early recipients of [[sex reassignment surgery]].<ref>[[Magnus Hirschfeld|Hirschfeld, Magnus]]. ''Chirurgische Eingriffe bei Anomalien des Sexuallebens: Therapie der Gegenwart'', pp. 67, 451–455</ref><ref name=aj>[https://web.archive.org/web/20071010080625/http://andrejkoymasky.com/liv/fam/bioe1/elbe1.html Lili Elbe]. andrejkoymasky.com. 17 May 2003</ref>
Elbe was born '''Einar Magnus Andreas Wegener''',{{sfn|Meyer|2015|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=T4yyCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA15&dq=%22Einar%20Magnus%20Andreas%20Wegener%22 15], [https://books.google.com/books?id=T4yyCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA310&dq=%22Einar%20Magnus%20Andreas%20Wegener%22 310–313]}} and was a successful painter under that name. During this time she also presented as Lili (sometimes spelled Lily) and was introduced publicly as Einar's sister.
After successfully [[transitioning (transgender)|transitioning]] in 1930, she changed her legal name to Lili Ilse Elvenes and stopped painting altogether.<ref name="Meyer pp. 311-314">{{harvnb|Meyer|2015|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=T4yyCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA311 311–314]}}</ref> The name Lili Elbe was given to her by Copenhagen journalist Louise Lassen.<ref name="Trans Media">{{cite news|url=http://www.transmediawatch.org/timeline.html|website=Trans Media Watch|accessdate=February 3, 2016|title=A Trans Timeline – Trans Media Watch}}</ref> She died from complications involving a uterus transplant.<ref name="Biography.com, 2015" /><ref name="The Week, 2015" /><ref name="Hist v H.wood">{{cite web|title=The Danish Girl (2015)|url=http://www.historyvshollywood.com/reelfaces/danish-girl/|website=HistoryVSHollywood.com|publisher=History vs Hollywood|accessdate=1 February 2016}}{{better source|date=August 2016}}</ref> Her autobiography ''Man into Woman'' was published posthumously in 1933.<ref>{{cite web| author=Worthen, Meredith | date = n.d. | url=http://www.biography.com/people/lili-elbe-090815|title=Lili Elbe – Painter | publisher=Biography.com|accessdate=August 15, 2016}}</ref>
==Early life== It is generally believed that Elbe was born in 1882, in [[Vejle]], Denmark. Her year of birth is sometimes stated as 1886, which appears to be from a book about her which has some facts changed to protect the identities of the persons involved. Facts about the life of Elbe's wife [[Gerda Wegener|Gerda Gottlieb]] suggest that the 1882 date is correct because they married while at college in 1904, when she would have been just eighteen if the 1886 date were correct.<ref name=cp>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927182419/http://www.cphpost.dk/get/59398.html She and She: The Marriage of Gerda and Einar Wegener]. The Copenhagen Post. 3 July 2000</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politietsregisterblade.dk/index.php?option=com_sfup&controller=politregisterblade&task=viewRegisterblad&id=1923045&limitstart=20 |title=Ejner Mogens Wegener, 28-12-1882, Vejle Stillinger: Maler |publisher=Politietsregisterblade.dk |date= |accessdate=30 December 2011}}</ref>
It is speculated that Elbe was [[intersex]],<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hoyer, ed.|first1=Niels|title=Man into woman : the first sex change, a portrait of Lili Elbe : the true and remarkable transformation of the painter Einar Wegener|date=2004|publisher=Blue Boat Books|location=London|isbn=9780954707200|pages=vii, 26–27, 172}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Lili Elbe's autobiography, Man into Woman|url=https://oii.org.au/789/book-review-man-woman/|website=OII Australia – Intersex Australia|publisher=[[OII Australia]]|accessdate=1 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Vacco|first1=Patrick|title=Les Miserables Actor Eddie Redmayne to Star as Queer Artist Lili Elbe|url=http://www.advocate.com/arts-entertainment/film/2014/04/29/les-miserables-actor-eddie-redmayne-star-queer-artist-lili-elbe|accessdate=1 September 2015|work=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]|date=29 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Could this be Eddie Redmayne's most challenging role?|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2969353/A-cross-dresser-1920s-Paris-loving-husband-sex-change-pioneer-Extraordinary-Lili-Elbe-Eddie-Redmayne-set-play-new-film.html|accessdate=1 September 2015|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|date=1 September 2015}}</ref>{{better source|date=September 2018}} although that has been disputed.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kaufmann|first1=Jodi|title=Transfiguration: a narrative analysis of male‐to‐female transsexual|journal=International Journal of Qualitative Studies in Education|date=January 2007|volume=20|issue=1|pages=1–13|doi=10.1080/09518390600923768}}</ref> Some reports indicate that she already had rudimentary ovaries in her abdomen and she may have had [[Klinefelter syndrome]].<ref name="Biography.com, 2015"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Matt & Andrej Koymasky - Famous GLTB – Lili Elbe|url=http://andrejkoymasky.com/liv/fam/bioe1/elbe01.html|website=HistoryVSHollywood.com|publisher=Matt & Andrej Koymasky|date=17 May 2003|accessdate=2 February 2016}}{{better source|date=August 2016}}</ref>{{better source|date=August 2016}}
== Marriage and modelling == [[File:Lili Elbe c1920.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Lili Elbe c. 1920]] [[File:Lili Elbe - Poplerne langs Hobro Fjord - 1908.png|thumb|left|''Poples along Hobro Fjord'' from 1908 - an example of Lili Elbe's work as landscape painter.]] Elbe met [[Gerda Wegener|Gerda Gottlieb]] while they were students at the [[Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts]] in Copenhagen,<ref name = art>{{cite web|url=http://www.vintage-movie-poster.com/Paintings/Fine_art.htm |title=Conway's Vintage Treasures |publisher=Vintage-movie-poster.com |date= |accessdate=8 April 2014}}</ref> and they married in 1904 when Gottlieb was 19 and Elbe was 22.<ref name = cp/> They worked as illustrators, with Elbe's specializing in landscape paintings, and Gottlieb illustrated books and fashion magazines.
They traveled through Italy and France, eventually settling in Paris in 1912, where Elbe could live openly as a woman, and Gottlieb identified as lesbian.<ref name="cp" /> Elbe received the Neuhausens prize in 1907 and exhibited at [[Kunstnernes Efterårsudstilling]] (the Artists' Fall Exhibition), at the Vejle Art Museum, and in the Saloon and Salon d'Automme in Paris. She is represented at Vejle Art Museum in Denmark.<ref name="aob">[https://web.archive.org/web/20060618025105/http://www.renaissanceblackpool.org/art.html The Arts and Transgender]. renaissanceblackpool.org</ref>
Elbe started dressing in women's clothes after filling in for Gottlieb's absentee model; she was asked to wear stockings and heels so her legs could substitute for those of the model. Elbe felt surprisingly comfortable in the clothing and began identifying as a woman.<ref name = aob/> Over time, Gottlieb became famous for her paintings of beautiful women with haunting, almond-shaped eyes dressed in chic fashions. In 1913, the unsuspecting public was shocked to discover that the model who had inspired Gottlieb's depictions of ''petites femmes fatales'' was in fact Elbe.<ref name = cp/>
In the 1920s and 1930s, Elbe regularly presented as a woman, attending various festivities and entertaining guests in her house. One of the things she liked to do was disappear into the streets of Paris in the throngs of revelers during the Carnival, wearing her modeling fashions.<ref name=gerda>[https://web.archive.org/web/20080110152844/http://home.get2net.dk/abra-ken/Gerda.htm Gerda Wegener]. get2net.dk</ref><ref name = hist>{{cite web|url=http://www.lgbthistorymonth.org.uk/history/lilielbe.htm |title=Lili Elbe (1886–1931) |publisher=LGBT History Month |date= |accessdate=8 April 2014}}</ref> Elbe was sometimes introduced by Gottlieb as her sister when she was dressed in female attire.<ref name = aj/> Only her closest friends knew once she had transitioned.
== Surgeries and dissolution of marriage == [[File:Lili Elbe by Gerda Wegener.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Lili Elbe by Gerda Gottlieb]] In 1930, Elbe went to [[Weimar Germany|Germany]] for [[sex reassignment surgery]], which was highly experimental at the time. A series of four operations were carried out over a period of two years.<ref name = hist/> The first surgery, [[Inguinal orchiectomy|removal of the testicles]], was made under the supervision of sexologist [[Magnus Hirschfeld]] in Berlin.<ref name = hist/> The rest of Elbe's surgeries were carried out by [[Kurt Warnekros]], a doctor at the Dresden Municipal Women's Clinic.<ref name=th>Brown, Kay (1997) [https://web.archive.org/web/20080308205659/http://www.transhistory.net/history/TH_Lili_Elbe.html Lili Elbe]. Transhistory.net.</ref> The second operation was to implant an ovary onto her abdominal musculature, the third to remove the penis and the scrotum,<ref name="Meyer pp. 271-281">{{harvnb|Meyer|2015|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=T4yyCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA271 271–281]}}</ref> and the fourth to transplant a uterus and construct a vaginal canal.<ref name="Biography.com, 2015">{{cite web|title=Lili Elbe Biography|url=http://www.biography.com/people/lili-elbe-090815|website=Biography.com|publisher=A&E Television Networks|accessdate=December 11, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Harrod, 2015">{{cite news|last1=Harrod|first1=Horatia|title=The tragic true story behind The Danish Girl|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/film/the-danish-girl/true-story-lili-elbe-transgender/|accessdate=11 December 2015|work=The Telegraph|date=8 December 2015}}</ref>
At the time of Elbe's last surgery, her case was already a sensation in newspapers of Denmark and Germany. A Danish court invalidated the couple's marriage in October 1930,<ref name="Meyer pp. 308-311">{{harvnb|Meyer|2015|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=T4yyCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA308 308–311]}}</ref> and Elbe managed to get her sex and name legally changed, including receiving a passport as Lili Ilse Elvenes. She stopped painting, believing it to be something that was part of the identity of Einar. After the dissolution of their marriage, Elbe returned to Dresden for her fourth surgery.
Elbe became the second transgender woman to undergo Gohrbandt's vaginoplasty technique in 1931, after [[Dora Richter]] underwent the same procedure.<ref name="Trans Media"/> Her castration and [[penectomy]] had been performed by Dr. Ludwig Levy-Lenz (1889–1966) the previous year. These preliminaries have sometimes caused confusion over the date of her reassignment surgery.<ref name="Trans Media"/> Gohrbandt's surgery deliberately left remnants of the scrotum intact, with a view to modifying these into labia at a later date, but for reasons that are unclear, he did not perform this further procedure himself. Instead, Elvenes' case was taken over by Dr. Kurt Warnekros (1882–1949), at the Dresden Women's Clinic. Here, the [[labiaplasty]] and a subsequent surgical revision led, in the pre-antibiotic age, to Elbe's death from infection in September 1931.<ref name="Trans Media"/>
The book-burning at the Institute for Sexual Research by Nazi students in May 1933, the obliteration of the Dresden Women's Clinic and its records in the Allied bombing raids of February 1945, and the myth-making process itself have left gaps and inconsistencies in the Lili Elbe narrative that may never be resolved.<ref name="Trans Media"/>
== Death == [[File:Lili Elbe 1930.jpg|thumb|upright|Lili Elbe, 1930]] Elbe began a relationship with French art dealer Claude Lejeune, whom she wanted to marry and with whom she wanted to have children. She was looking forward to her final surgery involving a [[Uterus transplantation|uterus transplant]].<ref name="The Week, 2015"/><ref name="Hist v H.wood"/><ref name="Harrod, 2015"/>
In June 1931, Elbe had an operation which consisted of implanting a uterus and the [[Vaginoplasty|construction of a vagina]], both of which were new and experimental procedures at that time.<ref name="Biography.com, 2015"/> Her immune system rejected the transplanted uterus, however, and she developed an infection. She died on September 13, 1931, three months after the surgery, of cardiac arrest brought on by the infection.<ref name="Biography.com, 2015"/><ref name="The Week, 2015">{{cite news|title=Lili Elbe: the transgender artist behind The Danish Girl|url=http://www.theweek.co.uk/65324/lili-elbe-the-transgender-artist-behind-the-danish-girl|accessdate=1 February 2016|work=This Week Magazine|date=18 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="Hist v H.wood"/><ref name="Harrod, 2015"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Lili Elbe (Einar Wegener) 1882–1931|url=http://danmarkshistorien.dk/leksikon-og-kilder/vis/materiale/lili-elbe-einar-wegener-1882-1931/|website=Danmarkshistorien.dk|language=Danish|publisher=Danmarkshistorien.dk|date=10 September 2013|accessdate=2 February 2016}}</ref>
Elbe was buried on [[Trinitatisfriedhof]] in Dresden. The grave was levelled in the 1960s. In April 2016, a new tombstone was inaugurated, financed by Focus Features, the production company of ''[[The Danish Girl]]''.<ref>http://www.queer.de/bild-des-tages.php?einzel=1485</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Kay|last=Haufe|work=Sächsische Zeitung|title=Hollywood rettet Lili Elbes Grab|date=22 April 2016|language=German|url=http://www.sz-online.de/nachrichten/hollywood-rettet-lili-elbes-grab-3379272.html|accessdate=26 April 2016|trans-title=Hollywood saves Lili Elbe's grave}}</ref> The tombstone does not record the date of Elbe's birth, just her name and places of birth and death.
==In popular culture== The LGBT film festival [[MIX Copenhagen]] gives four "Lili" awards named after Elbe.<ref>{{cite web | title = In Competition | work = | publisher =MIX Copenhagen | date = | url =http://mixcopenhagen.dk/en/in-competition | format = | doi = | accessdate = March 5, 2015 }}</ref>
In 2000, [[David Ebershoff]] wrote ''[[The Danish Girl]]'', a fictionalized account of Elbe's life.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/02/14/books/books-of-the-times-radical-change-and-enduring-love.html|title=BOOKS OF THE TIMES; Radical Change and Enduring Love|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 14, 2000|accessdate=December 11, 2015}}</ref> It was an international bestseller and was translated into a dozen languages. In 2015, it was made into a [[The Danish Girl (film)|film]], also called [[The Danish Girl (film)|''The Danish Girl'']], produced by [[Gail Mutrux]] and [[Neil LaBute]] and starring [[Eddie Redmayne]] as Elbe. The film was well received at the [[Venice Film Festival]] in September 2015,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/09/danish-girl-standing-ovation-venice-1201516383/|title='The Danish Girl' Wows With 10-Minute Standing Ovation In Venice Premiere|publisher=''Deadline''|date=5 September 2015|accessdate=6 September 2015 |language=}}</ref> although it has been criticized for its casting of a [[cisgender]] man to play a transgender woman.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/the-danish-girl-eddie-redmayne-defends-casting-as-trans-artist-lili-elbe-and-reveals-how-much-he-10451250.html |website=[[The Independent]] |first=Jess|last=Denham |date=12 August 2015|accessdate=7 March 2016 |title=The Danish Girl: Eddie Redmayne defends casting as trans artist Lili Elbe after backlash}}</ref> Both the novel and the film omitted topics including Gottlieb's sexuality, which is evidenced by the subjects in her erotic drawings,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://coilhouse.net/2012/08/the-incredibly-true-adventures-of-gerda-wegener-and-lili-elbe/|website=coilhouse.net|date=August 3, 2012|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=The Incredibly True Adventures of Gerda Wegener and Lili Elbe}}</ref> and the disintegration of Gottlieb and Elbe's relationship after their annulment.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.allenandunwin.com/documents/reading-groups/145-the-danish-girl-reading-group-notes|website=allenandunwin.com|accessdate=December 10, 2015|title=Reading Group Notes The Danish Girl}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|30em}} *{{cite book|last=Meyer|first=Sabine|title=»Wie Lili zu einem richtigen Mädchen wurde«: Lili Elbe: Zur Konstruktion von Geschlecht und Identität zwischen Medialisierung, Regulierung und Subjektivierung|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T4yyCwAAQBAJ|year=2015|publisher=transcript Verlag|isbn=978-3-8394-3180-1|ref=harv}}
==Further reading== * ''Man into woman: an authentic record of a change of sex'' / Lili Elbe ; edited by Niels Hoyer [i.e. E. Harthern] ; translated from the German by H.J. Stenning ; introd. by Norman Haire. – London, Jarrold Publisher's, 1933 (Original Danish ed. published in 1931 under title: ''Fra mand til kvinde.'' Later edition: ''Man into woman: the first sex change, a portrait of Lili Elbe – the true and remarkable transformation of the painter Einar Wegener. -'' London, Blue Boat Books, 2004. * ''Schnittmuster des Geschlechts. Transvestitismus und Transsexualität in der frühen Sexualwissenschaft'' by Dr. Rainer Herrn (2005), pp. 204–211. {{ISBN|3-89806-463-8}}. German study containing a detailed account of the operations of Lili Elbe, their preparations and the role of Magnus Hirschfeld. * "When a woman paints women" / Andrea Rygg Karberg and "The transwoman as model and co-creator: resistance and becoming in the back-turning Lili Elbe" / Tobias Raun in ''Gerda Wegener'' / edited by Andrea Rygg Karberg ... [et al.]. – Denmark, Arken Museum of Modern Art, 2015.

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox scientist |name = M. Shahid Qureshi |image =Prof_Dr_M_Shahid_Qureshi.jpg |image_size =200 |alt = |caption = |birth_date = |birth_place = [[Karachi]], Pakistan |death_date = |death_place = |residence = [[Karachi]], [[Sindh]], Pakistan |citizenship = [[Pakistan]] |nationality = Pakistani |fields = [[Astrophysics]] and [[Astronomy]] |workplaces = [[Institute of Space and Planetary Astrophysics]] (ISPA)
[[Karachi University]] (KU)
[[Institute of Business Administration, Karachi]] (IBA)
[[Pakistan Institute of Nuclear Science and Technology]] (PINSTECH) |alma_mater = [[University of Karachi]] (UoK) |doctoral_advisor = Dr. Nasiruddin Khan |academic_advisors = Dr. Khursheed Ather Siddiqui |doctoral_students = |notable_students = |known_for = His work on the [[astrophysics]], [[Supersymmetric quantum mechanics]] (SQM) and [[Applied mathematics]] |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = [[Abdus Salam]] |influenced_by = [[Abdus Salam]] |awards = |signature = |signature_alt = |footnotes = |ethnicity = }} Dr. [[Prof.]] '''Muhammad Shahid Qureshi''' or '''Shahid Qureshi''', styled as Dr. '''M. Shahid Qureshi''', is a Pakistani [[astrophysicist]] and a renowned [[astronomer]]. He is an academic and an eminent [[educationist]] from Pakistan who has published articles in the fields of [[astrophysics]] and [[astronomy]]. He is the [[Professor]] of astrophysics and astronomy at [[Karachi University]] and [[Institute of Space and Planetary Astrophysics]] (ISPA), and also leading ISPA, the country's prominent institution in the field of [[Planetary science|planetary astrophysics and planetary astronomy]]. He previously served as an [[Assistant Professor]] of mathematics. He is an avid supporter of science and technology in Pakistan and has helped directing documentaries concerning about the astrophysics and astronomy. He has also appeared in [[Geo TV|Geo Television]] and [[Dawn News]] frequently where he briefed the nation on [[Solar eclipse of 22 July 2009]]. ==Biography== He graduated and received a BSc with [[B.Sc. (Hons)|Honors]] in [[Applied Mathematics]] from Department of Mathematics of University of Karachi in 1979. He then received his MSc in Mathematics from the same institution with specialisation in [[Quantum mechanics]], and [[Astronomy]] in 1983. In between, he served [[United Bank Limited]], Karachi as a [[computer programmer]] to earn his living. In 1983, after getting his master's degree, he joined as a fellow the [[Pakistan Institute of Nuclear Science and Technology]], where he joined the "''Mathematical Physics Group''", and did preliminary research there. He left PINSTECH in 1984, and moved to Karachi, Sindh. He joined University of Karachi as a lecturer to fulfill his dream to become a professor of Mathematics. Under the supervision of noted quantum theorist and renowned [[particle physicist]] Dr. [[Khursheed Ather Siddiqui]], he did his MPhil in Particle physics from University of Karachi, writing a thesis and covered major area in the field of "[[Supersymmetric Quantum Mechanics]]". In 2002, he moved to the Institute of Space and Planetary Astrophysics on the directions of the then-[[Vice-Chancellor]] of University of Karachi, Dr. [[Zafar Saeed Saifi]]. Qureshi did his PhD. in [[astrophysics]] and [[Astronomy]] from ISPA in 2008. His doctoral thesis is on the "[[Astronomical seeing|Earliest Visibility of New Lunar Crescent]]". He has occasionally lectured in the field [[computational mathematics]] at [[Lahore University of Management Sciences]] (LUMS). He was serving at the [[Institute of Business Administration, Karachi]] (IBA) as the Chaiperson, Department of Mathematical Sciences of the Faculty of Computer Science, on deputation from University of Karachi and left from his position at IBA on completion of his deputation period in March 2016. At IBA he has not only established the department of Mathematical Sciences, he has also started the double major BS program in Mathematics and Economics, the first of its kind in Karachi. Moreover, he also played key role in developing the board of advanced studies and research at IBA that lead to formalise the graduate programs at IBA. In the mean time he also started MS and PhD programs in Mathematics at IBA. ===Institute of Space and Planetary Astrophysics=== Qureshi joined the teaching profession in 1984 at the University of Karachi. Later, he joined [[Institute of Business Administration, Karachi]]. For a brief period he also served the Department of Computer Science as a full-time Faculty member. Besides, he also taught as visiting faculty at various private sector Universities in Karachi including Institute of Business Administration. He is a well-known astrophysicist in Pakistan. And, he has given numerous interviews to the media, concerning the fields of [[physical cosmology]], [[astronomy]], and [[astrophysics]]. He played an important role in re-establishing the [[KU Observatory|Karachi University's Astronomical Observatory]]. As a noted [[space scientist]] at ISPA, he is engaged in research on [[Supersymmetric quantum mechanics]], [[lunar phase]], [[light pollution]] and [[solar energy]]. ===Influence and motivation=== At the Karachi University, he has maintain vital relationship with the professors from Karachi University. According to him, his professors played an important role in his life and influenced him to gain his doctorate in astronomy and astrophysics. According to an interview given to the Dawn News, it was one of his professors who influenced him to gain his doctorate degrees in astronomy. He laments, "In 1990, one of my professors said that very soon Pakistan will be asking the world to send us teachers to teach mathematics and physics as we ran out of them. Today I am forwarding his message: we do not have teachers to teach mathematics and physics". ===Higher education=== In 1983, he received his MSc in [[applied mathematics]] and M.Phil. in 1995 writing his thesis on [[Supersymmetric quantum mechanics]], from Karachi University.{{Cite web |last=Rahim |first=Rabia |title=A true visionary |url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/in-paper-magazine/education/a-true-visionary-579 |accessdate=5 July 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091205032743/http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/in-paper-magazine/education/a-true-visionary-579 |archivedate=5 December 2009 |df= }} In 2008, he was awarded his PhD. in Astrophysics and Astronomy, in which he wrote his thesis on "[[Astronomical seeing|the effects of atmospheric conditions on crescent visibility]], from the Karachi University. ==Advocacy for space research== He has been a vocal advocate for space research in Pakistan. Qureshi has been appeared in different Pakistani news channels and educational channels in which he has been advocating for space research in Pakistan. He has also been a core planner and organizer of several astronomical and astrophysics events at universities and high schools. With the help of Karachi University's Physics department, he planned a "Space Week" in ISPA on 31 October 2008. The event was called "Planet Watch" and a number of high school and college students were invited. He also delivered a lecture at the conference in which he urged: "You don’t need any equipment for astronomy. All you need is a pair of eyes and curiosity about the [[cosmos]]." He also briefly explained the origins of the seven-day week denomination: "According to initial cosmology, the ancients considered the [[planet]]s to be a total of seven: [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]], [[Venus]], [[Mars]], [[Jupiter]], [[Saturn]], the [[Sun]] and the [[Moon]] (also considered planets). Hence, the days of the week were also seven". He concluded the lecture with the nature of his involvement with the team at Institute of Space and Planetary Astrophysics, where he worked on [[astronomical object]]s, [[astrophysical plasma]], and [[physical cosmology]]. ==Research in astrophysics and particle physics== Qureshi's articles have been printed in international and national physics journals. He has been a known cited researcher in the field of computer programming while studying at Karachi University. He has been researching to the fields of astrophysics in relation with [[elementary particle physics]] and published numerous papers at ISPA. In relation to astrophysics to particle physics, he, once elaborate, while giving a lectured: "The well-known [[grand unification theory]] had two directions of research in the 1980s and '90s. The [[Supersymmetric theory]] appeared as one of the results. The empirical predictions of which, could not be tested till today, due to the absence of laboratories. We will be able to test some predictions of the supersymmetry theory when the [[Large Hadron Collider]] functions at its full capability. [[Particle physics]] and astrophysics, along wide with astronomy, has remained to explore the nature of forces in the first place and of course which is closely related to [[cosmology]], in which we describe the structure of the universe. So the other aspect of my research was astronomy and astrophysics." His work has been far reaching and influential. Due to lack to researches to the fields of astrophysics and astronomy; Qureshi's work has been a vital support to an academic research in astrophysics. At [[SUPARCO]], he also helped manufacturing and setting up the [[space observatory]] along with the Chinese scientists. ==Support for rocket science and Satellite Launch Vehicles (SLV)== He has been supporting the Satellite Launch Vehicle project program at SUPARCO. He has been also urged that Pakistan should launch its satellites via either [[Sonmiani]] or [[Tilla]]. In an interview while discussing Pakistan's status on [[Satellite Launch Vehicle]] with noted [[nuclear physicist]] Dr. [[Pervez Hoodbhoy]]. While in discussion, he urged that [[missile]]s have very roboost and effective [[electronics]] and computer system, the SLVs used the similar technology. Dr. M. Shahid Qureshi also urges that Pakistan has the basic technology to build an SLV.http://www.dawn.com/2008/10/20/local4.htm He discloses the discussion with Dr. Hoodbhoy and said "If we can launch a missile up to a range of 1,500 km, why not build an SLV that can launch [[Low Earth orbit|low-atmosphere satellites]]?" he said. According to Dr. M.S. Qureshi, "we can begin by [[remote sensing|launching navigation]], [[spy satellite|spy]] and [[weather satellite]]s, which can go up to 1,500 km into space. This alone can give us a lot of data that we need to buy now".{{Cite web | last = Reza | first = Sa'adia R | title = KARACHI: Pakistan risks losing orbital slot if satellite not launched | url=http://www.dawn.com/2008/10/20/local4.htm | accessdate = 20 October 2008 }} ==Research papers== *"Climatic Variability and Linear Trend Models for Major Cities of Pakistan", Journal of Geography and Geology, Canadian Center of Science and Education, Vol. 2, No. 1, 2010. *"A New Criterion of Earliest Visibility of New Lunar Crescent", Sindh Univ. Res. Jour. (Sci. Sec.), 42(1), 1–18, 2010. *"On Origin Theories of Ring Galaxies: Observational Data and Modelling”, Astronomy & Applied Mathematics, Vol. I, Ed. S Nuritdinov, Pub.: Fed. Concho Government Boarding School to age 13. Chilacco Government Boarding School, Jr. College in Weatherford, Oklahoma and [[Brigham Young University]] |spouse = |partner = |children =3 |parents =Harry Behan and Daisy Behan (nee Fletcher) |relations = |signature = |footnotes =mentioned in Father Powell's "Sweet Medicine" |battles = }}
'''Margaret Behan''' is a [[Native American in the United States|Native American]] woman who is Southern Arapaho-Cheyenne on her mother's side, and Northern Arapahoe/Northern Cheyenne on her father's side.<ref name = "ictmnjune2013"/> and a fourth generation descendant of a survivor of the [[Sand Creek Massacre]].<ref name="Harcourt-Smith">Harcourt-Smith</ref> Behan is a former member of the [[International Council of 13 Grandmothers]].
==Early years== Behan is "of the Kit Fox Clan of the [[Southern Cheyenne people|Cheyenne Nation of Oklahoma]] on her mother’s side, and on her father’s side she is half Northern Cheyenne and half [[Northern Arapahoe people|Arapahoe]] of the Rabbit Lodge."<ref name = "ictmnjune2013">{{Cite web | title =Wolf Connection to Join 13 Indigenous Grandmothers in Montana | accessdate =2013-06-16 | website =[[Indian Country Today Media Network]] | date =2012-07-24 | url =http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/article/wolf-connection-to-join-13-indigenous-grandmothers-in-montana-125303 }}</ref> She was one of eight children. Her parents were migrant farmworkers.<ref name = "missoulaindependent">{{Cite news | last = Mayrer | first = Jessica | title = Making amends among Montana's Northern Cheyenne | work = [[Missoula Independent]] | location = Missoula, MT | accessdate = 2013-06-19 | date = 2012-08-09 | url = http://missoulanews.bigskypress.com/missoula/apologies-accepted/Content?oid=1671977 }}</ref> Behan claims that she was prayed for and a [[Peyote]] ceremony was arranged before her conception.<ref>Schaefer (2006) p.35</ref>
==Family life== Behan had 3 children, 11 grandchildren, and one great grandchild.<ref>Schaefer (2006) p.36</ref>
==Work as an artist== Margaret's mother-in-law, noticed how well Margaret worked on a pair of beaded moccasins and suggested that she might want to work in clay. Margaret felt so confident in her new career as an artist that she resigned from her job in 1982 and took up her new artistic career full-time. Her work is mentioned in four Folk Art books.<ref name="Six Directions">Six Directions</ref> She later moved to [[Taos, New Mexico]] due to the properties of the clay there.<ref name="Six Directions"/>
==Addiction work== Margaret suffered from alcohol addiction as a young woman. She feels that she drank in order to 'fit in' with her friends. With the aid of addiction clinics, and more of her grandparent's ceremonies, Margaret was able to become free of her addiction.
As a result of this experience, Margaret trained to be a Licensed [[Substance abuse]] Counselor and with her traditional teachings, has led [[retreats]] for children and co-dependants of alcoholics<ref>Future Primitive</ref> to help other First Nation people that had found themselves in a similar position. Historical trauma commonly leads to alcohol, drug, and behaviour issues.<ref>Schaefer (2006) p.38</ref>
==The Cheyenne Elders Council== Margaret is the founder of "The Cheyenne Elders Council", formed in 2007-2008,<ref>NCCS</ref> with Behan as the sole member, and has the mission to, "Heal Our Own Oppression."<ref>Sacred Studies</ref> She had moved to the Northern Cheyenne Reservation, where her father was from, and "was troubled when she heard one of her people say that Cheyenne youth would have to save themselves," saying "They were not getting any kind of influence or teaching from the elders."<ref name = "missoulaindependent"/> "A project Behan and the Cheyenne Elders Council completed as part of the 11th council is the creation of the T’sistsistas’s Sacred School in Behan’s home. There, healers of the tribe will teach Cheyenne healing ways to the tribe’s youth."<ref name="Billings">{{cite news|last=Olp|first=Susan|title=Indigenous Grandmothers group comes to Lame Deer|url=http://billingsgazette.com/news/state-and-regional/montana/indigenous-grandmothers-group-comes-to-lame-deer/article_d77cb4e4-8508-5829-ae69-631e20f51c47.html|accessdate=3 June 2013|newspaper=[[Billings Gazette]] |date=July 29, 2012}}</ref> Behan says, "We need to bring our Cheyenne identity and pride back to the young people, teach them the traditional ceremonies and language."<ref>{{Cite news | title =Historic Horseback Ride Commemorating Cheyenne Exodus of 1878 Departs on June 1, 2012. | work =Indian Country Today Media Network | accessdate =2013-06-16 | date =2012-05-27 | url =http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/gallery/photo/historic-horseback-ride-commemorating-cheyenne-exodus-of-1878-departs-on-june-1-115100 }}</ref>
She was interviewed by [[AARP]] International Magazine in October, 2011.<ref>{{Cite news | title =An Interview with Grandmother Margaret Behan: Indigenous Grandmother's Lessons on Living Your Best Life | work =AARP International: News Makers | accessdate =2013-06-16 | date =2011-10-01 | url =http://www.aarpinternational.org/resource-library/resources/indigenous-grandmothers-lessons-on-living-your-best-life }}</ref>
In 2006, a chapter in the book "Grandmother's Council the World", features Behan and the [[Native American Church]], founded by her grandparents. This movement, (illegal at the time), allowed the combining of traditional ceremonies which then allowed the First Nation people's to stay connected to their traditional beliefs.
In 2012, Behan hosted "the 11th Gathering of the International Council of 13 Indigenous Grandmothers ... on the [[Northern Cheyenne Reservation]] July 26 to 29," at which the riders commemorating the [[Northern Cheyenne Exodus]] of 1878 shared stories of their journey.<ref name="Billings" /><ref>{{Cite news | title =Cheyenne Exodus Historic Horseback Journey Captured in Photographs }}</ref>"The Ride Home"<ref>{{ | url =http://theridehomemovie.com | work =Indian Country Today Media Network | accessdate =2013-06-16 | date =2012-07-28 | url =http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/gallery/photo/cheyenne-exodus-historic-horseback-journey-captured-in-photographs-125250 }}</ref> "The gathering ... [was] set up as a traditional Cheyenne encampment", with "thirteen teepees, one for each grandmother."<ref>{{Cite news | title = 11th International Council of Thirteen Indigenous Grandmothers July 26th-29th, 2012 Gratitude Brings Freedom In honor of Grandmother Margaret Behan | work = A Cheyenne Voice | location = [[Colstrip, Montana]] | accessdate = 2013-06-21 | date = 2012-07-31 | url = http://acheyennevoice.com/page/5/ }}</ref> In attendance was a great-great-great grandniece of [[George Armstrong Custer|General Custer]], who made a "formal apology to the Northern Cheyenne," and a great-great-granddaughter of Brig. Gen. [[Anson Mills]], who also offered an apology.<ref name = "missoulaindependent"/>
A two-part video of attendees from Vashon Intuitive Arts describing the event is available on the Internet Archive.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Asterino | first = Brenda | title = SHE-Grandmothers' Gathering part one (Montana Rally) | work = Internet Archive | accessdate = 2013-06-21 | url = https://archive.org/details/scm-201470-she-grandmothersgatheringpart }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | last = Asterino | first = Brenda | title = SHE-Grandmothers' Gathering part two (Montana Rally) | work = Internet Archive | accessdate = 2013-06-21 | url = https://archive.org/details/scm-206470-she-grandmothersgatheringpart }}</ref>

The '''Maska''' are a tribe of the [[Hazara people]], found in [[Afghanistan]] and neighboring countries.
Maska is a sub-tribe of [[Jaghori (Hazara tribe)|Jaghori]] tribe of Hazaras in Afghanistan. For long times ago Maska and Babah were twin brothers and according to the old myth they were separated by knife. In Afghanistan their ancestral place is [[Sange-e-Masha]] in [[Jaghori District]] of [[Ghazni Province]].<ref>Hassan Poladi. [https://books.google.com/books?id=1f8MAAAAIAAJ&q=maska+hazara&dq=maska+hazara&cd=1 The Hazāras]. Mughal Pub. Co., 1989. {{ISBN|0-929824-00-8}}, {{ISBN|978-0-929824-00-0}}.</ref>
