[[Image:RobertWCobb.jpg|right|Robert Watson Cobb]] '''Robert Watson Cobb''' is an [[Law of the United States|American lawyer]]. He worked for the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|George W. Bush administration]] before becoming [[NASA Office of Inspector General|NASA Inspector General]]. ==Early life and education== Cobb attended [[Vanderbilt University]], graduating in 1982 ''[[Latin honors|cum laude]]''. He graduated from [[George Washington University Law School|George Washington University's National Law Center]] in 1986 ''cum laude''. == Career ==
'''NASA Inspector General''' :Appointed: February 25, 2002 :Nomination sent to [[United States Senate|Senate]]: February 26, 2002 :[[Advice and consent|Confirmed]] by Senate: April 11, 2002
Cobb worked for five years as an associate at the [[law firm]] of Ober, Kaler, Grimes & Shriver. Cobb worked for almost nine years at the [[United States Office of Government Ethics]] before becoming [[White House Counsel|Associate Counsel to the President]] in the George W. Bush administration. In this position he was responsible for the administration of the [[Executive Office of the President of the United States|White House]] ethics program (the [[conflict of interest]] and [[financial disclosure]] clearance for candidates for nomination to [[Advice and consent|Senate-confirmed]] positions) under the supervision of then-[[White House Counsel]] [[Alberto Gonzales]]. [[President of the United States|President]] [[George W. Bush]] appointed Cobb to the position of NASA Inspector General on February 25, 2002. The nomination was sent to [[United States Senate|Senate]] February 26, 2002 and was confirmed on April 11, 2002. Cobb served as an "observer" to the [[Columbia Accident Investigation Board]], investigating the 2003 [[Space Shuttle Columbia disaster|Space Shuttle ''Columbia'' disaster]]. President Barack Obama took office in January, 2009. On April 2, 2009, Mr. Cobb offered his resignation to President Obama, effective April 11, 2009. Mr. Cobb is currently counsel to the Ethics Committee for Montgomery County, Maryland. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==Sources== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060212154245/http://www.hq.nasa.gov/office/oig/hq/inspector_general.html NASA biographical sketch] *[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/02/02/AR2006020202721.html NASA's Inspector General Probed]. [[Washington Post]], 2006-02-03, p A1. *[http://www.space.com/news/070405_griffin_nasaig.html NASA Chief Defends Embattled Inspector General]. [[Space.com]], 2007-04-05. *[https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/nominations/277.html Presidential nomination] {{DEFAULTSORT:Cobb, Robert Watson}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:NASA people]] [[Category:Maryland Republicans]]

{{EngvarB|date=March 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Rose McNamara | other_names = | image = Rose_McNamara.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Rose McNamara in Uniform | birth_name = Rose McNamara | birth_date = 10 September 1885 | birth_place = [[Dublin]], Ireland | death_date = 6 March 1957 | death_place = [[Dublin]], Ireland | nationality = Irish }} '''Rose McNamara''' (10 September 1885 – 6 March 1957) was an Irish nationalist, [[Irish republicanism|republican]], and Vice Commandant during the [[Easter Rising]] of 1916.
==Early life== Rose Anne McNamara was born to Benjamin McNamara, a van driver, and Johanna Mangan, at 8 [[Great Denmark Street|Denmark Street]], [[Dublin]], on 10 September 1885.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://civilrecords.irishgenealogy.ie/churchrecords/details-civil/cc94551151859|title=General Registrar's Office|last=|first=|date=|website=IrishGenealogy.ie|publisher=|access-date=10 September 2017}}</ref> Her father died in 1898. Rose was just 15.<ref name="CSO">{{cite web|url=http://cso.ie/en/releasesandpublications/ep/p-1916/1916irl/cpr/cwr/rmcn/|title=Rose McNamara (1885-1957)|publisher=Central Statistics Office}}</ref>
[[Marie Perolz]] introduced McNamara to [[Inghinidhe na hÉireann]] around 1906. Perolz's sister Delia was her sister in law. Delia was married to Matthew McNamara. McNamara joined [[Sinn Féin]] and became a member of [[Cumann na mBan]] when that formed out of the Inghinidhe na hÉireann. With them she marched in public parades, conducted demonstrations, learned to make field dressings and collected money for ammunition and equipment for the [[Irish Volunteers]].<ref name="CSO"/><ref name="Statement">{{cite web|url=http://www.bureauofmilitaryhistory.ie/reels/bmh/BMH.WS0482.pdf|title=Witness statement for Rose McNamara|publisher=Bureau of Military History}}</ref>
==Revolution== On Good Friday 1916, in preparation for the [[Easter Rising]] McNamara and others of the Cumann made field dressings. On the Monday her branch from Cumann na mBan were matched in full uniform to Emerald Square where they were given their instructions from [[Eamonn Ceannt]]. Rose served as Vice Commandant of the group who served in the [[Marrowbone Lane]] garrison, which was based in [[Marrowbone Lane Distillery|Jameson's Distillery]].<ref name="CSO"/><ref name="Her">{{cite web|url=http://www.her.ie/life/easter-rising-five-women-you-may-not-know-served-in-the-rebellion/28873|title=Five women you may not know}}</ref><ref name ="Times">{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/the-forgotten-role-of-women-insurgents-in-the-1916-rising-1.1030426|title=The forgotten role of women insurgents in the 1916 Rising}}</ref><ref name="Pašeta2013">{{cite book|author=Senia Pašeta|title=Irish Nationalist Women, 1900-1918|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PRPrAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA189|date=5 December 2013|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-107-04774-7}}</ref><ref name="details">{{cite web|url=http://www.irishcatholic.ie/article/devil-detail|title=The devil is in the detail|author=Greg Daly}}</ref>
She spent the Rising with a number of roles, working as quartermaster for the men, acting as a spotter for the snipers and ensuring nursing facilities for the wounded. On Sunday, April 30 they were told of the surrender. McNamara, refused the opportunity to leave as part of the women who were considered less important to the British accepting the surrender and she and the rest of the Cumann na mBan marched between the male Volunteers and were duly arrested and imprisoned.<ref name="CSO"/><ref name="Her"/><ref name ="Times"/><ref name="Pašeta2013"/><ref name="details"/>
''“On the route to Richmond Barracks we were right behind Commandant [[Thomas McDonagh]] and [[John MacBride|Major McBride]]. When we reached somewhere about Kilmainham, both Major McBride and T. McDonagh said: "That's right, girls, sing away" and Major McBride said to me: "Sing away, girls. You'll be alright. You'll be out tomorrow", and I replied "and what about you" meaning all the men. He said, very sadly, "Ah no. We won't be out. We'll be shot".''
While they were in prison in [[Kilmainham Gaol]] they could hear the men being executed by firing squad as McBride had predicted.<ref name="CSO"/>
In the aftermath the members of the Cumann were disheartened but collected funds for the prisoner's dependents. In 1917 McNamarra was First Lieutenant of her branch. Military drills and training began again. In 1918 the branch, including McNamara were involved in the anti-conscription activities.<ref name="Statement"/>
During the Irish War of Independence McNamara worked with the other women in collecting funds, attending funerals and other parades and in protesting at the gaols where prisoners were on hunger-strike. in 1919 McNamara became Captain of her Cumann na mBan branch. Her role was to ensure nursing cover at first aid stations during planned ambushes. She was notified in advance to make sure the house was ready to receive any wounded men. Commandant Joe O'Connor and Seán Guilfoyle were working with her on these.<ref name="Statement"/>
In the [[Irish Civil War]] she served under [[Countess Markievicz]].<ref name="CSO"/><ref name="Her"/> She attended the events at the Four Courts where the Pro and Anti Treaty sides clashed. McNamara was on the Anti-Treaty side. She procured refreshements for the men and carried messages for them. The following day she was given orders to serve at the United Services Club. Fighting continued in the city over night.<ref name="Statement"/>
Rose McNamara died 6 March 1957.<ref name="CSO"/>

Lost with all hands. | Ship status =Wreck | Ship notes =Position unknown }} {{Infobox ship characteristics | Hide header = | Header caption =''Ben Seyr'' | Ship type = Coastal Cargo Vessel | Ship tonnage = {{GRT|260|disp=long}} | Ship displacement = | Ship length = {{convert|126|ft|m|1|abbr=on}} | Ship beam = {{convert|22|ft|m|1|abbr=on}} | Ship draught = | Ship depth = {{convert|10|ft|m|1|abbr=on}} | Ship decks = | Ship deck clearance = | Ship ramps = | Ship power = | Ship propulsion = Marine compound reciprocating engine. | Ship speed = {{convert|9.5|kn|lk=in}} | Ship capacity = 265 tons of cargo | Ship crew =6 | Ship notes = }} |}
'''SS ''Ben Seyr''''' was a steel-built coastal cargo vessel which was operated out of [[Ramsey, Isle of Man]] for the Ramsey Steamship Company; ostensibly to [[Port of Liverpool|Liverpool]], [[Belfast Harbour|Belfast]] and [[Whitehaven]].<ref name="ReferenceA">''The Ramsey Courier.'' Friday 28 May 1920.</ref> Her name, Ben Seyr, came from the [[Manx language|Manx Gaelic term]] for ''gentlewoman.''<ref name="ReferenceA"/> She was lost in a storm in either the northern part of the [[Celtic Sea]], or the southern part of the [[Irish Sea]], in October 1938, going down with the loss of all hands.
==Construction and dimensions== ''Ben Seyr'' was constructed by the Manchester Dry Docks Company at [[Ellesmere Port]] and was completed in 1920.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Length {{convert|126|ft|m|1|abbr=on}}, beam {{convert|22|ft|m|1|abbr=on}}, depth {{convert|10|ft|m|1|abbr=on}}.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> ''Ben Seyr's'' cargo hold was divided into fore and aft hatches with a combined space of 12,400 cubic feet and which could accommodate 265 tons of cargo.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> She was driven by a marine compound reciprocating engine with her boiler manufactured by [[Cammell Laird|Cammell Laird's]]. The high-pressure cylinder was 15 inches in [[diameter]], the low-pressure cylinder 32 inches with a 21-inch stroke.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> ''Ben Seyr'' was fitted with a patented steam-powered steering gear designed by Fisher's of [[Paisley, Renfrewshire|Paisley]],<ref name="ReferenceA"/> which could be detached if necessary. She had bunker capacity for 40 [[ton]]s of coal with her bunkers designed to accommodate 20 tons on the [[Port and starboard|port side]] and the other 20 [[ton]]s on the [[Port and starboard|starboard]] side.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> She carried 20 tons of water ballast aft and 12 tons forward and had a tank installed which contained 300 [[imperial gallon|gallons]] of drinking water.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
For a vessel of her size, her engine room was said to be exceptionally large and airy and all accessories were said to be conveniently placed.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The quarters of the seamen and firemen were situated forward, underneath the [[Forecastle|forecastle head]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Below the [[Bridge (nautical)|wheel house]] was the accommodation for the [[Sea captain|Captain]] and [[First mate]] with the [[Chief engineer]]'s quarters situated at the after end of the ship. The fittings were made of oak and she was furnished with spring beds.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> ''Ben Seyr'' was fitted with a steam-powered [[windlass]] and in addition a steam winch for loading and unloading of cargo.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==Service life== ''Ben Seyr'' underwent her Sea Trials in early May 1920 during the course of which she covered a measured mile off [[Formby]] at a speed of {{convert|9.5|kn|lk=in}}.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> ''Ben Seyr'' entered service under the command of [[Sea captain|Captain]] E. Jones, who prior to this had served on the ''Ben Varrey''.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> On her maiden voyage she made passage from the Bar Lightship to [[Maughold Head]] in a time of 6.5 hours.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> On joining the Ramsey Steamship Company fleet she was the largest vessel within the fleet and brought the total number to five.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
''Ben Seyr'' conveyed numerous types of cargo, with the mainstays being coal, grain and timber.
==Incidents== With Captain Corlett in command, the ''Ben Seyr'' was approaching Ramsey Harbour on Friday, February 7, 1936, in challenging conditions. A southeasterly gale had developed making berthing in the port particularly difficult and leading to one of the ''Ben Seyr's'' ropes snapping following which she began to drift onto the Mooragh bank. Capt. Corlett displayed fine seamanship in raging control of the vessel and averting her grounding.<ref>''Isle of Man Examiner.'' Friday, February 14, 1936; Page: 6</ref>
In August 1937, one of the crew of the ''Ben Seyr'' was drowned in [[Maryport|Maryport Harbour]] following an accident.<ref name="ReferenceB">''The Ramsey Courier.'' Friday 14 October 1938.</ref> [[Able seaman|Able Seaman]] Charles Kneale was 23 years old and came from [[Ramsey, Isle of Man]].<ref name="ReferenceB"/> He was in a small boat sculling across the harbour together with another crew member [[Able seaman|Able Seaman]] Cecil Barber near to where the ''Ben Seyr'' was docked. In testimony Barber said that as they approached the dock gates Kneale fell into the water and although Barber did all he could to save him, he subsequently drowned.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> An inquest into Kneale's death was held later that night on board the ''Ben Seyr'' in order to allow the vessel to sail on the night tide.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> The ''Ben Seyr'' conveyed the body of Able Seaman Kneale back to Ramsey.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
==Loss== ''Ben Seyr'' departed [[Ramsey, Isle of Man|Ramsey]] on Sunday, 2 October 1938 under [[Sea captain|Captain]] Ambrose Crebbin, bound for [[Cardiff]] with a cargo of oats. During the course of the passage, she encountered heavy seas and was forced to run towards the Irish Coast in order to seek shelter, with word being received by her owners on the morning of Wednesday 5, that she had arrived off [[Rosslare Harbour|Rosslare]], [[County Wexford]]. The [[Station Master]] at [[Rosslare Harbour|Rosslare]] reported that the ''Ben Seyr'' had departed at [[24-hour clock#Midnight 00:00 and 24:00|14:00hrs]] later that day resuming passage to Cardiff,<ref>''The Ramsey Courier''. Friday 14 October 1938</ref> after which nothing more was seen or heard from her. ''Ben Seyr'' was not equipped with a [[Wireless#Radio|wireless]] and therefore no information was received regarding her position or the weather which she was encountering.
By the following Tuesday, 11 October, with still no news of the ''Ben Seyr,'' the following radio appeal was made on the [[BBC National Programme]] as well as on [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]].
{{Quotation|''"There has been no news for nearly a week of the British steamer Ben Syer which left Rosslare for Cardiff on Wednesday last. Anybody or any ship hearing of the Ben Seyr or being in touch with the vessel, is asked to communicate with Lloyds, London."''|''BBC National Programme news bulletin.'' Tuesday 11 October 1938.}}
When Wednesday came with still no news of the ''Ben Seyr'' hope began to fade. It seemed highly improbable that she could still be sheltering, for her crew had with them food for approximately five days and her coal bunkers would have been running out.
On Thursday 13 October the body of Seaman James Bradford was washed ashore on Middleton Sands, near [[Heysham Harbour]] on the [[Lancashire|Lancashire Coast.]]<ref name="ReferenceC">''Isle of Man Examiner.'' Friday 14 October 1938</ref> His body was found fully clothed and in a standard type [[Personal flotation device#Life jacket|life jacket]]. Within his coat was found a badge of the Isle of Man Branch of the [[Transport and General Workers' Union]] to which he belonged. He was formerly identified by his by his father,<ref>''Green Final.'' Saturday 15 October 1938</ref> and an inquest was held into his death at [[Heysham]] on Saturday 15 October.<ref>''Green Final.'' Saturday 15 October 1938</ref> James Bradford's body was returned to the Isle of Man on board the steamer [[Mona's Isle (1905)|''Mona's Isle]]. Following his funeral which was reported to have been very well attended, his body was buried at Maughold Churchyard.<ref>''Green Final.'' Saturday 15 October 1938</ref>
A relief fund for the dependents of the crew was set up on 18 October 1938. The fund raised a total of £1,387 (equivalent to £{{formatnum:{{Inflation|UK|1387|1939|{{Inflation-year|UK}}|r=0}}}} in {{Inflation-year|UK}}){{Inflation-fn|UK|df=y}} added to which was the sum of £400 (equivalent to £{{formatnum:{{Inflation|UK|400|1939|{{Inflation-year|UK}}|r=0}}}} in {{Inflation-year|UK}}){{Inflation-fn|UK|df=y}} from the Ramsey Steamship Company. During the years following, payments were made to the dependents at [[Christmas]] (£30) with financial aid also being given for medical and educational purposes. The relief fund continued to pay those dependents until 1955, when with the children of the dependents having grown into adulthood it was decided that the Ben Seyr Relief Fund should be wound up. A meeting was called by the Trustees at the Town Hall, Ramsey, on Monday 17 January 1955, for the purpose of passing a resolution for the winding up of the fund and distributing the balance amongst the last five dependents.<ref>''Isle of Man Examiner''. Friday 7 January 1955.</ref>
==Theories on sinking== How the ''Ben Seyr'' met her fate is a matter of conjecture. Having been seen at [[Rosslare Harbour|Rosslare]], it may be presumed that having sailed for [[Cardiff]] on Wednesday afternoon she soon encountered heavy seas. Her cargo of loose oats may have ran forward in the hold, the weight putting her nose under the water, in which case she could have sunk in a matter of minutes. Conversely, she may have attempted to turn back and run for the shelter of the Irish Coast during the course of which she was swamped by the heavy seas - again her sinking would have followed quickly.
The fact that the body of Seaman James Bradford was washed ashore on the northern part of the Lancashire Coast, could also support a theory that after leaving Rosslare the ''Ben Seyr'' [[Heaving to#Heaving to as a storm tactic|"''ran before the storm''"]] in an attempt to return to the [[Isle of Man]]. Local nautical theory at the time suggested this as a possibility, with the ''Ben Seyr'' subsequently [[Shipwrecking#Instability and foundering|foundering]] to the south of the [[Isle of Man]]. Also with the fact that Bradford's body was found in a [[Personal flotation device#Life jacket|life jacket]], it could suggest that the crew abandoned ship, however no other crew members bodies were found.
Several days after she had left [[Rosslare Harbour|Rosslare]] rumours began to circulate that one of the ''Ben Seyr's'' [[Lifeboat (shipboard)|lifeboats]] had been recovered on the Irish Coast. However, it turned out to be a [[Lifeboat (shipboard)|lifeboat]] belonging to the ''SS Donaghmnore'' of [[Belfast]], which had gone to the rescue of the ''SS Marjorie'' which was lost in the same storm off [[Dundrum, County Down|St. John's Point]], Ireland. Wreckage of the ''Marjorie'' was also washed up on the western coast of the Isle of Man.<ref>''Isle of Man Examiner.'' Friday 28 October 1938.</ref>
In August 1939, it was announced by the [[Board of Trade]] that after careful consideration of all the facts surrounding the loss of the ''Ben Seyr'' that it had been decided that there were no public grounds for the carrying out of a formal investigation into the case.<ref>''Isle of Man Examiner.'' Friday 18 August 1939.</ref>
==Victims==
A Memorial Service was held at St. Paul's Church [[Ramsey, Isle of Man|Ramsey]] on Saturday 15 October 1938, conducted by the Rev. M. W. Harrison, vicar of St. Paul's and assisted by the Rev. E.C. Paton who read the lesson.
===Crew=== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- !Name!!Position!!Address |- style="background:#9bddff;" |Crebbin, Ambrose William||[[Sea captain|Captain]].|| Darragh Road, [[Port Erin, Isle of Man]]. |- style="background:#9bddff;" |Morrison, William||[[Chief engineer|Chief Engineer]].|| Pulrose Park, [[Douglas, Isle of Man]]. |-style="background:#9bddff;" |Lace, David||[[Able Seaman]].|| Upper Queen's Pier Road, [[Ramsey, Isle of Man]]. |- style="background:#9bddff;" |Thomas, Jerry||[[Seaman]].|| Church Street, [[Ramsey, Isle of Man]]. |- style="background:#9bddff;" |Bradford, James||[[Seaman]].|| Church Street, [[Ramsey, Isle of Man]]. |- style="background:#9bddff;" |Barbour, Cecil||[[Seaman]].|| Page Moss Lane, Dovecot, [[Liverpool]]. |- style="background:#9bddff;" |} <ref name="ReferenceC"/>
==Trivia== In early March 1939, a message in a bottle was washed up on the shore at [[Silecroft]], [[Cumberland|southern Cumberland]] on which was written: {{Quotation|''"Ben Seyr. Foundering with fore hatches battered in. Heavy seas. 22 miles S.S.W. Maughull Head."''}}<ref>''Green Final'' Saturday 11 March 1939</ref> The message was regarded with some reserve. There was only one set of hatches on the ''Ben Seyr'' and if the word ''"Maughull"'' was supposed to mean [[Maughold]], then it is highly unlikely that it would have been mis-spelt by any member of the crew in the manner indicated. Also the position indicated in the message would have put the vessel somewhere between [[Langness]] and the [[Chicken Rock]].

{{pp-blp|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Other people|Scott Walker}} {{short description|45th Governor of Wisconsin}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Scott Walker |image = Scott Walker by Gage Skidmore 4.jpg |order = 45th [[Governor of Wisconsin]] |lieutenant = [[Rebecca Kleefisch]] |term_start = January 3, 2011 |term_end = <!-- January 2019 --> |predecessor = [[Jim Doyle]] |successor = [[Tony Evers]] (Elect) |office1 = 5th [[List of Milwaukee County executives|Executive of Milwaukee County]] |term_start1 = April 30, 2002 |term_end1 = December 27, 2010 |predecessor1 = [[Janine P. Geske]] (Acting) |successor1 = [[Lee Holloway]] (Acting) |state_assembly2 = Wisconsin |district2 = 14th |term_start2 = June 30, 1993 |term_end2 = April 30, 2002 |predecessor2 = [[Peggy Rosenzweig]] |successor2 = [[Leah Vukmir]] |birth_name = Scott Kevin Walker |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1967|11|2}} |birth_place = {{nowrap|[[Colorado Springs, Colorado]], U.S.}} |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = {{marriage|[[Tonette Walker|Tonette Tarantino]]|1993}} |children = 2 |residence = [[Wisconsin Governor's Mansion|Governor's Mansion]] |signature = Scott-walker-signature.png |website = {{url|scottwalker.com|Official website}} }} '''Scott Kevin Walker''' (born November 2, 1967) is an American politician serving as the [[List of Governors of Wisconsin|45th]] and current [[governor of Wisconsin]] since 2011. A [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], he was first elected governor in [[Wisconsin gubernatorial election, 2010|2010]], then won in an attempted recall election in [[Wisconsin gubernatorial recall election, 2012|2012]], and was elected a third time in [[Wisconsin gubernatorial election, 2014|2014]], before being defeated in [[Wisconsin gubernatorial election, 2018|2018]]. He formerly served as [[Milwaukee County Executive]] and in the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]].
Born in [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]], Walker was raised in [[Iowa]] and in [[Delavan, Wisconsin]], before attending [[Marquette University]]. He left Marquette before graduating, taking a full-time job with the [[American Red Cross]]. Walker was elected to the Wisconsin State Assembly in 1992, representing a district in western [[Milwaukee County]]. In 2002, Walker was elected County Executive in a special election following the resignation of [[F. Thomas Ament]]; he was elected for a full term in 2004 and was re-elected in 2008.
Walker campaigned for Governor of Wisconsin in [[Wisconsin gubernatorial election, 2006|2006]] and ran again in [[Wisconsin gubernatorial election, 2010|2010]]. Shortly after his inauguration in 2011, Walker introduced a [[Wisconsin Budget Repair Bill|budget plan]] which limited the [[collective bargaining]] of most Wisconsin public employees. The response to Walker's policies included [[2011 Wisconsin protests|protests]] at the [[Wisconsin State Capitol]] and an effort to recall Walker. In the [[Wisconsin gubernatorial recall election|2012 recall election]], Walker again defeated Barrett, becoming the first governor in the United States to survive a recall effort.
In 2014, Walker defeated his Democratic challenger, businesswoman and [[Madison, Wisconsin|Madison]] School Board member [[Mary Burke]]. Walker [[Scott Walker presidential campaign, 2016|was briefly a candidate]] for his party's [[Republican Party presidential primaries, 2016|presidential nomination]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 election]]. Walker sought a third term as governor in [[Wisconsin gubernatorial election, 2018|2018]] but was defeated by [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] challenger [[Tony Evers]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Democrat Tony Evers wins election for governor in Wisconsin.|url=https://twitter.com/AP_Politics/status/1060070757550702594|publisher=AP|accessdate=2018-11-07}}</ref>
==Early life, education, and career== Walker was born on November 2, 1967, in [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]], the elder of two sons of Patricia Ann "Pat" (née Fitch; born December 30, 1938), a bookkeeper, and Llewellyn Scott "Llew" Walker (May 19, 1939 – October 7, 2018), a [[Baptists|Baptist]] minister.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/2018/10/07/llewellyn-scott-walker-dies-during-sons-re-election-campaign/1558113002/|title = Llewellyn Scott Walker, father of Gov. Scott Walker, dies|last = Richard|first = Erin|website = [[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]|date = October 7, 2018|accessdate = October 20, 2018}}</ref>
The family moved to [[Plainfield, Iowa]], in 1970, where Llew worked as pastor in the local Baptist Church, TBC, and served on the municipal council.<ref>Jason Stein (January 31, 2015) [http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/walker-learned-early-lessons-at-fathers-iowa-church-b99435429z1-290442461.html "Scott Walker learned early lessons at father's Iowa church"], ''[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]''; accessed September 24, 2016.</ref> When Walker was ten years old, the family moved to [[Delavan, Wisconsin]], where his father continued to work as a minister, at the First Baptist Church of Delavan.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gonyea|first1=Dan|title=Now On The National Stage, Scott Walker Is Still A Guy From Delavan|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/itsallpolitics/2015/07/17/423809006/now-on-the-national-stage-scott-walker-is-still-a-guy-from-delavan|accessdate=April 28, 2018|work=All Things Considered|publisher=National Public Radio|date=July 17, 2015}}</ref> In 1985, when Walker was in high school, he attended and represented Wisconsin at two weeks of [[American Legion]]-sponsored training in leadership and government at [[Badger Boys State]] in Wisconsin and the selective [[Boys Nation]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref name="notable bbs graduates"/><ref name="who is"/> While at the event, he met [[President of the United States|U.S. president]] [[Ronald Reagan]]<ref name="preacher's kid"/><ref name="Biography.com">{{cite web | title=Scott Walker Biography | url=http://www.biography.com/people/scott-walker-20941829#synopsis | publisher=''Biography.com'' | accessdate=November 24, 2016}}</ref> and had a photo taken with him.<ref>{{cite web | last1=Viser | first1=Matt | title=Scott Walker’s Political Ambitions Fostered at Marquette | url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/politics/2015/02/11/scott-walker-dropped-out-marquette-but-his-education-campus-politics-set-him-ambitious-path/m41BjqIY9xAltlCgR6z5CM/story.html | date=February 11, 2015 | publisher=''[[The Boston Globe]]'' | accessdate=November 25, 2016}}</ref> Walker has credited the experience with solidifying his interest in public service and giving him the "political bug".<ref name="boys nation alum"/> He attained the highest rank, [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout]], in the [[Boy Scouts of America]],<ref name="preacher's kid"/><ref name="battleground"/> and graduated from Delavan-Darien High School in 1986.<ref name="close to home"/>
=== College=== In 1986, Walker worked as a volunteer for [[Tommy Thompson]]'s gubernatorial campaign, and in the fall of that year, enrolled at [[Marquette University]].<ref name="alumni"/> Within a few weeks of beginning studies, Walker became a student senator and a few weeks later led a probe involving student government leaders misusing funds during homecoming.<ref name=Politifact.college/> Walker's committee recommended impeachment of those being investigated, leading many to resign, and earning Walker enemies, a number of whom, according to [[Politifact]], "continue to taunt him today".<ref name=Politifact.college>{{cite web|last1=Umhoefer|first1=Dave|title=Solving the "mystery" of Scott Walker's college years and entry into politics|url=http://www.politifact.com/wisconsin/article/2013/dec/18/scott-walker-early-years|publisher=Politifact|accessdate=May 19, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150519181456/http://www.politifact.com/wisconsin/article/2013/dec/18/scott-walker-early-years|archivedate=May 19, 2015|date=December 18, 2013}}</ref>
In 1988, he ran for student government president, touting a 19-point resume.<ref name=Politifact.college/> On election day, a record number of students voted and Walker lost 927 to 1,245, following an alleged infringement of campaign guidelines; an election commission later found Walker guilty of beginning his campaign one week before he was allowed.<ref name=Politifact.college/> His opponent was impeached shortly after taking office but Walker did not apply for the position.<ref name=Politifact.college/> While at Marquette, Walker led the [[pro-life]] [[Students for Life of America|Students for Life]] group at the university.<ref name="Remarkably">{{cite web | last1=Ben-Meir | first1=Ilan | title=Scott Walker’s Remarkably Consistent, Two Decade Fight Against Abortion | url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/ilanbenmeir/scott-walkers-remarkably-consistent-two-decade-fight-against | date=August 25, 2015 | publisher=[[BuzzFeed]] | accessdate=November 24, 2016}}</ref>
In spring 1990, Walker discontinued his studies at Marquette, earning 94 of the 128 minimum credits needed to graduate.<ref name="politifact.com">{{Cite web|title=Solving the "mystery" of Scott Walker's college years and entry into politics|url=http://www.politifact.com/wisconsin/article/2013/dec/18/scott-walker-early-years|accessdate=July 29, 2015}}</ref> He left in good standing with a 2.59<ref name="politifact.com"/><ref name=Globe02112015>{{cite news|last1=Viser|first1=Matt|title=Scott Walker's political ambitions fostered at Marquette|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/politics/2015/02/11/scott-walker-dropped-out-marquette-but-his-education-campus-politics-set-him-ambitious-path/m41BjqIY9xAltlCgR6z5CM/story.html|accessdate=July 29, 2015|publisher=Boston Globe Media Partners LLC|date=February 11, 2015}}</ref>/4.0 [[GPA|grade point average]] but without obtaining a degree. Walker has said he dropped out of college when he received an offer for a full-time job with the [[American Red Cross]]; he had worked part-time in college for [[IBM]] selling warranties on mainframe computers, which led to the American Red Cross position.<ref name=Politifact.college/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Zeke J.|title=Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker: A 2016 Contender But Not A College Graduate|url=http://swampland.time.com/2013/11/19/wisconsin-gov-scott-walker-a-2016-contender-but-not-a-college-graduate|accessdate=May 1, 2015|publisher=TIME|date=November 19, 2013}}</ref><ref name="unseal">{{cite web|title=Scott Walker says he unsealed his records from college: False|url=http://www.politifact.com/wisconsin/statements/2015/mar/12/scott-walker/where-are-scott-walkers-student-records|website=politicfact|accessdate=March 16, 2015}}</ref>
==Wisconsin State Assembly== In 1990, at age 22, Walker ran for Milwaukee's 7th District seat in the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]]. He won the Republican nomination, but lost in the general election to incumbent Democrat [[Gwen Moore]], receiving less than one-third of the vote.<ref name="1990 election"/><ref name="politics calling"/> In 1993, Walker moved to [[Wauwatosa, Wisconsin|Wauwatosa]], a suburb of Milwaukee, and ran in a [[special election]] in the more conservative 14th legislative district, based around Wauwatosa. He defeated Democrat Chris Ament, son of then-Milwaukee County Executive [[Tom Ament]].<ref name="AP guide"/><ref name="drawn to politics"/>
During the campaign, Walker backed [[Welfare to work#1980s and 1990s|welfare reform]] and opposed the expansion of [[Public transport|mass transit]]. He supported a cap on state spending and said that the law on resolving labor disputes with local government employees needed to be reformed.<ref name="assembly foes"/> Walker received the endorsements of Wisconsin Right to Life and ''[[The Milwaukee Sentinel]]'', which called him a [[fiscal conservatism|fiscal conservative]] and noted his [[pro-life]], tough-on-crime, and pro-welfare reform positions.<ref name="sentinel choice"/> He was re-elected four times, serving until 2002 when he became a county executive.<ref name="AP guide"/>
While in the state assembly, he was interested in criminal justice matters<ref name="AP guide"/> and chaired the Committees on Correctional Facilities, and Corrections and the Courts. Over the years, he served on a number of other committees, including Health, Census and Redistricting, Financial Institutions, and Housing.<ref name="historical society"/> As a freshman legislator in 1993, he co-sponsored [[right-to-work law|right-to-work legislation]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Leading from Behind: How Years of Denials Got Scott Walker In Position to Approve Right-to-Work|first=David|last=Weigel|date=February 23, 2015|accessdate=May 15, 2015|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2015-02-23/leading-from-behind-how-years-of-denials-got-scott-walker-in-position-to-approve-right-to-work|publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker Backs Anti-Union Bill In State Senate: State Inches Toward Right-To-Work|first=Cole|last=Stangler|date=February 23, 2015|accessdate=May 15, 2015|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/wisconsin-governor-scott-walker-backs-anti-union-bill-state-senate-state-inches-1825122}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Walker: Lawmakers Should Wait Until Budget's Passage Before Acting On Right-To-Work|date=December 5, 2014|first=Shawn|last=Johnson|accessdate=May 15, 2015|publisher=[[Wisconsin Public Radio]]|url=http://www.wpr.org/walker-lawmakers-should-wait-until-budgets-passage-acting-right-work}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Scott Walker keeps changing his mind|first=Leslie|last=Larson|date=March 11, 2015|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/scott-walker-keeps-changing-his-mind-2015-3|accessdate=May 15, 2015|publisher=[[Business Insider]]}}</ref> In 1999 he took the lead in a [[truth-in-sentencing]] bill that increased prison time for some crimes, eliminated parole for others, and subsequently contributed to [[prison overcrowding]].<ref name="Keyes"/> Walker was a member of the [[American Legislative Exchange Council]] (ALEC) at the time, and credited the organization for much of the success of the legislation.<ref name="Keyes">Keyes, Scott. [http://www.thenation.com/article/199369/how-scott-walker-built-career-sending-wisconsin-inmates-private-prisons# "How Scott Walker Built a Career Sending Wisconsin Inmates to Private Prisons"], thenation.com, February 26, 2015; retrieved February 27, 2015.</ref>
In 2001, he was the lead sponsor of a bill to prevent pharmacists from being disciplined for refusing to fill prescriptions for [[emergency contraception]]<ref name="abortion, birth control"/> and was a strong supporter of a bill to require voters to show photo ID at the polls.<ref name="AP guide"/> According to research by two political analysts, Walker was more conservative than about 90% of his peers in the assembly and about 80% of the Republicans in the assembly.<ref>{{cite news|title=Scott Walker's legislative years: A staunch conservative, then as now|first=Craig|last=Gilbert|date=February 28, 2015|accessdate=May 15, 2015|url=http://www.jsonline.com/blogs/news/294519901.html|newspaper=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]}}</ref>
Walker had a strong pro-life record in the state assembly. With the exception of some bills while Walker was running for Milwaukee County Executive, Walker either sponsored or cosponsored all but three bills that would have restricted abortions.<ref name="Remarkably"/>
In 2001–02, Walker and fellow state assembly member [[Michael Huebsch]] [[Jamyi Witch hiring controversy|objected to the hiring]] of a state employee, Rev. Jamyi Witch, on the basis of her religious beliefs as a [[Wiccan]].<ref name="AU2002">[https://web.archive.org/web/20090512184102/http://www.au.org/media/church-and-state/archives/2002/02/aub.html "Wiccan prison chaplain sparks controversy in Wisconsin"], ''Americans United Bulletin'', February 2002; accessed November 8, 2014.</ref><ref name="SeattleTimes2002">Toosi, Nahal. [http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20011209&slug=witch09 "Wiccan Rev. Witch raises some brows at Wisconsin prison"], ''Milwaukee Journal Sentinel'' reprinted December 9, 2001 in ''Seattle Times''.</ref> Walker claimed that Witch's hiring as a prison [[Prison chaplain|chaplain]] raised "both personal and political concerns" because she "practice[d] a religion that actually offends people of many other faiths". Walker and Huebsch were ultimately unsuccessful in terminating Witch's chaplaincy or employment.<ref name="AU2002"/>
==Milwaukee County Executive== [[File:Milwaukee County Executive Scott Walker in 2009.jpg|thumb|Scott Walker in 2009]] Walker became [[Milwaukee County, Wisconsin|Milwaukee County]] [[county executive|Executive]] in a [[special election]] run in April 2002, after the former County Executive, [[Tom Ament]], resigned in the wake of a county pension fund scandal.<ref name="AP guide"/><ref name="announcement expected"/> Walker was elected to a four-year term in 2004, winning 57% of the vote to defeat former state budget director, David Riemer.<ref name="2004 race"/><ref name="2004 election results"/> Although in a liberal county and running for a nonpartisan position, Walker ran openly as a conservative Republican.<ref name="preacher's kid"/> He won another four-year term in 2008, defeating State Senator [[Lena Taylor]] with 59% of the vote.<ref name="2008 election results"/> Upon first being elected, Walker became the youngest person and the first Republican ever elected to the position<ref>{{cite web | last1=Stein | first1=Kate | title=Timeline: The Life and Career of Scott Walker | url=http://host.madison.com/wsj/news/local/govt-and-politics/timeline-the-life-and-career-of-scott-walker/html_4c4013e6-9bfe-5cdd-b494-2ba6bcf88827.html | date=July 19, 2015 | publisher=''[[Wisconsin State Journal]]'' | accessdate=November 24, 2016}}</ref> and remains the only Republican to hold this office to date.<ref>{{cite web|title=Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker (R) at the Iowa Freedom Summit|website=c-span.org|location=Recorded speech. Comment begins at 8:40|url=http://www.c-span.org/video/?c4525006/wisconsin-governor-scott-walker-iowa-freedom-summit|accessdate=March 4, 2015}}</ref>
Walker won the office on a platform of [[Fiscal conservatism#Modern fiscal conservatism in the United States|fiscal conservatism]],<ref name="Biography.com"/> promising to give back part of his own salary. He said that his voluntary give-back gave him [[moral authority]] to make cuts in the budget. He returned $60,000 per year (slightly less than half of his salary) during his first term, and reduced his give-back to $10,000 per year during his second term.<ref name="would lower"/>
During his eight years in office, there were disputes with the county board "over taxes, privatization of public services, quality of parks and public buildings, and delivery of social services", according to the ''Milwaukee Journal Sentinel''.<ref name="politics calling"/> The County Board approved several budgets over Walker's veto and he never submitted a budget with a higher property tax than the board had approved the prior year.<ref name="AP guide"/> During Walker's tenure the number of county employees was reduced by over 20% and the $3.5 million county deficit was turned into a surplus.<ref name="preacher's kid"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.politifact.com/wisconsin/statements/2013/nov/14/scott-walker/gov-scott-walker-says-he-cut-staffing-20-percent-d|title=Gov. Scott Walker says he cut staffing 20 percent during his tenure as Milwaukee County executive|date=November 14, 2013|publisher=Politifact|accessdate=January 10, 2015}}</ref> In addition, he cut over $44 million in proposed spending through his veto powers and helped eliminate the waiting list for long-term care for senior citizens.<ref name="preacher's kid"/>
===Operation Freedom investigation=== [[File:Governor of Wisconsin Scott Walker at the Milwaukee Veterans Affairs Medical Center in 2014.jpg|thumb|Governor Walker at the Milwaukee Veterans Affairs Medical Center]] Walker appointed Kevin Kavanaugh, treasurer of the local chapter of the [[Military Order of the Purple Heart]], as a member of the County Veterans Service Commission.<ref name="Schultze">{{cite web|last=Schultze|first=Steve|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/milwaukee/former-walker-appointee-convicted-of-stealing-51000-from-vets-lo775be-173958721.html|title=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|publisher=Jsonline.com|date=October 12, 2012|accessdate=July 19, 2013}}</ref> Walker raised funds annually for veterans at the Operation Freedom Benefit, with proceeds to the Military Order of the Purple Heart. Walker's Chief of Staff, Thomas Nardelli, indicated that he went to Walker with concerns about missing money in 2009, and Walker directed him to report it to the district attorney's office. The district attorney did not immediately act but later launched a "[[John Doe]]" investigation.<ref name="Schultze"/> Kavanaugh and four others were arrested for theft of funds. Kavanaugh was convicted and sentenced to 21 months in prison.<ref>{{cite web|last=Schultze|first=Steve|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/milwaukee/former-walker-appointee-convicted-of-stealing-51000-from-vets-lo775be-173958721.html|title=Ex-Walker appointee convicted of stealing $51,000 from veterans|publisher=Jsonline.com|date=October 12, 2012|accessdate=July 19, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://radio.foxnews.com/2012/12/08/republican-aide-gets-two-years-for-embezzling-from-fund-for-soldiers-families|title=Republican aide gets two years for embezzling from fund for soldiers|publisher=Radio.foxnews.com|date=December 8, 2012|accessdate=July 19, 2013}}</ref>
Tim Russell, employed by Walker in a number of posts, was implicated in the same investigation; he was charged in January 2012 and pleaded guilty in November 2012 to diverting more than $21,000 to his personal bank account. In 2010, Walker's last year as Milwaukee County executive, Russell was his deputy chief of staff and Milwaukee Housing Director.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/milwaukee/former-walker-aide-pleads-guilt-to-embezzlement-charge-in-john-doe-iq7rgfb-181418561.html|title=Former Walker aide pleads guilty to embezzlement charge in John Doe|author=Schultze, Steve|work=Journal-Sentinel|date=November 9, 2012}}</ref> Walker was not charged with any wrongdoing.<ref>[http://watchdog.org/63473/wirep-walker-untouched-in-latest-john-doe-charges-in-wisconsin Walker untouched in latest charges], watchdog.org; accessed October 28, 2013.</ref>
==Governor of Wisconsin== ===Elections=== ====2006 campaign for governor==== {{main|Wisconsin gubernatorial election, 2006}} While county executive, Walker became a candidate, in February 2005, in the 2006 race for Wisconsin governor.<ref name="Crushing">{{cite web | last1=Isenstadt | first1=Alex | title=The Crushing Defeat that Shaped Scott Walker | url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/03/the-crushing-defeat-that-shaped-scott-walker-116490 | date=March 29, 2015 | publisher=[[Politico]] | accessdate=November 24, 2016}}</ref> He dropped out on March 24, 2006, after about 14 months of campaigning, citing fundraising difficulties.<ref name="statement"/><ref name="Crushing"/> Walker threw his support to fellow Republican [[Mark Andrew Green]], who won the Republican primary unopposed, and Walker actively campaigned for him during the general election.<ref name="Crushing"/> Green lost the general election, in November 2006, to the incumbent Democrat, [[Jim Doyle]].<ref name="announcement expected"/> Despite Green's loss, Walker's strong support for him helped increase Walker's favorability with the state GOP and positioned him as the frontrunner for the 2010 election.<ref name="Crushing"/>
====2010 campaign for governor==== {{Further|Wisconsin gubernatorial election, 2010}} [[File:Scott Walker primary victory 2010.jpg|thumb|right|Walker after winning the 2010 Republican gubernatorial primary]] Walker became an early favorite for the 2010 Republican Party endorsement for Wisconsin governor, winning [[straw polls]] of Wisconsin GOP convention attendees in 2007 and 2008.<ref name="straw poll"/><ref name="early favorites"/> He announced his candidacy in late April 2009 after several months of previewing his campaign themes of reduced taxes and reduced spending to Republican audiences around the state. He criticized the 2009–11 Wisconsin state budget as too big given the slow economy.<ref name="announcement expected"/> In 2009 and 2010, [[Americans for Prosperity]] helped raise Walker's statewide profile, inviting him to address its events and rallies throughout the state.<ref name=kochworld>{{cite news|title=Scott Walker Is King of Kochworld|date=February 17, 2015|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2015-02-17/scott-walker-is-king-of-kochworld|accessdate=April 20, 2015|first=Julie|last=Bykowicz|work=[[Bloomberg News]]}}</ref> Walker won the Wisconsin GOP convention endorsement on May 22, 2010, receiving 91% of the votes cast by delegates. He won the Republican nomination in the [[primary election]] of September 14, 2010, receiving 59% of the popular vote, while former U.S. Representative [[Mark Neumann]] garnered 39%.<ref name="primary results"/>
[[File:Milwaukee County Executive Scott Walker runs for Governor of Wisconsin in October 2010.jpg|left|thumb|Scott Walker speaks before the gubernatorial election]] As part of his campaign platform, Walker said he would create 250,000 jobs in his first term through a program that would include tax cuts for small businesses, [[capital gains tax|capital gains]] tax cuts, and income tax cuts.<ref name="AP guide"/> He proposed cutting state employee wages and benefits to help pay for these tax cuts. Critics argued that his proposals would help only the wealthy and that cutting the salaries of public employees would adversely affect state services,<ref name="accuses"/><ref name="targets wages"/> while supporters argued that tax cuts for businesses would spur the economy and create jobs.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/105693663.html|title=Walker tells MMAC he supports repealing corporate income tax|author=Stein, Jason|date=October 25, 2010|newspaper=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel}}</ref>
Walker indicated he would refuse an $810 million award from the federal [[United States Department of Transportation|Department of Transportation]] to build a high speed railroad line from Madison to Milwaukee as he believed it would cost the state $7.5 million per year to operate and would not prove profitable.<ref name="no thanks"/> This was in spite of offers by the mayor of Madison and the Dane County executive to help absorb costs the state might have incurred.<ref>[http://host.madison.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/capitol-report/capitol-report-madison-mayor-lashes-out-at-walker-over-high/article_07b1f032-03da-11e0-976c-001cc4c002e0.html "Mayor of Madison lashes out at Walker"], host.madison.com; accessed November 27, 2014.</ref> The award was later rescinded and split among other states.<ref name="rail funds"/> This cost the state at least $60 million for rail repairs federal funds would have covered.<ref>[http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/121871844.html Report on rail repair federal funds rejected by Governor Walker], jsonline.com; accessed November 27, 2014.</ref>
Social issues played a part in the campaign. Walker has stated that he is "100% pro-life" and that he believes life should be protected from conception to natural death.<ref name="protecting"/> He opposes [[abortion]], including in cases of [[rape]] and [[incest]].<ref name="abortion, birth control"/><ref name="even in"/> He supports [[abstinence-only sex education]] in the public schools and opposes state supported clinical services that provide [[birth control]] and testing and treatment of [[sexually transmitted disease]]s to teens under age 18 without parental consent.<ref name="abortion, birth control"/> He supports the right of pharmacists to refuse to fill prescriptions for [[contraceptive]]s on religious or moral grounds.<ref name="abortion, birth control"/><ref name="abortion debate"/> He supports [[adult stem cell research]] but opposes human [[embryonic stem cell]] research.<ref name="AP guide"/><ref name="even in"/><ref name="adult stem cell"/><ref name="wants to ban"/>
As an opponent of [[same-sex marriage]], he opposed a law that allowed gay couples to register with counties to get certain benefits, such as hospital visitation rights. He later stated that his position on same-sex marriage was no longer relevant because Wisconsin's ban on same-sex marriage had been overturned by a federal court.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.jsonline.com/watchdog/noquarter/scott-walker-declines-to-say-where-he-stands-on-gay-marriage-today-b99290317z1-262952941.html|title=Walker declines to define stand on gay marriage today|author=Bice, Daniel|date=June 12, 2014|newspaper=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel}}</ref> Walker said he would sign an [[Arizona SB 1070|Arizona-style immigration bill]], which would allow local police to stop suspected illegal immigrants, if he were elected.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ontheissues.org/Governor/Scott_Walker_Immigration.htm|title=Scott Walker on Immigration|publisher=Ontheissues.org|accessdate=June 19, 2015}}</ref>
On November 2, 2010, his 43rd birthday, Walker won the general election with 52% of total votes cast, while Democrat [[Tom Barrett (Wisconsin politician)|Tom Barrett]] received 46%.<ref name="2010 gov"/> His running mate, now Lieutenant Governor, was [[Rebecca Kleefisch]], a former Milwaukee television news reporter.<ref name="2010 gov"/> Walker's victory came amid a series of Wisconsin GOP victories, with conservative Republican [[Ron Johnson (Wisconsin politician)|Ron Johnson]] winning the contested U.S. Senate seat, and with the GOP gaining majorities in the state's U.S. House delegation, State Assembly, and State Senate.<ref>{{cite web | title=Wisconsin: GOP Wins Senate, House, Gov. Seats, Ousting Feingold | url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/politics/2010-11-02-wi-full-election-results_N.htm | date=November 3, 2010 | publisher=[[USA Today]] (from the [[Associated Press]]) | accessdate=November 24, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last1=Stein | first1=Jason | last2=Johnson | first2=Annysa | title=Republicans Take Over State Senate, Assembly | url=http://archive.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/106582898.html | date=November 3, 2010 | publisher=''[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]'' | accessdate=November 24, 2016}}</ref>
{{Election box begin no change |title= 2010 Election for Governor of Wisconsin <ref>{{cite web |title=Election 2010; Wisconsin |url=https://www.nytimes.com/elections/2010/results/wisconsin.html |website=nytimes.com |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=18 November 2018}}</ref> }} {{Election box winning candidate with party link no change |party = Republican Party (United States) |candidate = Scott Walker |votes = 1,128,941 |percentage = 52.3 }} {{Election box candidate with party link no change |party = Democratic Party (United States) |candidate = [[Tom Barrett (Wisconsin politician)|Tom Barrett]] |votes = 1,004,303 |percentage = 46.5 }} {{Election box end}}
====2012 recall election==== {{Main|Wisconsin gubernatorial recall election}} After the contentious [[2011 Wisconsin protests|collective bargaining dispute]], Walker's disapproval ratings varied between 50% and 51% while his approval ratings varied between 47% and 49% in 2011.<ref>{{cite news|first=Patrick|last=Marley|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/130173963.html|title=New poll reflects divide on bargaining limits|newspaper=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|date=September 20, 2011|accessdate=January 21, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publicpolicypolling.com/main/2011/10/wisconsin-recall-prospects-dimming.html|title=Wisconsin Recall Prospects Dimming|publisher=Public Policy Polling|date=October 26, 2011|accessdate=January 21, 2012}}</ref> The effort to [[Recall elections in Wisconsin|recall]] Walker officially began on November 15, 2011.<ref>[http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/walker-recall-effort-to-start-at-midnight-tn31qjo-133810473.html "Walker recall effort kicks off"], ''Milwaukee Journal Sentinel'', November 15, 2011; retrieved December 17, 2011.</ref>
Walker reportedly raised more than $30 million during the recall effort,<ref>{{cite news|title=Why Scott Walker won the Wisconsin recall|publisher=The Washington Post|date=June 5, 2012|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-fix/post/why-scott-walker-won-the-wisconsin-recall/2012/06/05/gJQAfbOGHV_blog.html|accessdate=June 28, 2015|first=Chris|last=Cillizza}}</ref> with a significant portion from out of state.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gov. Scott Walker's Big Money Backers Include 13 Out-Of-State Billionaires|publisher=Forbes|date=June 5, 2012|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/clareoconnor/2012/06/05/gov-scott-walkers-big-money-backers-include-13-out-of-state-billionaires|accessdate=June 28, 2015|first=Clare|last=O'Connor}}</ref> Commentators claimed the amount of money raised was "illustrating the national significance both political parties saw in the recall fight".<ref>[http://host.madison.com/wsj/news/local/govt-and-politics/with-half-the-money-coming-from-out-of-state-walker/article_72b7126c-2770-11e1-8ffb-001871e3ce6c.html "With half the money coming from out of state, Walker far outraising recall organizers"], ''Wisconsin State Journal'', December 15, 2011; retrieved December 17, 2011.</ref> In March 2012, the [[Wisconsin Government Accountability Board]] announced there were more than 900,000 valid signatures to force a recall vote, well above the required minimum of 540,208.<ref>{{cite web|last=Marley|first=Patrick|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/gab-staff-finds-more-than-900000-valid-signatures-to-recall-walker-ah4ptmf-144948425.html|title=GAB announces signatures|publisher=Jsonline.com|date=March 29, 2012|accessdate=July 19, 2013}}</ref>
In February 2012, Walker's campaign requested additional time for the petition signatures to be verified, claiming about 20% of the signatures were not valid. Democrats argued that even if 20% of the signatures were disregarded they still had obtained 180,000 more signatures than required to initiate the recall. Wisconsin Democratic Party Communications Director Graeme Zielinski claimed Walker was "delaying the inevitable".<ref>{{cite news|last=Bauer|first=Scott|title=Governor Scott Walker seeks more time for review of recall signatures|url=http://www.greenbaypressgazette.com/article/20120216/GPG0101/202160588/Governor-Scott-Walker-seeks-more-time-review-recall-signatures|newspaper=Green Bay Press-Gazette|accessdate=February 17, 2012}}</ref> On February 17, 2012, Dane County Judge Richard Niess, who had signed the recall petition, denied Walker's request for additional time.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://2012.talkingpointsmemo.com/2012/02/judge-tells-walker-no-more-extensions-on-the-recall.php|title=Judge Tells Walker: No More Extensions On The Recall|first=Eric|last=Kleefeld|date=February 17, 2012|work=[[Talking Points Memo]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229201012/http://2012.talkingpointsmemo.com/2012/02/judge-tells-walker-no-more-extensions-on-the-recall.php|archivedate=February 29, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> On March 30, 2012, the Government Accountability Board unanimously ruled in favor of the recall election. The recall elections for both Walker and Kleefisch took place on June 5, 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=Scott Walker Recall Election Ordered By Government Accountability Board|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/03/30/scott-walker-recall_n_1391209.html|publisher=The Huffington Post|accessdate=March 30, 2012|date=March 30, 2012}}</ref>
During the Republican primary election for the recall, Walker received 626,538 votes. In the Democratic primary, all of the Democratic candidates combined received 670,288, with the winner, Tom Barrett, receiving 390,109, a majority. On June 5, 2012, Walker won the recall election.<ref>{{cite news|last=Keating|first=Frank|title=Book Review: 'Unintimidated'|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/dec/2/book-review-unintimidated|newspaper=The Washington Times|accessdate=December 14, 2013}}</ref> This was only the third gubernatorial recall election in U.S. history and the first and only one to date which failed to unseat the incumbent governor.<ref>{{cite web | title=Wisconsin's Walker Survives Recall by Wide Margin | url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2012/06/05/polls-close-in-wisconsin-voter-turnout-reported-heavy.html | date=June 6, 2012 | publisher=[[Fox News Channel]] | accessdate=November 24, 2016}}</ref> Walker won the recall, his second face-off with Barrett, by a slightly larger margin (53% to 46%) than in the 2010 election (52% to 46%) and became the first [[List of United States governors|U.S. governor]] to win a recall election.<ref>{{cite web|last=C-SPAN|title=Gov. Walker Survives Recall Election; Defeats Milwaukee Mayor Tom Barrett|url=http://www.c-span.org/Events/Gov-Walker-Survives-Recall-Election-Defeats-Milwaukee-Mayor-Tom-Barrett/10737431254-1|accessdate=July 19, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130618015337/http://www.c-span.org/Events/Gov-Walker-Survives-Recall-Election-Defeats-Milwaukee-Mayor-Tom-Barrett/10737431254-1/|archivedate=June 18, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Montopoli|first=Brian|title=CBS News: Scott Walker wins Wisconsin recall election|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-57447954-503544/wisconsin-recall-walker-opens-slight-lead-as-votes-are-counted|newspaper=CBS News|date=June 5, 2012}}</ref>
By the end of the recall election, Walker had a national network of conservative donors and groups supporting him. Nearly 300,000 people donated to his recall campaign, which garnered roughly $37 million. Two-thirds of the contributions came from outside Wisconsin. Walker, or the conservative causes he supports, are also supported by conservative donors and groups including [[Michael W. Grebe]], [[Diane Hendricks]], and the [[Bradley Foundation]], founder of the [[Badger Institute|Wisconsin Policy Research Institute]] and the [[MacIver Institute]]; and [[David H. Koch]] and [[Charles Koch]], initial funders of [[Americans for Prosperity]].<ref name=NYT6815>{{cite news|author1=Patrick Healy and Monica Davey|title=Behind Scott Walker, a Longstanding Conservative Alliance Against Unions|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/08/us/politics/behind-scott-walker-a-longstanding-conservative-alliance-against-unions.html|accessdate=June 8, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=June 8, 2015|quote=Mr. Walker had a national network of conservative donors and groups behind him. Almost 300,000 people donated to his recall campaign, which raised about $37 million, two-thirds of it from outside Wisconsin.}}</ref>
====2014 campaign for governor==== {{Main|Wisconsin gubernatorial election, 2014}} [[File:Scott Walker 2014 Wisconsin Governor Victory Party.jpg|thumb|right|Walker after winning re-election as governor of Wisconsin in 2014]] In his third election in four years, Walker faced Democrat [[Mary Burke]] to determine the governor of Wisconsin.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gold|first=Matea|title=Republican Scott Walker wins hard-fought Wisconsin gubernatorial race|publisher=The Washington Post|date=November 4, 2014|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/republican-scott-walker-wins-hard-fought-wisconsin-gubernatorial-race/2014/11/04/d8d86a36-532e-11e4-892e-602188e70e9c_story.html|accessdate=February 27, 2015}}</ref> Wisconsin labor unions, who helped organize the 2012 Wisconsin recall election, donated funds to boost Burke's campaign. Walker received help from a number of conservative donors. The polling through most of the race was close and no candidate was a definitive favorite.<ref>{{cite web | last1=Rocha | first1=Polo | title=How Scott Walker Won His Third Governor’s Race in Four Years | url=https://badgerherald.com/news/2014/11/06/how-scott-walker-won-his-third-governors-race-in-four-years/ | date=November 6, 2014 | publisher=''[[The Badger Herald]]'' | accessdate=November 24, 2016}}</ref> The gubernatorial election took place on November 4, 2014 and Walker won re-election by 6 percent of the vote.<ref>{{cite news|last=McCormack|first=John|title=Walker Wins Again|publisher=The Weekly Standard|date=November 17, 2014|url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/articles/walker-wins-again_818388.html|accessdate=February 27, 2015}}</ref>

2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wpr.org/trump-becomes-1st-republican-presidential-candidate-1984-win-wisconsin|title=Trump Becomes First Republican Presidential Candidate Since
