Wave|last1=Litke|first1=Eric|date=November 10, 2016|publisher=''[[The Post-Crescent]]''|accessdate=November 25, 2016}}</ref>
=== Tenure === [[File:Historic Tax Credit Bill Signing.jpg|thumb|upright=1.15|Walker signing Historic Tax Credit Bill December 11, 2013 at [[Hotel Northland]]]] Walker took the oath of office to become the 45th Governor of Wisconsin on January 3, 2011.<ref name="to resign"/><ref name="last day"/> By January 25, 2011, the state legislature passed a series of Walker-backed bills, the largest of which would cut taxes for businesses at "a two-year cost of $67 million", according to the ''[[Associated Press]]''.<ref name="tax cuts">{{cite news|author=Bauer, Scott|date=January 26, 2011|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-25/wisconsin-legislature-set-to-pass-tax-cuts.html|title=Wisconsin Legislature passes tax cut|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110128041240/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-25/wisconsin-legislature-set-to-pass-tax-cuts.html|archivedate=January 28, 2011}}</ref>
Walker became a figure of national recognition and controversy after he proposed the "[[2011 Wisconsin Act 10|Wisconsin budget repair bill]]" in 2011. The bill, which would eventually be passed by the [[Wisconsin Legislature]], significantly changed the [[collective bargaining]] process for most public employees in Wisconsin. Opponents of Walker's actions launched a push for a recall election and received enough support to force [[Wisconsin gubernatorial recall election|an election]] on June 5, 2012, the first time a Governor of Wisconsin had ever faced recall.<ref name="nytimes1">{{cite news|last=Davey|first=Monica|title=Recall Election for Wisconsin Governor Who Battled Unions|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/31/us/wisconsin-approves-recall-election-for-governor-walker.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=March 30, 2012}}</ref>
During Walker's first term as governor, the state's $3.6 billion budget deficit was turned into a surplus<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politifact.com/wisconsin/statements/2013/nov/15/scott-walker/gov-scott-walker-says-he-turned-36-billion-deficit|title=Gov. Scott Walker says he turned $3.6 billion deficit into a $500 million surplus|date=November 15, 2013|accessdate=February 28, 2015|website=Politifact}}</ref> and taxes were cut by $2 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politifact.com/wisconsin/statements/2014/mar/12/scott-walker/gov-scott-walker-says-he-has-generated-2-billion-t|title=Gov. Scott Walker says he has generated $2 billion in tax cuts|date=March 12, 2014|accessdate=February 28, 2015|website=Politifact}}</ref> More than 100,000 jobs were created in the state of Wisconsin.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Horsley|first1=Scott|title=Wisconsin Voters Divided On Whether Job Growth Is Enough|url=https://www.npr.org/2014/09/04/345825909/wisconsin-voters-divided-on-whether-job-growth-is-enough|publisher=NPR|accessdate=September 13, 2014}}</ref> Overall, Wisconsin performed above the national average.<ref>{{cite web | last1=Puzder | first1=Andy | title=A Closer Look at Scott Walker’s Record on Jobs | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/a-closer-look-at-scott-walkers-record-on-jobs-1430688558 | date=May 3, 2015 | publisher=''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' | accessdate=November 6, 2016}}</ref> However it has yet to regain all the jobs lost during and after the [[Great Recession|Great Recession of 2007–2009]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.factcheck.org/2014/09/spinning-wisconsin-voters|title=Spinning Wisconsin Voters|date=September 10, 2014|accessdate=October 27, 2014|website=FactCheck.org}}</ref>
====2011 Budget Repair Bill and protests==== {{Further|2011 Wisconsin protests}} Walker proposed the [[Wisconsin Budget Repair Bill]] on February 11, 2011, estimated to save Wisconsin $30 million in the current fiscal year and $300 million over the next two years.<ref name="may take an ax"/> The bill requires additional contributions by state and local government workers to their health care plans and pensions, amounting to roughly an 8% decrease in the average government worker's take home pay.<ref name="outline intentions"/> The bill eliminated, for most state workers, other than certain public safety workers, many collective bargaining rights aside from seeking pay increases, and then not above the rate of inflation, unless approved by a voter [[referendum]].<ref name="how we got here"/> Under the bill, unions have to win yearly votes to continue representing government workers and could no longer have dues automatically deducted from government workers' paychecks.<ref name="may take an ax"/><ref name="read summary"/> Certain law enforcement personnel and firefighters are exempt from the bargaining changes.<ref name="ads attack"/><ref name="budget fights"/>
On January 18, 2011, days after Walker's inauguration, [[Beloit, Wisconsin|Beloit]] businesswoman and Walker supporter [[Diane Hendricks]] asked him, "Any chance we'll ever get to be a completely red state and work on these unions and become a right-to-work (state)?", and he replied: <blockquote>Well, we're going to start in a couple weeks with our budget adjustment bill. The first step is, we're going to deal with collective bargaining for all public employee unions, because you use divide and conquer. So for us the base we've got for that is the fact that we've got – budgetarily we can't afford not to. If we have collective bargaining agreements in place, there's no way not only the state but local governments can balance things out. So you think city of Beloit, city of Janesville, any of the school districts, that opens the door once we do that. That's your bigger problem right there.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Marley|first1=Patrick|title=A transcript of the Walker-Hendricks union discussion|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/a-transcript-of-the-walkerhendricks-union-discussion-805952v-151052965.html|accessdate=March 16, 2015|agency=Journal Sentinel|date=May 10, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|date=May 10, 2012|title=In film, Walker talks of 'divide and conquer' union strategy|first1=Jason|last1=Stein|first2=Patrick|last2=Marley|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/in-film-walker-talks-of-divide-and-conquer-strategy-with-unions-8o57h6f-151049555.html|newspaper=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]|accessdate=May 12, 2015}}</ref></blockquote>
After video tape of the interaction was released in May 2012, Walker's opponents said Walker had revealed his intention to target private sector unions and pursue right-to-work legislation. Walker said he was not pursuing right-to-work legislation and that in his 2011 comment to Hendricks he was referring to his responsibility as governor to defend taxpayers from unions that he believed were frustrating resolution of the state's budget deficit.<ref name=fox20120511>{{cite news|publisher=[[Fox News]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2012/05/11/video-walker-explains-divide-conquer-strategy|date=May 11, 2012|title=Video: Walker explains divide, conquer strategy|accessdate=May 12, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Scott Walker Recall: Governor Outlines 'Divide And Conquer' Union Strategy In Video|first=Jeremy|last=White|date=May 11, 2012|accessdate=May 12, 2015|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/scott-walker-recall-governor-outlines-divide-and-conquer-union-strategy-video-698009|publisher=[[International Business Times]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|title=Scott Walker said budget strategy in Wisconsin was 'divide and conquer'|first=Aaron|last=Blake|date=May 11, 2012|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-fix/post/scott-walker-said-budget-strategy-in-wisconsin-was-divide-and-conquer/2012/05/11/gIQARhmTIU_blog.html|accessdate=May 12, 2015}}</ref>
In announcing the proposed legislation, Walker said the [[Wisconsin National Guard]] and other state agencies were prepared to prevent disruptions in state services.<ref name="is prepared"/><ref name="national guard"/> He later explained that police and firefighters were excluded from the changes because he would not jeopardize public safety. Walker stated that the bill was necessary to avoid laying off thousands of state employees and that no one should be surprised by its provisions. Union leaders and Democratic legislators immediately criticized the bill, claiming Walker had never campaigned on doing away with collective bargaining rights.<ref name="national guard"/> In a media interview a week later, Walker said he was not trying to break the public sector unions, noting that Wisconsin government employees would retain the protections of civil service laws. He said that asking employees to pay half the national average for health care benefits was a modest request.<ref name="bold political"/>
Demonstrators began protesting the proposed bill on February 14, 2011.<ref>[http://host.madison.com/wsj/news/local/education/on_campus/article_87a7eaa0-3853-11e0-bcc7-001cc4c002e0.html UW-Madison students to Walker: "Don't Break My ♥"], ''Wisconsin State Journal'', February 14, 2011. Retrieved December 17, 2011.</ref> During the sixth day of the protests, leaders of the two largest unions said publicly they were prepared to accept the financial concessions in the bill, but would not agree to the limitations of collective bargaining rights. All 14 of the Democratic state senators left the state to [[Illinois]] on February 17, preventing the passage of the bill by the mostly Republican legislature in the absence of the [[quorum]] necessary for a vote.<ref name="shows no sign"/> The missing legislators said they would not return to Madison unless Walker agreed to remove the limitations on collective bargaining from the bill.<ref name="outline intentions"/><ref name="fake sick"/> Walker warned that if the budget repair bill was not passed by March 1, refinancing of a $165 million state debt would fail, and more cuts would be needed to balance the budget.<ref name="outline intentions"/>
Appearing on ''[[Meet the Press]]'' on February 27, Walker stated that he did not believe the unions were negotiating in good faith in offering pension and health-care concessions because local unions had recently pushed through contracts with school boards and city councils that did not include contributions to the pensions and health care and that, in one case, a contract even included a pay increase.<ref name="shows no sign"/> On February 28, the largest public union filed an unfair labor practices complaint with the state labor relations board, claiming that Walker had a duty to negotiate, but had refused.<ref name="outline intentions"/>
On March 8, private emails dating back to February 28 were released. These emails showed that Governor Walker had tried to negotiate with Democratic legislators, even proposing to allow some collective bargaining rights.<ref name="will negotiate"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://media.journalinteractive.com/documents/Email_exchange_030811.pdf|title=Email exchange|date=March 8, 2011|accessdate=August 17, 2011}}</ref> However, after failing to reach a compromise with Democratic legislators, the Republican Senate legislators removed certain fiscal provisions from the bill, allowing it to be passed by a simple senate majority.<ref name="walker passes bill"/>
On March 18, Judge Maryann Sumi issued a court order to prohibit publication of the bill by the Secretary of State while legal challenges to it were being considered. On March 26, the Legislative Reference Bureau (LRB) published the bill. Republicans contended the court order did not mention the LRB, which is (also) responsible for publishing laws, and that the publication made the bill law. Democrats maintained the bill could not become law until the Secretary of State took action, and the entire law was published in the state newspaper of record, the ''Wisconsin State Journal''. Sumi subsequently clarified that, pursuant to her order, the bill could not be considered to be published, pending completion of court review.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1370357/Opponents-Wisconsin-anti-union-promise-tsunami-litigation.html|title=Opponents of 'anti-union' bill promise tsunami of litigation|work=Daily Mail|date=March 26, 2011|accessdate=January 21, 2012|location=London, UK}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Jonsson|first=Patrik|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Politics/2011/0326/Wisconsin-union-gutting-law-took-effect-Saturday-or-did-it|title=Wisconsin union-gutting law took effect Saturday – or did it?|publisher=The Christian Science Monitor|date=March 26, 2011|accessdate=January 21, 2012}}</ref>
On May 26, Judge Sumi struck down the budget repair bill, finding that its passage was in violation of state open meetings laws.<ref>{{cite news|title=Judge voids law limiting union rights|author=Bauer, Scott|agency=Associated Press|date=May 27, 2011|url=http://articles.boston.com/2011-05-27/news/29600429_1_open-meetings-quorum-requirement-protests|work=The Boston Globe}}</ref> The [[Wisconsin Supreme Court]] overturned Sumi's ruling on June 14.<ref>{{cite news|last=Marley|first=Patrick|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/123859034.html|title=Supreme Court reinstates collective bargaining law|newspaper=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|date=June 14, 2011|accessdate=January 21, 2012}}</ref>
Walker claimed the measures would "save jobs, protect taxpayers, reform government and help balance the budget."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/03/10/police-remove-protesters-wisconsin-capitol|title=Police remove protesters Wisconsin Capitol|publisher=foxnews.com|date=March 10, 2011|accessdate=February 23, 2015}}</ref> He added, "You see, despite a lot of the rhetoric we've heard over the past 11 days the bill I put forward isn't aimed at state workers, and it certainly isn't a battle with unions. If it was, we would have eliminated collective bargaining entirely or we would have gone after the private-sector unions."<ref>[http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/116696249.html Excerpt from Walker speech re unions], jsonline.com; accessed February 25, 2015.</ref> As part of the cost savings resulting from the changes to collective bargaining, Walker points to significant reductions in the premiums for health insurance for many school districts. Prior to the deficit reduction bill, WEA Trust, which is affiliated with Wisconsin's largest teachers union, dominated the market for health insurance for the state's school districts. The changes to collective bargaining made it easier for school districts to change health insurance providers and negotiate better premiums. Walker claims that Wisconsin school districts have saved an estimated $30 million as a result of the change.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kertscher|first=Tom|url=http://www.politifact.com/wisconsin/article/2012/may/21/behind-rhetoric-wea-trust-and-school-health-care-c|title=Behind the rhetoric: The WEA Trust and school health care costs|publisher=PolitiFact|date=May 21, 2012|accessdate=May 22, 2015}}</ref>
=====John Doe campaign finance investigation===== In August 2012, the first investigation, which had been launched by [[John T. Chisholm|John Chisholm]], Milwaukee County District Attorney, a Democrat, into missing funds, was rolled into a second [[Wisconsin Circuit Court#Grand jury and John Doe proceedings|John Doe probe]] based on a theory that Governor Walker's campaign had illegally coordinated with conservative groups engaged in issue advocacy during the recall elections.<ref name="watchdog.org">{{cite news|last1=Kittle|first1=MD|url=http://watchdog.org/149217/john-doe-wall-street-journal-investigation|title='Never-ending' John Doe never ended, WSJ reports|newspaper=Wisconsin Reporter|date=June 9, 2014|accessdate=April 13, 2015}}</ref>
The initial John Doe judge, retired Kenosha County Circuit Judge Barbara A. Kluka, overseeing the John Doe investigation issued 30 subpoenas and 5 search warrants. She also issued a secrecy order which meant those being investigated were legally bound from discussing any facet of the investigation publicly.<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304799404579155953286552832 "Wisconsin Political Speech Raid"], ''Wall Street Journal'', November 18, 2013; accessed May 22, 2015.</ref> On October 29, 2013, she [[recusal|recused]] herself from the investigation without explanation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://watchdog.org/113658/judge-investigation-democrat|title=EXCLUSIVE: Judge in Democrat-led John Doe probe recuses herself|work=Watchdog.org|accessdate=May 10, 2015}}</ref> Kluka's replacement, Judge Gregory Peterson, quashed several subpoenas in January 2014, saying "there was no probable cause shown that they violated campaign finance laws".<ref name="watchdog.org"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://watchdog.org/113658/judge-investigation-democrat|title=EXCLUSIVE: Judge in Democrat-led John Doe probe recuses herself|work=Watchdog.org|accessdate=May 22, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://watchdog.org/115840/judge-milwaukee-investigation|title=Sources: New judge named in Democrat-led secret probe|work=Watchdog.org|accessdate=May 22, 2015}}</ref>
On July 16, 2015, the Wisconsin Supreme Court ruled 4–2 that Walker did not illegally collaborate with conservative groups during the recall campaigns. Writing for the majority in the case, Justice Michael Gableman stated: "To be clear, this conclusion ends the John Doe investigation because the special prosecutor's legal theory is unsupported in either reason or law," he said, "Consequently, the investigation is closed."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hensch|first1=Mark|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/presidential-races/248162-walker-cleared-in-campaign-finance-probe|title=Court ends Walker campaign finance probe|publisher=The Hill|date=July 16, 2015|accessdate=July 16, 2015}}</ref> In March 2017, a federal judge dismissed a lawsuit filed against the investigators of the case.<ref>{{cite web | title=Federal Judge Dismisses Governor Scott Walker-Related John Doe Lawsuit | url=http://fox6now.com/2017/03/16/federal-judge-dismisses-governor-scott-walker-related-john-doe-lawsuit/ | date=March 16, 2017 | publisher=''fox6now.com'' | accessdate=March 22, 2017}}</ref>
====2011–2013 budget proposal==== Wisconsin faced an anticipated deficit of approximately $3.6 billion in the 2012–13 budget cycle<ref name="may take an ax"/><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Reuters|title=Wisconsin boosts 3-year rev projection by $636 mln|date=May 11, 2011|author=Pierog, Karen|quote=The new revenue projection comes as the {{sic|the}} state wrestles with a $3.6 billion hole in its upcoming two-year budget.|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/05/11/wisconsin-revenue-idUKN1124356120110511|accessdate=August 3, 2011}}</ref> which must be balanced according to state law. Walker's proposed budget cut $834 million in state aid for K-12 education, which would be a 7.9% reduction from the prior budget. He proposed a 5.5% decrease in the maximum amount of funding school districts can receive from state aid and property taxes, which would limit how much property taxes could be increased to compensate for the reduction in state aid. The budget lowered state capital gains taxes for investments in Wisconsin businesses. It increased spending on health care by $1.3 billion to cover increased costs for [[Medicaid]], and increased transportation funding by $410.5 million.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stein|first=Jason|title=Walker's budget cuts would touch most Wisconsinites|publisher=Milwaukee-Wisconsin Journal Sentinel|date=March 1, 2011|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/117154428.html|accessdate=January 12, 2015}}</ref>
====2013–2015 budget proposal==== [[File:Governor of Wisconsin Scott Walker speaking at the 2015 Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC).jpg|thumb|300px|right|Walker speaking at the 2015 [[Conservative Political Action Conference]]]] Walker's proposed budget for fiscal 2013–2015 froze spending on public schools and tightened the income requirements for Medicaid recipients. It proposed an increase in funding for fighting domestic violence, mental health care, higher education, and job training. It also included a $343 million cut in income taxes and an expansion of the state's school voucher program.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hall|first=Dee|title=Gov. Scott Walker to stump for budget that includes income tax cut, school voucher expansion|publisher=The Journal Times|date=February 21, 2013|url=http://journaltimes.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/gov-scott-walker-to-stump-for-budget-that-includes-income/article_b09dc5fd-8c6f-58b1-b9ac-e14b8a10c1e3.html|accessdate=February 5, 2015}}</ref>
====2015–2017 budget proposal==== Walker's proposed budget for fiscal 2015–2017 included a $300 million cut to the [[University of Wisconsin System]], while holding funding flat for K-12 public schools and continuing to expand the school voucher program. It included a plan to borrow $1.3 billion to fund improvements to roads and infrastructure, and proposed drug testing for recipients of public benefits like Medicaid and food stamps.<ref>{{cite news|title=Scott Walker unveils Wisconsin budget|publisher=CBS News|date=February 4, 2015|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/scott-walker-unveils-wisconsin-budget|accessdate=February 5, 2015}}</ref>
====Domestic partner registry defense==== On May 13, 2011, the Walker administration petitioned the Dane County Circuit Court for permission to withdraw the state as a defendant from ''[[Appling v. Doyle]]'', which was a challenge to the state's [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Wisconsin|domestic partner registry]].<ref name="withdraw">{{cite web|last=Marley|first=Patrick|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/121956273.html|title=Walker seeks to stop defense of state's domestic partner registry|publisher=Jsonline.com|date=May 16, 2011|accessdate=December 4, 2013}}</ref>
====Regulatory reform bill==== On May 23, 2011, Walker signed legislation changing the process of creating administrative rules for the state. This measure, which became 2011 Wisconsin Act 21 (and became effective June 8, 2011), changes State agency authority to promulgate rules, provides for gubernatorial approval of proposed rules, revised the requirement of an economic impact analysis for proposed rules and changes venue in the process of judicial review of agency rules.{{Clarify|date=February 2015}}<ref>{{cite news|author=Best, Michael|url=http://www.natlawreview.com/article/wisconsin-governor-walker-signs-regulatory-reform-bill-law|title=Wisconsin Governor Walker Signs Regulatory Reform Bill into Law|publisher=The National Law Review|date=July 1, 2011|accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref>
====Voter ID law==== {{main|2011 Wisconsin Act 23}} On May 25, 2011, Walker signed a [[Voter ID laws in the United States|voter ID law]] that required voters to show a government-issued ID before casting a ballot.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/05/25/wisconsin-voter-id-law-scott-walker_n_867090.html|title=Wisconsin Voter ID Law Signed By Scott Walker|publisher=The Huffington Post|agency=Reuters|date=May 25, 2011|accessdate=January 21, 2012|first=Nicholas|last=Wing}}</ref>
The [[ACLU]] filed a lawsuit in federal court to invalidate the law on December 13, 2011, claiming the law violates the constitutional guarantee of [[Equal Protection Clause|equal protection under the law]].<ref>[http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-12-13/wisconsin-voter-id-law-unconstitutional-aclu-says-in-suit.html "Wisconsin Voter ID Law Unconstitutional, ACLU Says in Suit"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130606220526/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-12-13/wisconsin-voter-id-law-unconstitutional-aclu-says-in-suit.html |date=June 6, 2013 }}, BusinessWeek.com, December 13, 2011; retrieved December 17, 2011.</ref> On April 29, 2014, U.S. District Judge [[Lynn Adelman]] struck down the law, saying it violated the [[Voting Rights Act]] and [[U.S. Constitution]].<ref name="Fed judge Strikes down Voter ID">{{cite web|title=Federal judge strikes down Wisconsin's voter ID law|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/federal-judge-strikes-down-wisconsins-voter-id-law-b99258822z1-257200321.html|website=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|accessdate=August 18, 2014}}</ref>
The Wisconsin Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of the voter ID law under the [[Constitution of Wisconsin]] in two other cases in July 2014.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Associated Press|title=Wisconsin Supreme Court Upholds Voter ID Law|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/wisconsin-supreme-court-upholds-voter-id-law-24789178|website=ABC News|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140810161134/http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/wisconsin-supreme-court-upholds-voter-id-law-24789178|archivedate=August 10, 2014|year=2014}}</ref> On September 12, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit|7th Circuit Court of Appeals]] allowed the law to be put into effect just 54 days before the 2014 elections, overturning a previous ruling in federal court.<ref>{{cite news|title=Federal Appeals Court Permits Wisconsin Voter ID Law|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/13/us/voter-id-law-in-wisconsin-is-permitted-by-us-court.html?smid=fb-share|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=December 26, 2014|first=Monica|last=Davey|date=September 12, 2014}}</ref>
On October 9, 2014, the state was again barred from implementing the voter ID law for 2014 by the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]].<ref>Liptak, Adam. [https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/10/us/politics/supreme-court-blocks-wisconsin-voter-id-law.html?_r=0 "Courts Strike Down Voter ID Laws in Wisconsin and Texas"], nytimes.com, October 9, 2014; retrieved December 26, 2014.</ref><ref>Barnes, Robert. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/courts_law/supreme-court-blocks-wisconsin-voter-id-law/2014/10/09/e52af8fe-4ff4-11e4-8c24-487e92bc997b_story.html "Supreme Court Blocks Wisconsin Voter ID Law"], WashingtonPost.com; October 9, 2014; retrieved December 26, 2014.</ref> On March 23, 2015, the Supreme Court denied writ of certiorari, thus ruling in favor of the state of Wisconsin's new stricter voter ID law.<ref>{{cite news|title=U.S. top court rejects challenge to Wisconsin voter ID law|url=http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/us-top-court-rejects-challenge-to-wisconsin-voter-id-law/ar-BBiBVmH?ocid=ansnewsreu11|publisher=Reuters|date=March 23, 2015|accessdate=March 25, 2015}}</ref>
====Rejection of health care funds==== In January 2012, Walker returned a $37.6 million federal grant meant to set up a health exchange in Wisconsin for the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]].<ref name="stein"/> Walker said "Stopping the encroachment of Obamacare in our state, which has the potential to have a devastating impact on Wisconsin's economy, is a top priority."<ref name="APACA"/> Walker rejected an $11 million federal grant designed to improve Medicaid enrollment systems.<ref name="stein"/> It can take up to 3 months to determine whether an applicant qualifies for the program. If the applicant does not qualify, the state must pay the medical costs for the first three months. The Walker administration previously said it wants to end the practice of presuming some applicants are eligible and go to a real-time system for determining eligibility.<ref name="stein"/> Walker rejected an expansion of Medicaid coverage for the state, but instead reduced the eligibility requirements for the state's [[BadgerCare]] program.<ref>Spicuzza, Mary. [http://host.madison.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/legislature-s-budget-committee-rejects-medicaid-expansion/article_764dc436-c4a7-5d8e-89d0-39ffa09c7f8d.html "Legislature's budget committee rejects Medicaid expansion"], ''Wisconsin State Journal'', June 4, 2013.</ref>
====Education==== On April 2, 2012, Walker signed a law to fund evaluation of the reading skills of kindergartners as part of an initiative to ensure that students are reading at or above grade level by 3rd grade. The law also created a system for evaluating teachers and principals based in part on the performance of their students. It specified that student performance metrics must be based on objective measures, including their performance on [[standardized tests]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Raymond Neupert|url=http://wdez.com/news/articles/2012/apr/02/walker-signs-reading-teacher-evaluation-bill|title=Walker signs reading, teacher evaluation bill|publisher=KDEZ|date=April 2, 2012|accessdate=August 29, 2013}}</ref>
Walker approved a two-year freeze of tuition at the University of Wisconsin System in the 2013 budget. In 2014, he proposed a two-year extension of the freeze based on expected cash balances for the system in excess of $1 billion.<ref>{{cite news|author=Jason Stein|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/walker-proposes-another-two-year-uw-system-tuition-freeze-b99245814z1-254902211.html|title=Scott Walker proposes another two year UW System tuition freeze|publisher=Milwaukee-Wisconsin Journal Sentinel|date=April 11, 2014|accessdate=April 29, 2015}}</ref>
On February 3, 2015, Walker delivered a budget proposal to the Wisconsin Legislature, in which he recommended placing the [[University of Wisconsin]] system under the direction of a "private authority", governed by the Board of Regents (all the governor's appointees). The budget proposal called for a 13% reduction in state funding for the university system.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/education/walker-proposes-13-cut-more-freedom-for-uw-system-b99433644z1-289880441.html|title=Walker proposes 13% cut, more freedom for UW System|last=Bauer|first=Scott|work=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|date=January 27, 2015|accessdate=February 8, 2015}}</ref>
The budget proposal also called for re-writing the [[Wisconsin Idea]], replacing the university's fundamental commitment to the "search for truth" with the goal of [[Economy of the United States|workforce]] readiness.<ref>[http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/documents-show-walker-administration-seeking-removal-of-uws-wisconsin-idea-b99439710z1-290927651.html Walker administration seeking removal of UWS 'Wisconsin Idea'], jsonline.com; accessed February 6, 2015.</ref> Walker faced broad criticism for the changes and at first blamed the rewriting of the Wisconsin Idea on a "drafting error."<ref>[http://www.politifact.com/wisconsin/statements/2015/feb/06/scott-walker/despite-deliberate-actions-scott-walker-calls-chan Despite deliberate actions, Walker calls proposed change to UW System administration a "drafting error"], politifact.com; accessed February 6, 2015.</ref> [[Politifact]] and the ''[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]'' later reported that Walker's administration had insisted to University of Wisconsin officials on scrapping the Wisconsin Idea, the guiding principle for the state's universities for more than a century. Walker then acknowledged that UW System officials had raised objections about the proposal and had been told the changes were not open to debate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/documents-show-walker-administration-seeking-removal-of-uws-wisconsin-idea-b99439710z1-290927651.html|title=Walker forced to admit UW objected to Wisconsin Idea changes|last1=Stein|first1=Jason|last2=Marley|first2=Patrick|last3=Herzog|first3=Karen|work=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|date=February 5, 2015|accessdate=February 8, 2015}}</ref>
====Indian gaming==== Section 20(b)(1)(A) of the [[Indian Gaming Regulatory Act]] (IGRA) gives governors unrestricted authority to approve or veto any off-reservation tribal casino located in their state.<ref name="wargames">{{cite journal|last1=Whittlesey|first1=Dennis J.|author2=Dickinson Wright PLLC|title=War Games in Wisconsin (2013 Style) Re: Indian Tribes|journal=The National Law Review|date=November 6, 2013|url=http://www.natlawreview.com/article/war-games-wisconsin-2013-style-re-indian-tribes|accessdate=November 18, 2013}}</ref>
Walker has said he will only approve new off-reservation casino projects if they are supported by every tribe in the state. This has been referred to as the "Walker Rule".<ref name="wargames"/> In January 2015, Walker rejected a proposed casino in [[Kenosha, Wisconsin]].<ref>[http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/scott-walker-rejects-menominee-bid-for-kenosha-casino-b99431696z1-289587411.html Walker rejects proposed casino in Kenosha], jsonline.com; accessed March 3, 2015.</ref>
====Abortion==== Walker signed the 2011 state budget that de-funded [[Planned Parenthood]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Wisconsin Cuts Funds to Planned Parenthood|first=Maggie|last=Fox|magazine=[[National Journal]]|date=June 26, 2011|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/healthcare/wisconsin-cuts-funds-to-planned-parenthood-20110626|accessdate=May 12, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150506142952/http://www.nationaljournal.com/healthcare/wisconsin-cuts-funds-to-planned-parenthood-20110626|archivedate=May 6, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In 2013, Walker signed a bill that requires women seeking abortions to undergo an [[ultrasound]] and doctors to show the women the image of the fetus.<ref name="APoct22">{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/scott-walker-outlines-abortion-gay-marriage-positions-in-letter-b99375704z1-279975922.html|title=Scott Walker outlines abortion, gay marriage positions in letter|newspaper=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]|date=October 22, 2014|accessdate=May 12, 2015}}</ref>
In 2013, Walker signed a bill requiring abortion providers in Wisconsin to have admitting privileges at a hospital within 30 miles. The law was found unconstitutional by the [[Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals]] in 2015. The court found the medical justifications for such restrictions "nonexistent" and said they "cannot be taken seriously as a measure to improve women's health."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Marley|first1=Patrick|title=Judges: Wisconsin abortion admitting privileges law unconstitutional|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/wisconsin-abortion-admitting-privileges-law-unconstitutional-court-affirms-b99621967z1-353085451.html|accessdate=June 5, 2016|work=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|date=November 23, 2015}}</ref> In June 2016, the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] ruled on ''[[Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt]]'', and struck down admitting privileges and other similar restrictions, finding that they were an unconstitutional "undue burden" on women. The day after delivering this decision, the Court refused to hear the Walker administration's appeal of the Seventh Circuit decision, leaving its finding of unconstitutionality in place. Walker blamed an "activist court" for finding his law unconstitutional.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Stein|first1=Jason|title=U.S. Supreme Court denies Wisconsin's appeal on abortion clinic restrictions|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/us-supreme-court-denies-wisconsins-appeal-on-abortion-clinic-restrictions-b99752440z1-384689071.html|accessdate=July 5, 2016|work=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|date=June 28, 2016}}</ref>
On July 20, 2015, Walker signed a bill into law that banned all abortions after the 20th week of pregnancy, "except when the life of the mother is in immediate danger."<ref name="20WeekBan">{{cite web | last1=Stein | first1=Jason | title=Scott Walker Signs 20-Week Abortion Ban, Trooper Pay Raise | url=http://archive.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/scott-walker-signs-bill-banning-abortions-after-20-weeks-b99540949z1-317539131.html | date=July 20, 2015 | publisher=''[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]'' | accessdate=November 24, 2016}}</ref>
===Right to work===
In 2012, regarding [[Right-to-work law|right-to-work legislation]], Walker told reporters at the state Republican Party convention that "It's not going to get to my desk ... I'm going to do everything in my power to make sure it isn't there because my focal point (is) private sector [[trade union|unions]] have overwhelmingly come to the table to be my partner in economic development."<ref name="Kertscher">{{cite web|last1=Kertscher|first1=Tom|title=On supporting 2015 right to work legislation, a Scott Walker reversal|url=http://www.politifact.com/wisconsin/statements/2015/feb/23/scott-walker/supporting-2015-right-work-legislation-scott-walke|website=Politifact.com|accessdate=March 10, 2015}}</ref> While campaigning for re-election in 2014, Walker again said he had no plans to pursue right-to-work legislation focused on private unions.<ref name=npr20150225/>
Once the legislation was initiated in the state legislature, Walker stated: "I haven't changed my position on it, it just wasn't a priority for me. But should they pass it within the next two weeks, which is their target, I plan on signing it."<ref name=npr20150225>[https://www.npr.org/2015/02/25/389028488/wisconsin-governor-to-sign-right-to-work-bill-amid-protests Governor Walker signs right to work bill amid protests], npr.org, February 25, 2015; accessed March 9, 2015.</ref> On March 9, 2015, Walker signed legislation making Wisconsin a right-to-work state.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/10/us/gov-scott-walker-of-wisconsin-signs-right-to-work-bill.html Governor Walker of Wisconsin signs right-to-work bill], nytimes.com, March 10, 2015.</ref> The law applied to private employee unions as well as public.<ref name=aj20150309>{{cite news|title=How Scott Walker won by dividing and conquering Wisconsin unions|date=March 9, 2015|first=Ned|last=Resnikoff|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2015/3/9/how-scott-walker-won-by-dividing-and-conquering-wisconsin-labor.html|accessdate=May 12, 2015|agency=[[Al Jazeera]]}}</ref> Once signed, Walker claimed partial credit for the right-to-work law.<ref name=aj20150309/> Politifact.com rated Walker's position on right-to-work as a "major reversal of position."<ref name=Kertscher />
Three trade unions, including the [[AFL-CIO]], subsequently sued to get the law overturned as unconstitutional. In March 2015, the court declined the unions' request to put the law on hold until the lawsuit is settled.<ref>Andrew M. Harris (March 19, 2015) [https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2015-03-19/scott-walker-fights-labor-over-dues-as-presidential-race-looms Wisconsin Unions Lose Bid to Block Walker's Right-to-Work Law], Bloomberg.com; accessed May 12, 2015.</ref> Following a protracted legal battle, in 2017 the U.S. appeals court in Chicago upheld Wisconsin’s right-to-work law ending the substantive legal challenges to the law.
===WEDC===
{{main|Wisconsin Economic Development Corporation}} In 2011, the WEDC was created by Walker as a quasi-public entity to replace the state's [[Wisconsin Department of Commerce|Department of Commerce]] with the objective of incenting job creation in Wisconsin. A 2013 report from the state's Legislative Audit Committee indicated that the organization gave some "grants, loans, and tax credits to ineligible recipients, for ineligible projects, and for amounts that exceeded specified limits." It also reported that WEDC "did not consistently perform statutorily required program oversight duties such as monitoring the contractually specified performance of award recipients".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Stein|first1=Jason|last2=Marley|first2=Patrick|title=Wisconsin jobs agency failed in tracking taxpayer money, audit finds|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/wisconsin-jobs-agency-failed-in-tracking-taxpayer-money-audit-finds-9a9pl8g-205595881.html|website=jsonline.com|publisher=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, Inc|accessdate=June 23, 2005|date=May 1, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Swensen|first1=Dean|last2=Ramirez|first2=Zach|last3=Baker|first3=Kelly|last4=Kleinmaier|first4=Dan|last5=Klusmeier|first5=Amy|last6=Malone|first6=James|last7=Natzke|first7=Noah|last8=Reed|first8=Bob|last9=Schindler|first9=Jacob|last10=Tippens|first10=Georges|title=Wisconsin Economic Development Corporation|journal=Legislative Audit Bureau|date=May 1, 2013|url=http://legis.wisconsin.gov/lab/reports/13-7full.pdf|accessdate=June 25, 2015}}</ref> According to Wisconsin Public Radio, "The agency has been plagued by mismanagement and questions about handing out loans without properly vetting recipients."<ref name=npr0721>{{cite web|last1=Murray|first1=Pat|title=WEDC Selects Chairman To Replace Walker|url=http://www.wpr.org/wedc-selects-chairman-replace-walker|website=wpr.org|publisher=Wisconsin Public Radio|accessdate=July 21, 2015|date=July 21, 2015}}</ref>
In June 2015, it was reported that under Walker, WEDC gave out $124 million between the years 2011 and 2013 without formal review. Based on the 27 awards during that period, 2,100 jobs had been created to date out of a total expected of 6,100. $62.5 million was awarded to [[Kohl's]] to create 3,000 jobs as part of a headquarters expansion but only 473 had been created, $18 million was awarded to [[Kestrel K-350|Kestrel Aircraft]] which was supposed to create 665 jobs but only created 24, and $15 million went to Plexus Corp. to create 350 jobs, but created zero. In July 2013, WEDC adopted a new policy requiring written reviews on all program awards. According to WEDC, it had approved more than 760 reviewed awards under the new policy by June 2015.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Tribune Wire Reports|title=Scott Walker's Wisconsin jobs agency gave out $124 million without review|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-scott-walker-jobs-agency-20150619-story.html|accessdate=June 25, 2015|publisher=Chicago Tribune|date=June 19, 2015|quote=The three highest un-reviewed awards all came through the enterprise zone program. The largest, $62.5 million, went to Kohl's Department Stores for an expansion of its corporate headquarters on June 28, 2012, for a project that was expected to create 3,000 jobs but that has created just 473 so far. The next highest was $18 million to Kestrel Aircraft Company for an expected 665 jobs, but just 24 have been created. The third highest was $15 million to Plexus Corp. to create 350 jobs, but none have been created, according to a tally provided by WEDC.}}</ref>
Walker introduced a state budget in February 2015 which removed all of the elected officials from the board. This included removing himself from chairmanship of WEDC. This was revised by the Legislature's budget committee who altered it to only remove Walker. Walker signed the budget in July 2015.<ref name=npr0721/>
