news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jeffreydorfman/2017/09/06/government-incentives-to-attract-jobs-are-terrible-deals-for-taxpayers/1#5b7ad9526eff|title=Government Incentives To Attract Jobs Are Terrible Deals For Taxpayers|last=Dorfman|first=Jeffrey|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-11-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2018-11-06/wisconsin-s-deal-with-foxconn-is-the-worst-of-corporate-welfare|title=Wisconsin’s Deal With Foxconn Was as Bad as They Come|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bloomberg.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> The nonpartisan Wisconsin’s Legislative Fiscal Bureau estimated that the Foxconn plant would not break even on the investment until 2043, and that was in the best-case scenario.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/8/10/16125792/apple-foxconn-wisconsin-deal-jobs-profitable-2043|title=Wisconsin won’t break even on Foxconn plant deal for over two decades|work=The Verge|access-date=2018-11-03}}</ref> Others noted that Foxconn had in the past made similar claims about job creation in various localities which did not turn out to be true.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://money.cnn.com/2017/07/27/technology/business/foxconn-china-us-wisconsin-workers/|title=Foxconn invests in Wisconsin: Workers 'should be wary'|last=Griffiths|first=James|work=CNNMoney|access-date=2018-11-03}}</ref><ref name=":3" />
Foxconn sought to locate a plant in the Great Lakes region, because it need access to large amounts of water.<ref name=":3" /> The other Great Lakes states were not willing to offer as generous subsidies as Wisconsin.<ref name=":3" />
Initially, the subsidies were set at $3 billion, which would have cost the state $231,000 per job created (under the assumption of 13,000 jobs).<ref name=":4" /> The cost of the subsidies were higher than yearly state funding for the University of Wisconsin system and the state prisons.<ref name=":4" /> Other estimates of the subsidies go as high as $4.8 billion, which meant that the cost of the subsidy per job (assuming 13,000 jobs) was more than $346,000.<ref name=":2" /> Depending on how many jobs are created, the cost per job may go as high as more than a million dollars.<ref name=":5" />
Walker exempted the firm from Wisconsin's environmental rules regarding wetlands and streams.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://madison.com/wsj/news/local/govt-and-politics/broader-relaxation-of-environmental-rules-seen-coming-from-foxconn/article_2192c025-2984-5713-9463-7b4092e1dd09.html|title=Broader relaxation of environmental rules seen coming from Foxconn|author=Steven Verburg|work=Wisconsin State Journal|date=August 20, 2017}}</ref><ref name=":3" /> Walker and the Trump administration rolled back air pollution limits in the area of the plant, overruling objections of Environmental Protection Agency staff.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.apnews.com/8ac3c33e68274190a84b6154097c53e7|title=Illinois officials concerned over Foxconn plant impact|date=2018-06-13|work=AP NEWS|access-date=2018-11-03}}</ref> The plant was estimated to contribute significantly to air pollution in the region.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eu.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/2018/03/28/foxconn-industrial-operations-would-represent-major-new-source-air-pollution-region/461586002/|title=Foxconn industrial operations would represent a major new source of air pollution in region|work=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|access-date=2018-11-03}}</ref> Environmentalists criticized the decision to allow Foxconn to draw 7 million gallons of water per day from Lake Michigan.<ref name=":3" /> The roughly four square miles of land necessary for the Foxconn campus was in part made possible by forcing homeowners to sell at a fixed prize under the threat of seizing the land under eminent domain.<ref name=":5" />
In 2018, the Walker administration shifted up to $90 million in local road funding to road work related to the Foxconn factory.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eu.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/2018/02/28/wisconsin-shifting-up-90-million-local-road-funding-foxconn-related-projects/380750002/|title=Wisconsin is shifting up to $90 million in local road funding to Foxconn-related projects|work=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|access-date=2018-11-03}}</ref> The Wisconsin state legislature granted Foxconn special legal privileges within the Wisconsin judicial system.<ref name=":5" />
==2016 presidential campaign== [[File:Walker16 Flag.png|thumb|250px|Flag logo of Walker's campaign]] [[File:Governor of Wisconsin Scott Walker at Citizens United Freedom Summit in Greenville South Carolina May 2015 by Michael Vadon 09.jpg|thumb|Governor Walker at Citizens United Freedom Summit in [[South Carolina]]]] [[File:Governor of Wisconsin Scott Walker (and Scott Brown) at Seacoast Harley Davidson in North Hampton NH on July 16th 2015 by Michael Vadon 04.jpg|thumb|Governor Walker speaks in [[New Hampshire]]]] [[File:Scott Walker 2016 RNC.jpg|thumb|Walker speaking at the [[2016 Republican National Convention]]]] {{main|Scott Walker presidential campaign, 2016}} {{Further|United States presidential election, 2016}} In late January 2015, Walker set up a [[527 organization]] called "Our American Revival" to "help spread his message and underwrite his activities" which ''The Washington Post'' described as helpful for building the political and fundraising networks for a run for the presidency.<ref name="balz529">{{cite news|last1=Balz|first1=Dan|title=Scott Walker forms committee in preparation for 2016 presidential bid|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2015/01/27/scott-walker-forms-committee-in-preparation-for-2016-presidential-bid|accessdate=February 27, 2015|agency=''Washington Post''|date=January 27, 2015|work=The Washington Post}}</ref>
In February 2015, [[Trip Gabriel]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' described him as having "quickly vaulted into the top tier of likely candidates in the Republican presidential race".<ref name="nyt2-22-15">{{cite news|last1=Gabriel|first1=Trip|title=Scott Walker Hardens Tone on Social Issues to Woo Christian Conservatives|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/23/us/politics/scott-walker-hardens-tone-on-social-issues-to-woo-christian-conservatives.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&module=first-column-region&region=top-news&WT.nav=top-news&_r=0|accessdate=February 22, 2015|agency=New York Times|date=February 22, 2015|work=The New York Times}}</ref> On April 20, at a fundraising event for the New York State Republican Party, [[David Koch]] told donors that he and his brother, who oversee one of the biggest private political organizations in the country, believed that Walker would be the Republican nominee.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2015/04/20/koch-brothers-signal-support-for-scott-walker/?_r=0|title=Kochs Signal Support for Scott Walker|author=Nicholas Confessore|publisher=www.nytimes.com|date=April 20, 2015}}</ref>
Following a controversial statement by [[Rudy Giuliani]], Walker declined to answer the question of whether he believes [[Barack Obama|President Obama]] loves America or was a true Christian, stating that he did not know President Obama's patriotism was in doubt.<ref name="nyt2-22-15"/>
In June 2015, Walker took a further step towards a presidential campaign when he established a "testing-the-waters" federal campaign committee. This allowed him to raise federal campaign dollars as he explored a possible presidential run.<ref name="nbcnews1">{{cite web|last=Rafferty|first=Andrew|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/scott-walker-makes-another-move-towards-2016-run-n377641|title=Scott Walker Makes Another Move Towards 2016 Run|publisher=NBC News|date=June 18, 2015}}</ref>
In July 2015, after Walker aides said that he would soon announce his candidacy,<ref name="jsonline.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/scott-walker-set-to-file-papers-to-run-for-president-today-b99531061z1-311437521.html|title=Scott Walker files papers to run for president|author=Mary Spicuzza|work=jsonline.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/scott-walker-takes-first-steps-to-enter-2016-race|title=Election 2016: Scott Walker takes first steps to enter presidential race|date=July 2, 2015|work=cbsnews.com}}</ref> Walker announced his candidacy via social media.<ref name="twitter.com">{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/ScottWalker/status/620554821028876288|title=Scott Walker on Twitter|work=Twitter}}</ref>
As of August 18, 2015, Crowdpac ranked Walker as the fourth-most conservative candidate (following [[Rand Paul]], [[Ted Cruz]] and [[Ben Carson]]) for the 2016 presidential election based on an analysis of campaign donors.<ref>{{cite web|title=2016 Presidential Election|url=https://www.crowdpac.com/elections/2016-presidential-election|publisher=Crowdpac|date=August 18, 2015}}</ref> Based on an analysis including Crowdpac's rating, public statements by candidates on issues, and congressional voting (not applicable to Walker), [[FiveThirtyEight]] had ranked Walker the third-most conservative among candidates as of May 27, 2015.<ref>{{cite news|last=Enten|first=Harry|date=June 4, 2015|title=Rick Perry Fell Harder Than Anyone — And He's The First To Try Again|url=http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/rick-perry-fell-harder-than-anyone-and-hes-the-first-to-try-again/|publisher=FiveThirtyEight |access-date=July 20, 2015}}</ref>
Initially a front-runner in the race,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2015/02/23/2016-power-index-unsteady-walker-still-jebs-top-rival-but-press-pile-on.html|title=2016 Power Index: Unsteady Walker Still Jeb’s Top Rival, But Press Pile On Continues|first=Chris|last=Stirewalt|date=February 23, 2015|work=foxnews.com|accessdate=October 22, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=Walker takes the lead in GOP Race | url=http://www.publicpolicypolling.com/pdf/2015/PPP_Release_National_22415.pdf | date=February 24, 2015 | format=PDF | publisher=''[[Public Policy Polling]]'' | accessdate=October 22, 2016}}</ref> Walker saw a precipitous decline in both polling numbers and campaign funds.<ref name=BurnsHealy>{{cite news|last1=Burns|first1=Alexander|last2=Healy|first2=Patrick|title=Scott Walker Quits the 2016 Presidential Race|url=https://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2015/09/21/scott-walker-said-to-be-quitting-presidential-race/?_r=0|accessdate=September 21, 2015|publisher=New York Times|date=September 21, 2015}}</ref><ref name=Koren>{{cite news|last=Koren|first=Marina |title=Why Scott Walker Isn't Running Anymore |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2015/09/scott-walker-is-out/406564/ |accessdate=September 21, 2015 |publisher=Atlantic Monthly |date=September 21, 2015}}</ref> On September 21, 2015, Walker suspended his campaign and asked other candidates to do the same, so that the party could rally around a conservative alternate to Donald Trump.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/scott-walker-donald-trump-drop-out-speech-2015-9|title=Scott Walker unloads on Donald Trump while exiting the race|first1=Colin|last1=Campbell|work=Business Insider|date=September 21, 2015|accessdate=October 22, 2016}}</ref>
On March 29, 2016, Walker endorsed the candidacy of [[Ted Cruz]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/03/29/politics/scott-walker-endorsement-wisconsin-primary/index.html |title=Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker endorses Ted Cruz |last1=Scott |first1=Eugene |last2= |first2= |date=March 29, 2016 |website=CNN.com |publisher= |access-date=March 29, 2016 |quote=}}</ref> After Donald Trump became the presumptive nominee for the Republican Party in May 2016, Walker stated that he would support Trump as the Republican nominee, saying that Trump would make a better president than [[Hillary Clinton]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Collins |first=Eliza |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2016/05/04/scott-walker-bobby-jindal-kelly-ayotte-ari-fleischer-criticized-donald-trump/83928628/ |title=4 Republicans who say they'll now (reluctantly) back Trump |date=May 4, 2016 |work=USA TODAY |accessdate=June 9, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Wise |first=David |url=http://elections.wispolitics.com/2016/05/walker-cites-supreme-court-taxes.html |title=WisPolitics Election Blog: Walker cites Supreme Court, taxes, regulations in saying Trump would 'clearly' be better president than Clinton |work=WisPolitics.com |accessdate=June 9, 2016}}</ref> Walker withdrew his support for Trump on June 8, 2016 after Trump called the judge [[Gonzalo P. Curiel]] biased against Trump because of Curiel's Mexican heritage. While still maintaining that Trump would be better choice than Clinton, Walker noted that Trump is not yet the party's nominee and wanted Trump to renounce his comments on the judge before the [[2016 Republican National Convention]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Nelson |first=Louis |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/06/scott-walker-trump-endorsement-224059 |title=Walker backs away from endorsing Trump |work=Politico |date=June 8, 2016 |accessdate=June 9, 2016}}</ref>
Walker also prepped then-[[Indiana]] Governor and Republican Vice-Presidential Nominee [[Mike Pence]] for his debate against [[Virginia]] Senator and Democratic Vice-Presidential Nominee [[Tim Kaine]] on October 4, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/vice-presidential-candidates-prep-debate/story?id=42446291|title=VP Candidates Prep for Their Debate|first=Meghan|last=Keneally|date=September 30, 2016|work=ABC News|accessdate=October 22, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last1=Shih | first1=Adrienne | title=Gov. Scott Walker: Mike Pence Didn't 'Take the Bait' at Debate | url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/10/05/politics/scott-walker-mike-pence-debate/ | date=October 5, 2016 | publisher=[[CNN]] | accessdate=November 24, 2016}}</ref>
==Political positions==
===Abortion=== Throughout his life and career, Walker has had a strong and consistent position against abortion.<ref name="Remarkably"/><ref>{{cite web | title=Scott Walker Outlines Abortion, Gay Marriage Positions in Letter | url=http://archive.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/scott-walker-outlines-abortion-gay-marriage-positions-in-letter-b99375704z1-279975922.html | date=October 22, 2014 | publisher=''[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]'' (from the [[Associated Press]]) | accessdate=November 24, 2016}}</ref> In 2010 Walker told the editorial board of the ''[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]'' he opposed abortion, without exception for rape or incest.<ref name="even in"/><ref name="APoct22"/><ref name="nyt2-22-15"/><ref>{{cite news|magazine=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]|title=Scott Walker Wants to Totally Outlaw Abortion. In This Sneaky New Ad, He Pretends He Doesn't|first=Andy|last=Kroll|date=October 7, 2014|accessdate=May 12, 2015|url=https://www.motherjones.com/mojo/2014/10/scott-walker-wisconsin-governor-ban-abortion-rape-incest}}</ref> Regarding his stance on abortion, he has stated: "I don't apologize for that, but I don't focus on that; I don't obsess with it."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cook|first1=David|title=Gov. Scott Walker's position on abortion: 'I don't obsess with it'|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Politics/monitor_breakfast/2013/1202/Gov.-Scott-Walker-s-position-on-abortion-I-don-t-obsess-with-it|accessdate=May 22, 2015|agency=The Christian Science Monitor|date=December 2, 2013}}</ref> In a TV ad during his 2014 campaign for re-election Walker stated that he is "[[pro-life]]", and pointed to legislation he signed that leaves "the final decision to a woman and her doctor".<ref>{{cite web | title=Campaign 2014: Scott Walker 'Decision' | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/posttv/politics/campaign-2014-scott-walker-decision/2014/10/09/f30c8b3c-4fcb-11e4-877c-335b53ffe736_video.html | date=October 9, 2014 | newspaper=The Washington Post| accessdate=November 24, 2016}}</ref> In August 2015, he criticized the notion that abortion is necessary to save the life of the mother in certain cases, calling it a "false choice."<ref>{{cite web | last1=Spicuzza | first1=Mary | title=Scott Walker Calls Abortion to Save a Woman's Life a 'False Choice' | url=http://archive.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/scott-walker-calls-abortion-to-save-a-womans-life-a-false-choice-b99553080z1-321141741.html | date=August 8, 2015 | newspaper=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel}}</ref>
In an interview with the ''[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]'' a few weeks before the November 2014 election, Walker declined to answer directly when asked if abortion should be prohibited after 20 weeks.<ref name="nyt2-22-15"/> In July 2015, Walker signed a state law banning abortion after 20 weeks, including in cases of rape or incest but excluding when immediate danger existed to the life of the mother.<ref name="20WeekBan"/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Schleifer|first1=Theodore|title=Scott Walker: I would sign 20-week abortion ban|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/06/01/politics/scott-walker-abortion-ban-20-weeks/index.html|website=CNN|accessdate=June 2, 2015}}</ref>
===Economy and budget=== [[File:Scott Walker (16936089101).jpg|thumb|Governor Walker speaking at the Arizona Chamber of Commerce & Industry's Leadership Series luncheon in [[Phoenix, Arizona]]]] As Governor of Wisconsin, Walker has received grades of B in 2012<ref>{{cite web|last=Edwards|first=Chris|publisher=[[Cato Institute]]|url=http://object.cato.org/sites/cato.org/files/pubs/pdf/GRC2012.pdf|title=Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors 2012|date=October 9, 2012|accessdate=September 3, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Edwards|first=Chris|publisher=[[Cato Institute]]|url=http://www.cato.org/publications/white-paper/fiscal-policy-report-card-americas-governors-2012|title=Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors: 2012|date=October 9, 2012|accessdate=September 3, 2015}}</ref> and B in 2014<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kaeding|first1=Nicole|last2=Edwards|first2=Chris|publisher=[[Cato Institute]]|url=http://object.cato.org/sites/cato.org/files/pubs/pdf/fprc-on-americas-governors_1.pdf|title=Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors 2014|date=October 2, 2014|accessdate=September 3, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Kaeding|first1=Nicole|last2=Edwards|first2=Chris|publisher=[[Cato Institute]]|url=http://www.cato.org/publications/white-paper/fiscal-policy-report-card-americas-governors-2014|title=Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors 2014|date=October 2, 2014|accessdate=September 3, 2015}}</ref> from the [[Cato Institute]], a [[Libertarianism in the United States|libertarian]] think tank, in their biennial Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors.
===Education=== Walker moved to weaken [[tenure]] for professors at the [[University of Wisconsin]] and to cut its funding, while offering authority to reduce spending.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bauer|first1=Scott|title=Walker proposes 13% cut, more freedom for UW System|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/education/walker-proposes-13-cut-more-freedom-for-uw-system-b99433644z1-289880441.html|accessdate=5 November 2015|publisher=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|date=January 27, 2015}}</ref> He recommended deleting parts of the system's mission that contribute to the [[Wisconsin Idea]]. Parts of the mission proposed for deletion, such as the "search for truth," were to be replaced with a directive "to meet the state's workforce needs." Walker later called the change a "drafting error," but public records requests and litigation showed that Walker himself and his office were "the driving force" behind the changes.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Marley|first1=Patrick|last2=Stein|first2=Jason|title=Records: Scott Walker wanted Wisconsin Idea changes|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/judge-orders-scott-walker-to-release-emails-on-wisconsin-idea-b99733921z1-381151041.html|accessdate=July 5, 2016|work=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|date=May 27, 2016}}</ref> He supports the public funding of private schools and religious schools in the form of vouchers for students. He supports the increased availability of [[Charter schools in the United States|charter schools]].<ref name=wp713>{{cite news|last1=Strauss|first1=Valerie|title=Gov. Scott Walker savages Wisconsin public education in new budget|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/answer-sheet/wp/2015/07/13/gov-scott-walker-savages-wisconsin-public-education-in-new-budget|website=The Washington Post|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=July 15, 2015|date=July 13, 2015}}</ref>
===Environment=== Walker signed a "No Climate Tax" pledge promising not to support any legislation that would raise taxes to [[Climate change mitigation|combat climate change]] and has been a keynote speaker at the [[Heartland Institute]], which promotes [[climate change denial]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Waldmann|first1=Paul|title=Where the 2016 GOP contenders stand on climate change|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/plum-line/wp/2014/05/12/where-the-2016-gop-contenders-stand-on-climate-change|accessdate=April 27, 2015|publisher=Washington Post|date=May 12, 2014}}</ref> He proposed funding cuts for clean energy and other environmental programs. He has proposed giving many powers of the Environmental Protection Agency to the states. He opposed the Obama administration's efforts to reduce [[carbon emissions]].<ref name=nyt713/>
===Foreign policy=== [[File:U.S. Governor of Wisconsin Scott Walker in 2011 at troop send-off which will arrive in Kosovo to participate in the NATO-led peacekeeping mission.jpg|thumb|Walker in 2011, speaking to troops who will participate in the [[Kosovo Force|NATO-led peacekeeping mission in Kosovo]]]] [[File:U.S. Governor of Wisconsin Scott Walker speaking at the Chatham House in London, UK in 2015.jpg|thumb|Governor Walker speaking at the [[Chatham House]] in [[London]] in 2015]] In 2015, Walker indicated that he favored providing arms to Ukraine to fight [[War in Donbass|Russian-backed separatists]] in that country.<ref name=nyt713/>
In 2015, Walker stated in an interview with [[Charlie Sykes]] that if elected president, he would "absolutely" decide on his first day in office to "cancel [[Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action|any Iranian deal the Obama administration makes]]," even if European allies which were also party to an agreement opted not to reimpose [[Sanctions against Iran|sanctions]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/plum-line/wp/2015/04/02/scott-walker-ill-blow-up-any-iran-deal-no-matter-what-our-european-allies-think|title=Scott Walker: I'll blow up any Iran deal, no matter what our European allies think|last1=Sargent|first1=Greg|date=April 2, 2015|newspaper=Washington Post|accessdate=April 2, 2015}}</ref>
In 2015, while campaigning for the Republican presidential nomination, Walker faulted Obama for lack of strategy in dealing with the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] group,<ref name=nyt713>{{cite news|last1=Mullany|first1=Gerry|title=Scott Walker on the issues|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/14/us/politics/scott-walker-on-the-issues.html|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=July 13, 2015|date=July 13, 2015}}</ref> and did not rule out sending U.S. troops to Syria to engage in ground combat with ISIL there.<ref name=nyt713/> In February 2015, when asked about the [[Syrian civil war|war in Syria]], Walker said that the U.S. should "go beyond just aggressive air strikes. We have to look at other surgical methods. And ultimately, we have to be prepared to put boots on the ground if that's what it takes."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Friedersdorf|first1=Conor|title=Scott Walker's Naive Foreign-Policy Beliefs|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2015/02/scott-walkers-naive-foreign-policy-beliefs/385104|website=The Atlantic|publisher=The Atlantic Monthly Group|accessdate=July 9, 2015}}</ref>
In a 2015 interview, Walker said that "the most significant foreign policy decision" of his lifetime was President [[Ronald Reagan]]'s [[1981 air traffic controllers strike|firing 11,000 striking air traffic controllers]] in 1981, saying: "It sent a message not only across America, it sent a message around the world ... [that] we weren't to be messed with."<ref name=politico20150306>{{cite news|title=Scott Walker takes on unions again|first=Brian|last=Mahoney|date=March 6, 2015|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/03/scott-walker-takes-on-unions-again-115808.html|accessdate=May 12, 2015|publisher=[[Politico]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|title=Scott Walker calls Reagan's bust of air traffic controller strike 'most significant foreign policy decision'|first=Philip|last=Rucker|date=February 28, 2015|accessdate=May 12, 2015|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2015/02/28/scott-walker-calls-reagans-bust-of-air-traffic-controller-strike-most-significant-foreign-policy-decision}}</ref>
In 2015, Walker opposed [[Cuban Thaw|rapprochement in relations between the U.S. and Cuba]].<ref name=nyt713/>
===Guns=== Walker has been strongly in favor of [[Gun politics in the United States|gun rights]]. In July 2011, he signed a bill into law making Wisconsin the 49th [[Concealed carry in the United States|concealed carry]] state in the United States,<ref>{{cite web | last1=Stein | first1=Jason | title=Walker Signs Concealed-Carry Measure Into Law | url=http://archive.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/125235719.html | date=July 8, 2011|newspaper=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel}}</ref> and on December 7 of that same year he signed the [[castle doctrine]] into law.<ref>{{cite web | last1=Stein | first1=Jason | title=Walker Signs 'Castle Doctrine' Bill, Other Measures | url=http://archive.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/walker-to-sign-castle-doctrine-bill-wednesday-bh3brej-135197918.html | date=December 7, 2011 | publisher=''[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]'' | accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref> In January and April 2015 speeches in Iowa, Walker included passing those laws among his accomplishments.<ref name=fox20150127>{{cite news|title=Our American Revival: Gov. Scott Walker wades into the presidential campaign waters|date=January 27, 2015|first=Derica|last=Williams|accessdate=May 12, 2015|url=http://fox6now.com/2015/01/27/governor-scott-walker-creates-new-pac-ahead-of-2016|publisher=[[Fox News]]}}</ref><ref name=cspan20150425>{{cite AV media|publisher=[[C-SPAN]]|title=Iowa Faith and Freedom Coalition Summit|url=http://www.c-span.org/video/?325573-1/iowa-faith-freedom-coalition-summit|date=April 25, 2015|accessdate=May 12, 2015|location=[[Waukee, Iowa]]}}</ref>
The [[National Rifle Association]] gave Walker a 100% ranking in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Scott Kevin Walker's Ratings and Endorsemens|url=https://votesmart.org/candidate/evaluations/3552/scott-walker#.VT2WUiFViko|website=VoteSmart|accessdate=April 27, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=NRA Endorses Scott Walker for Governor in Wisconsin | url=https://www.nrapvf.org/articles/20140922/nra-endorses-scott-walker-for-governor-in-wisconsin | date=September 22, 2014 | publisher=NRA-PVF| accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref>
On June 24, 2015, Walker signed two bills into law, one which removed the state's 48-hour waiting period for buying a gun and another which gave retired or off-duty police officers the legal right to carry concealed guns in public schools.<ref>{{cite web | last1=Strauss | first1=Daniel | title=Scott Walker Signs Two Pro-Gun Bills | url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/06/scott-walker-two-gun-bills-119380 | date=June 24, 2015 | newspaper=Politico| accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref>
===Health care=== Walker opposes the Affordable Care Act (ACA or "Obamacare") and has signed Wisconsin onto a lawsuit seeking to have the ACA rolled back (including provisions for preexisting conditions).<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.politifact.com/wisconsin/statements/2018/oct/18/tony-evers/scott-walker-says-he-would-cover-pre-existing-cond/|title=Scott Walker backs plans to end pre-existing protections?|work=PolitiFact|date=October 18, 2018|author=Tom Kertscher}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-na-pol-republicans-medicaid-20181101-story.html|title=Republican candidates say they would protect sick Americans but fight coverage for poorest patients |last=Levey|first=Noam N.|website=Los Angeles Times|date=November 1, 2018}}</ref> He supported the [[Graham–Cassidy health care amendment|Graham-Cassidy legislation]] to repeal the ACA; this repeal bill would have eliminated blanket protections for preexisting conditions.<ref name=":0" /> In 2018, Walker pledged to pass legislation to protect individuals with preexisting conditions in case the Affordable Care Act were repealed; according to PolitiFact, "he hasn’t spelled out an alternative that would provide protections that Obamacare does."<ref name=":0" /> As Governor, he has blocked [[Medicaid expansion|expansion of Medicaid]] in Wisconsin.<ref name=":1" />
===Immigration===
====Illegal immigration==== Walker has stated that securing the United States border with Mexico is "our first priority". After that, [[illegal immigrants in the United States]] could "secure their citizenship" but would have to "get in the back of line", and wait like anyone else applying for citizenship.<ref name="immigration">[http://www.cnn.com/2015/03/26/politics/election-2016-scott-walker-immigration/index.html Scott Walker comments on immigration], cnn.com; accessed April 10, 2015.</ref> Walker says that he does not advocate deportation for all people in the country illegally, but he is not in favor of amnesty.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/updates/scott-walker-believe-candidate-stands-10-issues|title=What does Scott Walker believe? Where the candidate stands on 10 issues|publisher=Pbs.org|date=July 13, 2015|accessdate=July 27, 2015}}</ref>
In a 2015 appearance on ''[[Meet the Press]]'', Walker said proposals to build a wall along the {{convert|5525|mi|km|abbr=on}} [[Canada–United States border]] was "a legitimate issue for us to look at."<ref>Walker quickly switched the subject to the Middle East, rebuilding the military, and national security. The exchange about Canada never even made it to air. It was edited out of the interview highlights that ran on ''Meet The Press'', and was posted on NBC's website.</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Bradner|first=Eric|title=Scott Walker: U.S.-Canada Wall a 'legitimate' Idea|publisher=CNN|date=August 30, 2015|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/08/30/politics/scott-walker-northern-border-immigration-2016}}</ref>
====Legal immigration==== Walker has stated that he would work to "protect American workers" by aligning his position with Sen. [[Jeff Sessions]] (R-AL), who wrote in a ''[[Washington Post]]'' op-ed that legal immigration needs to be "slowed".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/slow-the-immigration-wave/2015/04/09/c6d8e3d4-dd52-11e4-a500-1c5bb1d8ff6a_story.html|title=America needs to curb immigration flows|website=washingtonpost.com|date=April 21, 2015|first=Jeff|last=Sessions}}</ref>
===Role of government=== [[File:Governor Scott Walker of Wisconsin at Southern Republican Leadership Conference in Oklahoma City, OK May 2015 by Michael Vadon 06.jpg|thumb|Governor Walker at 2015 [[Southern Republican Leadership Conference]] in [[Oklahoma City, OK]]]] Walker stated in an OP-ED in the Washington Post "Like most Americans, I think government is too big and too expansive, but the government that is necessary should work — and work well."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Walker|first1=Scott|title=Scott Walker: What Wisconsin can teach Washington|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/scott-walker-what-wisconsin-can-teach-washington/2013/10/08/95e3efb0-3030-11e3-9ccc-2252bdb14df5_story.html|accessdate=May 6, 2015|publisher=Washington Post|date=October 18, 2012}}</ref>
===Same-sex marriage=== Walker says he believes in "marriage between one man and one woman".<ref name=nyt713/> Walker voted for Wisconsin's constitutional amendment to ban [[same-sex marriage]], both as a legislator and as a voter.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Washington Blade]]|date=April 30, 2015|first=Chris|last=Johnson|title=Walker calls for federal amendment against same-sex marriage|url=http://www.washingtonblade.com/2015/04/30/walker-calls-for-fedl-amendment-against-same-sex-marriage|accessdate=May 12, 2015}}</ref><ref name=politico20150426>{{cite news|title=In Iowa, GOP field stresses opposition to same-sex marriage|first=James|last=Hohmann|date=April 26, 2015|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/04/iowa-faith-freedom-summit-2015-117346.html|accessdate=May 12, 2015|publisher=[[Politico]]}}</ref> In September 2014, Walker said he was defending the amendment.<ref name="APoct22"/> When the U.S. Supreme Court subsequently rejected the appeals of five states, including Wisconsin, in October 2014, allowing same-sex marriages to continue, Walker stated: "I think it's resolved."<ref>[http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/gay-marriages-to-resume-in-wisconsin-as-supreme-court-rejects-appeals-b99365650z1-278229621.html Gay marriages to resume in Wisconsin as US Supreme Court rejects appeal], jsonline.com; accessed March 13, 2015.</ref> In April 2015, in [[New Hampshire]], Walker stated that marriage is "defined as between a man and a woman",<ref>{{cite news|title=Same-sex marriage debate forces GOP contenders to tread carefully|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/same-sex-marriage-snarls-gop-contenders/2015/04/24/6b5a8d18-ea8c-11e4-9767-6276fc9b0ada_story.html|first1=Sandhya|last1=Somashekhar|first2=Robert|last2=Costa|date=April 24, 2015|accessdate=May 12, 2015|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]}}</ref> and in Iowa said a federal constitutional amendment allowing states to define marriage was reasonable.<ref name=politico20150426/> Walker called the U.S. Supreme Court's ''[[Obergefell v. Hodges]]'' decision to legalize same-sex marriage nationwide a "grave mistake".<ref>{{cite news|last1=The Associated Press|title=Walker calls gay marriage ruling 'grave mistake'|url=http://www.channel3000.com/news/politics/walker-has-long-opposed-samesex-marriage/33789126|website=channel3000.com|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=June 27, 2015|date=June 26, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150628143110/http://www.channel3000.com/news/politics/walker-has-long-opposed-samesex-marriage/33789126|archivedate=June 28, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Unions=== Walker said public-union collective-bargaining rights frustrate balancing the state budget.<ref name="fox20120511"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://host.madison.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/with-dues-depleted-wisconsin-s-three-afscme-councils-merge/article_136e2e6e-c63a-503b-8aa5-ad4586ba9e1d.html|date=May 1, 2015|first=Steven|last=Verburg|newspaper=Wisconsin State Journal|accessdate=May 12, 2015|title=With dues depleted, Wisconsin's three AFSCME councils merge}}</ref> Walker signed right-to-work legislation he said would contribute to economic growth.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[NBC News]]|title=Scott Walker Signs Anti-Union Bill|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/wisconsin-gov-scott-walker-signs-right-work-bill-n319941|first=Leigh Ann|last=Caldwell|date=March 9, 2015|accessdate=May 12, 2015}}</ref> ''[[The Atlantic]]'' has written that "anti-union politics" have defined his tenure as governor and established him as a Republican presidential contender.<ref name=atlantic20150309>{{cite news|title=Scott Walker, Anti-Union Man|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2015/03/scott-walker-anti-union-man/387283|accessdate=May 12, 2015|first=Russell|last=Berman|date=March 9, 2015|magazine=[[The Atlantic]]}}</ref> ''[[Politico]]'' wrote that Walker initiated a 21st-century revival of anti-union legislation in upper Midwestern industrial states and that his "fervent anti-union rhetoric and actions" has helped his national reputation within the Republican Party.<ref name="politico20150306"/>
===Youth rights=== On May 24, 2017, Walker signed a bill that allowed unaccompanied [[minor (law)|minors]] to attend [[concert]]s and other musical festivals where [[alcohol]] is being served.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fox6now.com/2017/05/24/gov-scott-walker-signs-bill-allowing-minors-at-music-festivals/?fref=gc|title=Gov. Scott Walker signs bill allowing minors at music festivals|date=May 24, 2017|publisher=}}</ref> On June 21, 2017, he signed into law a bill that allowed 16- and 17-year-olds to work without [[work permit|parental permission]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fox6now.com/2017/06/21/gov-walker-approves-ending-work-permits-for-16-17-year-olds/?fref=gc|title=Gov. Walker approves ending work permits for 16-, 17-year-olds|date=June 22, 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
==Personal life== [[File:Scott Walker hugs wife Tonette at 2016 Presidential announcement.jpg|thumb|right|Walker embraces his wife Tonette during his [[Scott Walker presidential campaign, 2016|2016 presidential campaign]] announcement with their sons present]] Walker and his wife [[Tonette Walker|Tonette]] have two sons, Matt (born 1994) and Alex.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bash|first1=Dana|title=Sons of Gov Scott Walker, Alex and Matt Walker disagree with their father on same-sex marriage and more|url=http://cnnpressroom.blogs.cnn.com/2015/07/12/sons-of-gov-scott-walker-alex-and-matt-walker-disagreeing-with-their-father-on-same-sex-marriage-and-more|work=CNN's State of the Union|date=July 12, 2015}}</ref> Walker's wife and sons disagree with him on certain political and religious issues.<ref>{{cite web | last1=Jordan | first1=Mary | title=Scott Walker’s wife, toughened by life, is ready for fires of a campaign | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/scott-walkers-wife-toughened-by-life-adds-steel-to-the-gop-candidates-spine/2015/07/05/61337f5d-2513-4698-8f27-647e28b3c8cc_story.html | date=July 5, 2015 | publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]'' | accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref>
The family attends Meadowbrook Church, a nondenominational, evangelical church in [[Wauwatosa, Wisconsin|Wauwatosa]], which is a daughter church of [[Elmbrook Church]], in nearby [[Brookfield, Wisconsin|Brookfield]].<ref name="prayer breakfast"/><ref name="first lady"/> Tonette Walker works in the development department for the [[American Lung Association]].<ref>{{cite web|title=About First Lady Walker|publisher=Wisconsin Government|url=http://firstlady.wi.gov/about-first-lady-walker|accessdate=March 3, 2015}}</ref><ref name="is married"/>
During the summers of 2004 through 2009, as Milwaukee County Executive, Walker led a motorcycle tour called the "Executive's Ride" through Wisconsin and parts of neighboring states. The ride was organized to attract people to [[Milwaukee County]].<ref name="harley"/> Walker rides a 2003 [[Harley Davidson]] [[Harley-Davidson FL|Road King]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Steve|first1=Schultze|title=Walker hits the road on his own Harley|url=http://www.jsonline.com/blogs/news/43346517.html|accessdate=November 11, 2014|newspaper=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|date=April 21, 2009}}</ref>
In 2013, Walker published ''Unintimidated – A Governor's Story and A Nation's Challenge'', co-written with [[Marc Thiessen]], about his experiences during the recall vote and subsequent election, both of which he won.<ref>[http://www.fox11online.com/news/wisconsin/gov-scott-walkers-new-book-criticizes-mitt-romneys-2012-presidential-campaign Walker's new book criticizes Romney] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019125457/http://www.fox11online.com/news/wisconsin/gov-scott-walkers-new-book-criticizes-mitt-romneys-2012-presidential-campaign |date=October 19, 2013 }}, fox11online.com; accessed January 28, 2014.</ref>

[[File:Matilda_"Tillie"_Kinnon_Paul_Tamaree.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Matilda_%22Tillie%22_Kinnon_Paul_Tamaree.jpg|thumb|Tillie Paul]] '''Tillie Paul''' (January 18, 1863 – August 20, 1952) was a [[Tlingit]] [[translator]], [[Civil rights history|civil rights advocate]], [[educator]], and [[Presbyterianism|Presbyterian]] church elder.
==Early life and education== Matilda Kinnon was born in [[Victoria, British Columbia]], the younger daughter of a Tlingit mother named Kut-XooX, and a [[Scotland|Scottish]] father named James Kinnon, who was employed by the [[Hudson's Bay Company]].<ref name="Jones2">Cherry Lyon Jones, [https://books.google.com/books?id=pWK9AgAAQBAJ&lpg=PA20&ots=d-URRZeb0s&dq=Matilda%20Kinnon%20Paul&pg=PA11#v=onepage "Matilda Kinnon 'Tillie' Paul Tamaree"] in ''More Than Petticoats: Remarkable Alaska Women'' (Globe Pequot 2014): 11-20. {{ISBN|9780762774302}}</ref> When her mother fell ill with [[tuberculosis]], she arranged to bring Tillie and her sister north to be raised by Tlingit relatives. Aided by a clansman, Kut-Xoox traveled by canoe with her two daughters along the [[Inside Passage]], a journey of 600 miles. After her mother's death, young Tillie was raised by a maternal aunt, Xoon-sel-ut, and her uncle, Chief Snook of the [[Naanya.aayi]], a clan of the [[Stikeen-quann]], near [[Wrangell, Alaska]]. Her adoptive family gave her the name Kah-thli-yudt, soon shortened to "Kah-tah-ah."<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Haa k̲usteeyí, our culture : Tlingit life stories|last=Dauenhauer, Nora Marks and Richard Dauenhauer, eds.|first=|publisher=University of Washington Press|year=1994|isbn=0295974001|location=Juneau, Alaska|pages=}}</ref>
Tillie lived in Wrangell until she was 12 years old, when she received a marriage proposal from a Christian [[Tsimshian|Tsimishian]] chief, Abraham Lincoln.<ref name="Jones2" /> Her uncle consented to the marriage, but Tillie was ambivalent. They arranged that she would travel south to Lincoln's home in [[Prince Rupert, British Columbia]] with the understanding that no marriage would take place against her will. After her decision not to marry, when she was no longer under the care of the Tsimishian, she went to live with a Methodist minister and his wife, missionaries at [[Lax Kw'alaams|Port Simpson]], British Columbia. There, she relearned English and was schooled in Christian worship.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Wise women: from Pocahontas to Sarah Winnemucca, remarkable stories of Native American trailblazers|last=Turner, Erin, ed.|first=|publisher=TwoDot|year=2009|isbn=9780762755387|location=Guilford, CT|pages=}}</ref>
Her family arranged for her return to Wrangell and she was admitted to [[Amanda McFarland|Amanda McFarland's]] Presbyterian Home and School for Girls, where she started using the name "Tillie Kinnon." <ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title="Female Native Teachers in Southeast Alaska: Sarah Dickinson, Tillie Paul, and Frances Willard," in Margaret Connell Szasz, ed., Between Indian and White Worlds|last=Wyatt|first=Victoria|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|year=1994|isbn=0806133856|location=|pages=}}</ref>
== Teaching and missionary work == While at the McFarland School, Tillie worked as an interpreter for clergyman [[S. Hall Young]] in and around Wrangell. She married Louis Francis Paul and in 1882 the two became the first Native couple to be commissioned by the [[Presbyterian Board of Home Missions]] to found a new missionary school. Located in [[Klukwan, Alaska|Klukwan, Alaska,]] the school served 64 men and women; Tillie and her husband visited homes three times a week, sharing just twelve textbooks among their students. The couple opened a second school in the [[Tongass National Forest|Tongass]] region of Alaska, where Paul's family lived.<ref name=":0" /> Paul died in 1886, presumably drowned while scouting for a new school location. However, a contemporary biographer of Tillie Paul's, [[Mary Lee Davis House|Mary Lee Davis]], suggests that his death was a suspicious one.<ref>{{Cite book|title=We Are Alaskans|last=Davis|first=Mary (Caldwell)|publisher=W. A. Wilde Co.|year=1931|isbn=|location=Boston|pages=257}}</ref>
Paul's death left Tillie with three young sons to care for on her own. She moved to [[Sitka, Alaska]] to work at [[Sheldon Jackson College|Sitka Industrial Training School,]] invited by [[Sheldon Jackson]], a missionary and the General Agent of Education for the [[Territory of Alaska|Alaskan Territory]]. There, she performed a range of tasks, acting as an interpreter, supervising sewing classes, serving as a nurse in the boy's hospital ward, and eventually becoming matron of the girl's dormitory.<ref name=":22">{{Cite book|title=Haa k̲usteeyí, our culture : Tlingit life stories|last=Dauenhauer, Nora Marks and Richard Dauenhauer, eds.|first=|publisher=University of Washington Press|year=1994|isbn=0295974001|location=Juneau, Alaska|pages=}}</ref>
During her years in Sitka, she worked with a fellow teacher, [[Fanny Willard]], to create a writing system for Tlingit language and together they compiled a Tlingit dictionary.<ref name=":0" /> She published several articles about Tlingit culture in the Presbyterian newspaper, ''The North Star''<ref name=":0" /> and lectured on Tlingit culture in Sitka as a member of the Society of Alaskan Natural History and Ethnology.<ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3761386/tillie_paul_donated_baskets_to_sheldon/ "Tlingit Baskets to be Displayed"] ''Sitka Daily Sentinel'' (March 7, 1997): 6. via [[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}}</ref> Tillie also learned to play the organ, becoming proficient enough to accompany school and church events. Some of her translated hymns and prayers are still in use among Tlingit Christians today.<ref name=":0" />
Tillie traveled on behalf of the Presbyterian Church, attending its General Assembly in New York City at least twice. In 1902, she was invited to address the Assembly on the subject of women's role in the church.<ref name="Jones2" />
In 1931, Tillie Paul was the first woman ordained as an elder in the [[Alaska Northwest Synod]] of the Presbyterian Church, in the first year that Presbyterian women could be so ordained.<ref name="Jones2" />
== Civil rights advocacy == [[File:Tillie Paul and her son William.jpg|thumb|Tillie Paul and her son William]] In 1905, Tillie founded the New Covenant Legion, a Christian temperance organization intended to reach Native communities considered especially at risk from alcohol abuse, with George Beck, a student at the Sitka school. The New Covenant Legion in turn became the [[Alaska Native Brotherhood/Sisterhood|Alaska Native Brotherhood]] (ANB) and Alaska Native Sisterhood, the first advocacy organizations for [[Alaska Natives|Alaska Native]] rights. Tillie's sons, [[William Paul (attorney)|William Paul]] and Louis Paul, were leaders in the ANB as were many of the students Tillie taught at the Sitka school. While her sons are generally given credit for transforming the ANB from a service organization to a political one, Tillie's influence in shaping these leaders was recognized by her contemporaries.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Cultural Politics and the Mass Media: Alaska Native Voices|last=Daley, Patrick J. and Beverly A. James|first=|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=2004|isbn=0252029380|location=Urbana, Illinois|pages=}}</ref>
In November 1922, Tillie assisted a Tlingit relative, Charlie Jones, to vote, after he was refused by election officials in Wrangell. Both were charged with felonies: Charlie Jones for "falsely swearing to be a citizen" and voting illegally and Tillie for aiding and abetting him.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sitnews.us/Kiffer/WilliamLewisPaul/021609_william_paul.html|title=William Paul Was The "Father of Native Land Claims"|last=Kiffer|first=Dave|date=February 16, 2009|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Her son William, by this time an attorney, defended them both at a trial that took place in [[Ketchikan, Alaska]] in 1923. The case hinged on the definition of Native citizenship, which, until 1915, had been determined by the [[Dawes Act|Dawes Act of 1887]]. That act required Native people to sever tribal ties in order to be recognized as citizens. By 1915, the Alaska Territory had passed the [[Alaska Citizenship Act of 1915|Alaska Citizenship Act.]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://library.alaska.gov/hist/fulltext/ASL-KFA-1225.A3-1915.htm|title=1915 Alaska Citizenship Act|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> It only recognized Native people as citizens under strict conditions, including the endorsement of at least five white citizens, certain testing requirements, as well as proof that they had "adopted the habits of civilization." <ref>{{Cite book|title=The Battle Over Bilingual Ballots: Language Minorities and Political Access|last=Tucker|first=James Thomas|publisher=Routledge|year=2016|isbn=0754675726|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> William Paul argued that Jones fulfilled the requirements of citizenship under Dawes, insofar as he owned a house, paid taxes, made charitable contributions, and, generally "lived like a white person." Judge Thomas Reed ruled that Dawes preempted the 1915 Citizenship Act. Effectively, this meant that the territorial government could not add procedures such as endorsement by white citizens, testing, or obtaining a certificate of citizenship if the requirements for citizenship under Dawes were met. Tillie Paul Tamaree and Charlie Jones were acquitted.<ref name=":1" />
In his ruling, Judge Reed wrote that "if you find that the defendant Charley (sic) Jones was born within the limits of the United States, then you must conclude that the said Charley Jones was born under and within the terms of the [[Citizenship Clause|1st Section of the 14th Amendment]]." In 1924, the [[Indian Citizenship Act]] conferred citizenship on all Native Americans born within the United States and its territories, extending the franchise, but not completely eradicating further attempts to limit Native American's right to vote.<ref>Peter Metcalfe, [https://books.google.com/books?id=83v8CAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA22&dq=Tillie%20Paul%20Tamaree&pg=PA20#v=onepage&q=Tillie%20Paul%20Tamaree&f=false ''A Dangerous Idea: The Alaska Native Brotherhood and the Struggle for Indigenous Rights''] (University of Alaska Press 2014): 20. {{ISBN|9781602232402}}</ref><ref>Amy Fletcher, [http://juneauempire.com/art/2015-05-13/breathing-life-history-locals-gather-remember-tlingit-civil-rights-hero-william-paul "Tlingit Civil Rights Hero William Paul Sr. Remembered"] ''Juneau Empire'' (May 12, 2015).</ref>
==Personal life and legacy== [[File:Tille Paul Manor.jpg|thumb|Tillie Paul Manor]] In 1882, Tillie Kinnon married Louis Francis Paul, with whom she had three sons.<ref name="Jones2" />
In 1887, Tille was widowed.<ref name="Jones2" />
In 1905, Tillied married again to William Tamaree, with whom she had three daughters.<ref name="Jones2" />
In 1924, Tillie's son, William became the first Alaska Native elected to the territorial legislature.<ref>Finding aid, [http://archiveswest.orbiscascade.org/ark:/80444/xv32848 William Lewis Paul Papers], University of Washington Libraries, Special Collections.</ref>
In 1952, Tillie Paul died at a hospital in Wrangell, age 90.
In 1979, an infirmary building on the campus of Sheldon Jackson College was named for Tillie Paul.<ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3761301/campus_building_named_for_tillie_paul/ "SJ Names Place to Honor Tlingit Woman, Tillie Paul"] ''Daily Sitka Sentinel'' (October 19, 1979): 5. via [[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}}</ref>
In 1997, her daughter-in-law, Frances Lackey Paul, published a children's book, Kahtahah, based on her mother-in-law's early life.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Kahtahah-Frances-Lackey-Paul/dp/0882400584|title=Kahtahah, Frances Lackey Paul|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
In 2001, the Sheldon Jackson School was designated a [[National Historic Landmark]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/places/sheldon-jackson-school.htm|title=Sheldon Jackson School National Historic Landmark|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
In 2015, Tillie Paul's great-granddaughter, Debra O'Gara, was named Tribal Court Presiding Judge by the Central Council of the Tlingit and Haida Indian Tribes of Alaska.<ref>Raeanne Holmes, [http://alaska-native-news.com/debra-ogara-hired-as-tribal-court-presiding-judge-19869 "Debra O'Gara Hired as Tribal Court Presiding Judge"] ''Alaska Native News'' (October 29, 2015).</ref>

{{Infobox scientist |name = Walter J. Kauzmann |image = |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date|1916|8|18|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Mount Vernon, New York]], U.S. |residence = |nationality = American |death_date = {{death date and age|2009|1|27|1916|8|18}} |death_place = [[Montgomery, New Jersey]], U.S. |field = [[Chemist]] |work_institution = [[Princeton University]] |alma_mater = [[Cornell University]] (B.A.), Princeton University (Ph.D.) |doctoral_advisor = [[Henry Eyring (chemist)|Henry Eyring]] |known_for = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = }}
'''Walter J. Kauzmann''' (18 August 1916 – 27 January 2009) was an [[United States|American]] [[chemist]] and professor emeritus of [[Princeton University]]. He was noted for his work in both [[physical chemistry]] and [[biochemistry]]. His most important contribution was recognizing that the [[hydrophobic effect]] plays a key role in determining the three-dimensional [[Protein structure|structure of proteins]].<ref name = "Hydrophobic_effect">Walter Kauzmann, Some Factors in the Interpretation of Protein Denaturation, ''Advances in Protein Chemistry'' (1959) Vol. 14, pgs 1–63.</ref> He is also well known for an insight into the nature of [[supercooled liquid]]s which is now known as [[Glass transition#Kauzmann's paradox|Kauzmann's paradox]].<ref name = "Kauzmann_Paradox">[Walter Kauzmann, The Nature of the Glassy State and the Behavior of Liquids at Low Temperatures, Chemical Reviews (1948), Vol 43, pg. 219.]</ref> At Princeton, Kauzmann was the David B. Jones Professor Emeritus of Chemistry. He chaired the Department of Chemistry from 1964 to 1968 and the Department of Biochemical Sciences from 1980 to 1981.
He was born in [[Mount Vernon, New York]] and grew up in [[New Rochelle, New York]]. He was the son of the German-born Albert F. Kauzmann, who came to the United States in 1895, and Julia (Kahle) Kauzmann. Albert operated a gem-importing business in [[Lower Manhattan]] and would often bring his son to work on Saturday mornings. They would spend the afternoon at the [[American Museum of Natural History]] or attend a matinee at the [[Metropolitan Opera]], nurturing Walter's lifelong love of science and music.
Kauzmann earned a B.A. degree in 1937 from [[Cornell University]], which he attended on a full scholarship. He started his doctoral work at Princeton University in [[organic chemistry]], but switched to physical chemistry, earning a Ph.D. in 1940 under the direction of [[Henry Eyring (chemist)|Henry Eyring]]. Following his Ph.D., Kauzmann had a two-year postdoctoral appointment in Pittsburgh as a Westinghouse Research Fellow, in the laboratory led by [[Edward U. Condon]]. It was during this period that Kauzmann wrote his now classic paper on supercooled liquids and glasses that contained the Kauzmann paradox.<ref name = "Kauzmann_Paradox" /> At the end of this fellowship, with the U.S. fighting [[Second World War|WWII]], Kauzmann joined the U.S. government's National Defense Research Council laboratory in [[Bruceton, Pennsylvania]], which was directed by [[George Kistiakowsky]], and worked on [[chemical explosive]]s.
In 1944, Kauzmann was recruited into the top secret [[Manhattan Project]] and he moved to [[Los Alamos, New Mexico]]. Eventually, Kauzmann was put in charge of producing the detonator for the [[Trinity test]], which was the first detonation of an [[atomic bomb]], and of the ([[Fat Man]]) plutonium bomb that was dropped on [[Nagasaki, Japan]]. Kauzmann witnessed the Trinity test on July 16, 1945, and his memories were recorded in a newspaper article.<ref>[http://www.capitalcentury.com/1944.html Jon Blackwell, 1944: Brain power into nuclear power, ''The Trentonian'']</ref> Fifty years later, Kauzmann discussed why he worked on the atomic bomb:
"But there was another, even stronger reason that many of us felt justified our working as hard as we could on the bomb. It was felt that if it were possible to make atomic bombs, somewhere, someday, someone would figure out how to do it and some country would proceed to make them. If this were done after World War II was over, the bomb would very likely be made as a secret weapon. This would inevitably lead to World War III. Therefore, there were strong reasons for trying to make the bomb - and use it - before the end of World War II. The people of the world would then know the terrible thing that could be unleashed if there were a World War III. And the politicians could then be encouraged to try to do something about preventing World War III." <ref>Walter Kauzmann’s [http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/121599163/PDFSTART Reminiscences from a life in protein physical chemistry], Protein Science (1993) Vol 2, pgs 671-691.</ref>
In 1946, Kauzmann returned to Princeton as an Assistant Professor of Chemistry and remained on the Princeton Faculty throughout his long academic career. His work was centered in the area of [[biophysical chemistry]], particularly the studies of the structure and [[thermodynamics]] of proteins. His insight that hydrophobic interactions play a key role in stabilizing protein structure was made before [[X-ray crystallography]] provided the first three-dimensional structures of proteins.<ref name = "Hydrophobic_effect" /> Kauzmann's model, that proteins fold to bury hydrophobic residues and to expose [[Hydrophile|hydrophilic]] ones, has stood the test of time <ref>[[Charles Tanford|Tanford, C.]] & Reynolds, J. Nature's Robots: A History of Proteins Ch. 12 (Oxford Univ. Press, Oxford, 2001</ref> and is one of the key principles of [[de novo protein structure prediction]]. Kauzmann became an emeritus professor in 1982.
His first book, ''Quantum Chemistry'', was published in 1957, followed by ''The Kinetic Theory of Gases'' (1966) and ''Thermodynamics and Statistics'' (1967). With [[David Eisenberg]], a former postdoctoral fellow of Kauzmann, he wrote ''The Structure and Properties of Water'' (1969), a book reissued in 2005 by Oxford University Press as part of its Classic Texts in the Physical Sciences series. The first three are textbooks for undergraduate physical chemistry, which Kauzmann taught at Princeton for many years. Kauzmann's pedagogy is discussed in an article by [[Bruce Alberts]].<ref>Bruce Alberts, Walter Kauzmann’s contribution to the future of science: a personal recollection, Biophysical Chemistry (2003) Vol. 105, pgs. 175-177.</ref>
Kauzmann married Elizabeth Flagler Kauzmann, then a research assistant in the laboratory of Frank Johnson in the Princeton Biology Department, in April, 1951. Elizabeth died in 2004 after more than 50 years of marriage. They are survived by two sons, a daughter, and eight grandchildren. They summered on [[Cape Breton Island]], and eventually donated {{convert|40|acre|m2}} of their property to the Nova Scotia Nature Trust.<ref>[http://nsnt.ca/ourwork/explorer/?id=12 Nova Scotia Nature Trust]</ref>
==Awards and honors==
* [[Guggenheim Fellowship]]s (1957 and 1994) * Elected to the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] (1963) * Elected to the [[United States National Academy of Sciences]] (1964) * Inaugural Linderstrøm-Lang Prize for outstanding contributions in the areas of biochemistry or physiology (1966). * Honorary Ph.D. from The University of Stockholm (1992) * Stein and Moore Award of the Protein Society “for his seminal work on the physical chemistry of proteins.” (1993) * A special issue of Elsevier's 'Biophysical Chemistry' was published in September 2003, Volume 105, Issues 2-3, Pages 153-772, to celebrate Walter Kauzmann's 85th Birthday. * Princeton University established an annual Walter Kauzmann Lectureship in Chemistry. (2008)

McKenzie. *[http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=2142097 Walter Kauzmann's Stein and Moore Award Citation]. *Walter Kauzmann’s [http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/121599163/PDFSTART Reminiscences from a life in protein physical chemistry], Protein Science (1993) Vol. 2, pgs 671-691 (Public Access). *[http://www.nap.edu/html/biomems/heyring.html Kauzmann’s Biographical Memoir of his mentor, [[Henry Eyring (chemist)|Henry Eyring]]] * Walter Kauzmann [http://www.cell.com/biophysj/abstract/S0006-3495%2864%2986925-3 The Three Dimensional Structure of Proteins] (1964) Biophysical Journal Vol. 4, pgs 43-54.

{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox military person |name= William Pope McArthur |image= WPMcArthur.jpg |caption= |birth_date= April 2, 1814 |death_date= December 23, 1850 |birth_place= [[Ste. Genevieve, Missouri]] |death_place= At sea |nickname= |allegiance= |branch= [[United States Navy]] |serviceyears= 1832 - 1850 |rank= [[Lieutenant Commander]] |unit= [[U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey]] |commands= USS ''Consort''
US survey schooner ''Ewing'' |battles= [[Second Seminole War]] |awards= |relations= |laterwork= }} '''William Pope McArthur''' (April 2, 1814 – December 23, 1850) was an [[United States Navy|American naval]] officer and [[hydrologist]] who was involved in the first surveys of the [[Pacific Coast]] for the [[U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey]]. ==Early life== McArthur was born in [[Ste. Genevieve, Missouri]] to John and Mary (Linn) McArthur. McArthur's maternal uncle, [[Lewis Fields Linn|Dr. Lewis F. Linn]], was [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] for [[Missouri]]. At Linn's request, McArthur was appointed [[Midshipman]] in the [[U.S. Navy]] on February 11, 1832. In 1837 he attended the Naval School at [[Norfolk, Virginia]]. During the [[Second Seminole War]] (1837–1838), McArthur was promoted to the temporary rank of Lieutenant and placed in command of a small craft. Among the passengers was [[Joseph E. Johnston]], who accompanied the vessel as a civilian topographical engineer. He later served as a general in the US Army and then the Confederate Army during the [[American Civil War]].McArthur, Lewis [http://www.history.noaa.gov/stories_tales/mcarthur_pacificcoast.html ''Pacific Coast Survey of 1849 and 1850''] Private history 1915 NOAA.gov retrieved December 26, 2007 McArthur was wounded in both legs by Seminole at [[Jupiter, Florida]]. While one musket ball was pulled from one leg, a ball remained in the other leg. He was sent to the Naval Hospital in [[Norfolk, Virginia]] for treatment and convalescence. There he met, courted, and married Mary Stone Young, the daughter of the Superintendent of the Hospital. Among their children was [[Lewis Linn McArthur]], an [[Oregon Supreme Court]] Justice. In 1840 he began a survey of the [[Gulf Of Mexico]] aboard the brig ''[[USS Consort (1836)|Consort]]''. ==Survey of the Pacific Coast== [[File:Cape Disappointment1.jpg|thumb|Cape Disappointment Lighthouse]] On October 27, 1848 [[Alexander Dallas Bache|A.D. Bache]], Superintendent U.S. Coast Survey, instructed him to go to San Francisco, California to begin "the survey of the Western Coast of the United States." After sailing from New York McArthur was delayed in Panama by the influx of settlers in the [[California Gold Rush]]. In Panama, McArthur was asked to captain a former coal storage ship to San Francisco. The ''von Humboldt'' left Panama on May 21, 1849 and took 102 days to arrive at San Francisco, the first 46 of which were spent getting to the Mexican port of Acapulco. Among the four hundred passengers on ''von Humboldt'' were [[Collis P. Huntington]], the future president of the [[Southern Pacific Railroad]] and San Francisco Society portrait painter [[Stephen William Shaw|Stephen W. Shaw]]. In September 1849, [[Lieutenant Commander]] McArthur was placed in command of the US survey schooner ''Ewing'' which had been brought around the [[Cape Horn]] to the west coast by Lieutenant [[Washington Allon Bartlett]].http://www.lib.noaa.gov/noaainfo/heritage/coastsurveyvol1/BACHE6.html Upon reaching San Francisco, The ''Ewing'' and the ''[[USS Massachusetts (1845)|USS Massachusetts]]'' were hampered from progress in the survey due to desertions of their crews to the goldfields, including a mutiny when crew members rowing into the city from the ''Ewing'' threw an officer overboard in an attempt to desert to flee to the gold fields.{{cite web|last=Gudde|first=Dr. Erwin G.|url=http://www.history.noaa.gov/stories_tales/ewingmutiny.html|title=Mutiny on the Ewing|accessdate=January 2, 2008}} Originally published in The JOURNAL, Coast and Geodetic Survey, 1951-12-01, Number 4 They managed to survey [[Mare Island Strait]] before steaming to Hawaii to obtain crewmen from Hawaiian monarch [[Kamehameha III|King Kamehameha III]]. They returned to San Francisco in the spring of 1850 with the coastal survey of northern California beginning on 1850-04-03 and continued up to the mouth of the [[Columbia River]] On August 1, 1850, while still in Oregon, McArthur purchased a 1/16 interest in [[Mare Island]] for $468.50 then returned to San Francisco later that month to prepare charts and write reports. ===Cape Disappointment and Cape Flattery Lighthouses=== In 1848 Congress had appropriated funds for two [[lighthouses]] in the act creating the [[Oregon Territory]].{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} McArthur was to recommend placing one at [[Cape Disappointment Lighthouse|Cape Disappointment]] on the Columbia and one at [[Cape Flattery Lighthouse|Cape Flattery]] at the entrance to [[Puget Sound]]. In his report McArthur wrote:
The greatly increasing commerce of Oregon demands that these improvements be made immediately… Within the last eighteen months more vessels have crossed the [[Columbia Bar|Columbia river bar]] than had crossed it, perhaps, in all time past.Hannable. William [http://www.historylink.org/essays/output.cfm?file_id=5622 Historylink.org] 2003-12-06 retrieved 2008-01-02
===Oregon Territory=== McArthur and some of his ship mates were quite taken with Oregon and the [[Willamette Valley]], he wrote:
The climate is agreeable and healthy. The water is not inferior to any in the world. The face of the country is too uneven to permit as general cultivation, still it will and must soon become a great agricultural and stock growing country. The scenery is beautiful and in some places and some points of view the grandest that the eye ever beheld.
[[Simon F. Blunt|Lieutenant Blunt]] who accompanied him on the expedition even made a [[Homestead Act|land claim]] on behalf of himself, McArthur and Bartlett. McArthur's uncle, Senator Linn, along with Senator [[Thomas Hart Benton (senator)|Thomas Hart Benton]], had been an advocate of [[Manifest Destiny|American expansion]] in the West.Schwantes, Carlos Arnaldo ''The Pacific Northwest - An Interpretive History'' University of Nebraska Press 1989 1996 Rev. and enl. ed. p. 92 {{ISBN|0-8032-9228-7}} ==Death== McArthur was not to survive the voyage to the east coast in 1850. He became ill onboard with [[dysentery]], died, and was buried in Panama. The Navy purchased the original 956 acres (387 ha) of the [[Mare Island Naval Shipyard]] on January 4, 1853. McArthur's family share was $5,218.20. in 1867, his body was disinterred and he was reburied on Mare Island. ==Ships and Placenames== McArthur's name is applied to several ships and placenames. *[[McArthur (schooner)|''McArthur'']], a [[schooner]] launched in 1876 *[[USC&GS McArthur (1874)|USC&GS ''McArthur'']], a [[survey ship]] in service in the [[United States Coast Survey]] from 1876 to 1878 and in the [[United States Coast and Geodetic Survey]] from 1878 to 1915 *[[SS William P. McArthur|SS ''William P. Mcarthur'']], a [[Liberty ship]] launched in 1942 *USC&GS ''McArthur'' (MSS 22), later [[NOAAS McArthur (S 330)]], a [[survey ship]] in service the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey from 1966 to 1970 and in the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] from 1970 to 2003, since 2006 a [[Blackwater Worldwide|Blackwater]] vessel *[[NOAAS McArthur II (R 330)|NOAAS ''McArthur II'' (R 330)]], an [[Oceanography|oceanographic]] [[research ship]] in service in the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration since 2003 *[[McArthur Peak (Alaska)]] - a {{convert|2239|ft|m|sing=on}} mountain on [[Kuiu Island]] in Alaska *[[McArthur Reef]], a reef in the [[Sumner Strait]] off [[Clarence Strait]] in Alaska ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Find a Grave|125198922}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McArthur, William Pope}} [[Category:United States Coast Survey personnel]] [[Category:1814 births]] [[Category:1850 deaths]] [[Category:People from Ste. {{unreferenced|date=August 2011}} '''Yu Huiyong''' ({{zh|c=于会泳|p=Yú Huìyǒng|w=Yu Hui-yung}}) (1925–1977) was a Chinese artist and politician of the [[Communist Party of China]] and the [[People's Republic of China]]. He is known for the art he made of [[Mao Zhedong]], the then-leader of China. ==Biography== Yu Huiyong was born in [[Shandong Province]] in 1925. He was greatly interested in [[music]] and learned to play a variety of instruments such as the erhu, the sanxian, and the dizi. During the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]], he joined a communist performance group, and in 1949 went to teach at the [[Shanghai Conservatory of Music]] (while simultaneously studying [[popular music]]), helping at turning a Western-oriented institution into a training ground for the communist art of [[People's Republic of China|People's China]]. In the meantime, he joined the [[Communist Party of China]]. He graduated in 1950 but continued to work in the field of music. In the same year, Yu Huiyong was transferred to the Research Institute on Ethnic Music, where he wrote many essays on music styles in China's provinces and took part in creating orchestral performances. In later years, he continued teaching and writing, publishing a comprehensive essay on China's folk music in 1959. In 1962 he was promoted to [[lecturer]] at the [[Shanghai]] Conservatory, and deputy director of its musical theory department the following year. In 1965 he was appointed member of the Drama Reform and Creative Group, and worked on musical embellishment of ''Taking Tiger Mountain by Strategy'', one of the "eight model revolutionary theatrical works" re-elaborated by [[Jiang Qing]]. In 1966, when the [[Cultural Revolution]] broke out, Yu Huiyong and many of the Shanghai Conservatory staff were targeted as bourgeois intellectuals and forced to resign, submit to self-criticism and criticism by students, and do physical labor. Yu Huiyong however took active part at the movement: he was called to [[Beijing]] to stage the "eight model revolutionary theatrical works", then returned to Shanghai where he joined the "rebel faction". In 1967 he was appointed vice-chairman of the Shanghai Conservatory Revolutionary Committee, chairman of the preparatory committee for the Shanghai Cultural Revolutionary Committee, and put in charge of the Shanghai [[Peking Opera]] Theatre. He worked directly under [[Zhang Chunqiao]], one of the [[Gang of Four]]. Taking an ever more prominent role, in 1968 Yu Huiyong chaired the criticism meeting against [[He Luting]], president of the Shanghai Conservatory of Music. In 1969 he participated to the [[National Congress of the Communist Party of China|CPC 9th National Congress]] and was appointed standing committee member of the Shanghai Municipal Revolutionary Committee. In 1970 Yu Huiyong was transferred to Beijing to become a member of the Cultural Group Under the [[State Council of the People's Republic of China]] chaired by [[Wu De]]. He was in charge of following movie transposition of model operas like ''[[The Legend of the Red Lantern]]'', ''[[Red Detachment of Women (ballet)|Red Detachment of Women]]'', etc. In 1973 he was elected member of the [[Central Committee of the Communist Party of China|CPC Central Committee]] by the Party's 10th Congress, and also appointed deputy head of the Cultural Group; later he was promoted to [[Ministry of Culture of the People's Republic of China|Minister of Culture]] in 1975 as the post was re-established by the 1st Session of the [[4th National People's Congress]]. In the last stages of the Cultura Revolution, Yu Huiyong oversaw art production and anti-revisionist works in China, as the film ''Chunmiao'' (Spring Sprout), which was criticized by [[Deng Xiaoping]] as "ultra-leftist". All of this led him to be accused of being part of the Gang of Four plot, aspiring to be a [[Vice Premier of the People's Republic of China|vice-premier]] and [[Politburo of the Communist Party of China|CPC Politburo]] member. For that he was arrested in October 1976. He committed suicide in August 1977. {{S-start}} {{S-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Wu De]]|as=Head of the State Council Cultural Group}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Ministry of Culture of the People's Republic of China|Minister of Culture of the People's Republic of China]]|years=1975–1976}} {{s-aft|after=[[Huang Zhen]]

'''Zbigniew Marian Wilczek Alba''' or '''Ziggy the bagman''' as he is known, is a man who chooses to be homeless and can be found in the inner [[Brisbane]] suburb of [[Toowong]]. Ziggy objects to being labelled as "homeless" as he does not ask for food, money or clothing and actually enjoys his current living conditions, despite being without a home of his own and living in a public park. More recently he has gained much media attention, becoming a controversial issue in two consecutive local [[elections]].<ref>{{Cite news | edition = 1 - First with the news | page = 4 | last1 = Heywood | first1 = Lachlan |last2=Thompson |first2=Erica | title = Bagman rules great mayoral debate | work = [[The Courier-Mail]] | location = Brisbane | date = 2004-02-28 }}</ref>
==Biography== Despite the lack of information pertaining to his early life it is known that Ziggy the bagman was born as Zbigniew Marian Wilczek in the early 1950s and was of a [[Poles|Polish]] nationality. His name was later changed to Tim Jenkins. While it is unknown when exactly he became homeless, he had been sighted in Jephson Street Toowong as early as 1989. He became known by the locals as either "Tim" or "Ziggy". "Ziggy the bagman" became his nickname throughout his ongoing media coverage.
He entered public view in the year 2000 with the then [[Lord Mayor]] [[Jim Soorley]] protesting the complaints of several Toowong businesses requesting that he be removed on the grounds that he was bad for business and his low levels of hygiene attracted rats. Soorley claimed that he was completely within the law in his position. As he gained attention, he was in increased danger, with his small home being attacked several times by various groups demanding his removal from Toowong. His publicity only grew and since then has featured in local news reports several times.
Early in 2004 he was the subject of "Operation Ziggy", an effort by [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] presenter (from 612 AM) [[Spencer Howson]] to find him a home. After being interviewed on air, it was revealed that Ziggy was not so willing to be a party to this scheme and so the plan collapsed.<ref name=operationziggy>{{Cite web| title = Spencer's "Operation Ziggy" Collapses on Day One | work = [[612 ABC Brisbane]] | date = 2004-01-19 | url = http://www.abc.net.au/brisbane/stories/s1028202.htm |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20041217195513/http://www.abc.net.au/brisbane/stories/s1028202.htm |archivedate = 2004-12-17}}</ref>
Later that year a portrait of him painted by local artist Bruce Chapman was entered in the Archibald Prize.<ref>{{Cite news | edition = 2 - State - Main Country | page = 34 | last = Lawrence | first = Jessica | title = Portrait of a bagman - Painting of homeless Ziggy in the Archibald Prize | work = [[The Sunday Mail (Brisbane)]] | date = 2004-03-14 }}</ref> His only requested payment was $8 worth of food, including [[ice cream]], several [[cookie|biscuits]] and a bottle of [[soft drink]]. Ziggy also gave an interview for a similar fee of $10.<ref>[http://upload.sjc.uq.edu.au/2005/pdfs/timoct6.pdf Interview with Ziggy] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060824050110/http://upload.sjc.uq.edu.au/2005/pdfs/timoct6.pdf |date=August 24, 2006 }}</ref>
During July 2004, he is said to have had his first shower and his home became too messy by his own self-imposed rules; the police were called in to help clean up and Ziggy promised to move by Christmas. He found a new spot in a local barbecue area, remaining in Toowong. After more attacks on him midway through 2005, new calls were made to have him taken off the streets, Lord Mayor [[Campbell Newman]] insists, just as his predecessor did, that Ziggy is breaking no laws and will not be forced to move, despite Newman's personal hopes that he could be moved to a "proper place". In December 2005 his possessions were confiscated by police due to smell and vermin.
In July 2006 Ziggy moved on from his High Street<ref>{{Cite news | edition = 1 - First with the news | page = 31 | last = Atfield | first = Cameron | title = Ziggy in stardust as he abandons High Street | work = [[The Courier-Mail]] | location = Brisbane | date = 2006-07-27 | url = http://www.couriermail.news.com.au/story/0,20797,19926406-3102,00.html }}</ref> location to a new spot at Oakman Park. Radio News reported that he moved because of attacks at his old location. He later moved to Toowong Creek. <ref>{{Cite web | last = Levingston | first = Rebecca | title = Ziggy's great escape | work = [[612 ABC Brisbane]] | format = item | accessdate = 2012-10-09 | date = 2008-12-02 | url = http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2008/12/02/2435161.htm }}</ref> Ziggy has most recently moved to a Taringa park between Morrow Street and Moggil Road.<ref>{{Cite web| last = McDonald| first = Shae| title = Ziggy the bagman at home in park| work = [[The Courier-Mail]]| accessdate = 2017-01-14| date = 2016-07-10| url = http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/ziggy-the-bagman-now-lives-at-taringa/news-story/4d3070464318b5fc602fdcc75f7c7abc}}</ref>
